questions.text: The most common site of branchial cyst is ______.

choices.text: Junction of upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle
Junction of middle and lower third of the sternomastoid muscle
Between the two heads of the sternomastoid muscle

questions.solution:
The most common site of a branchial cyst is at the junction of the upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle at its anterior border.

Branchial cyst develops from the vestigial remnants of the second branchial cleft. It is usually lined by squamous epithelium and contains thick, turbid fluid full of cholesterol crystals. It is fluctuant and may transilluminate to a lesser extent when it contains clear fluid.

A branchial fistula may be acquired or congenital. The congenital fistula is seen at the junction of the middle and lower third of the sternomastoid. An acquired fistula is usually seen in cases of incomplete surgery for the branchial cyst or spontaneous rupture, and it is seen at the same site as the cyst.

The below image shows a large right-sided branchial cyst.

questions.text: A child was born with membranes around the body and had ectropion and eclabium. He is brought to the OPD with lesions covering his face, trunk, and extremities. Which of the following is an unlikely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture shows a neonate encased in a shiny, parchment-like membrane (collodion baby) suggestive of a disorder belonging to the autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis spectrum and ichthyosis vulgaris is unlikely the diagnosis because it does not present at birth.

Ichthyosis vulgaris is an autosomal dominant condition caused due to a mutation in the filaggrin gene (FLG). It develops in the first few months of life. Patients exhibit accentuated palmar and plantar creases and have dry scaly skin. The scales appear light grey and cover the extensor surfaces of the limbs and the trunk. It usually spares the groin and larger flexures. Immunohistochemistry reveals an absent or markedly reduced filaggrin signal.

Autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis spectrum includes the following:

  • Harlequin ichthyosis (HI).
  • Bathing suit ichthyosis (BSI).
  • Lamellar ichthyosis (LI).
  • Congenital ichthyosiform erythroderma (CIE).
  • Self- improving congenital ichthyosis (SICI).
  • Transient manifestations, such as collodion baby.

Ichthyotic scales are large and polygonal with a thickened, fish-scale appearance of the skin, in ichthyosis vulgaris as shown in the image below.

Other options :

Option B: Lamellar ichthyosis is associated with shedding of the collodion membrane, followed by the development of large dark grey/brownish scales affecting the trunk and the scalp, but sparing the face and extremities.

Option C: Bathing suit ichthyosis the babies are born as collodion babies, they later develop a lamellar type of ichthyosis that spares the face and the extremities, and follows the distribution pattern of bathing suits.

Option D: Harlequin ichthyosis is the most devastating type of autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis. It occurs due to mutations of the ABCA12 gene. It is associated with thickened skin over nearly the entire body at birth. Neonates are born with armor-like skin (truncal plates with fissuring). The skin forms large, diamond-shaped plates that are separated by deep cracks, as shown in the image below.

questions.text: Which of the following is least useful in the management of a patient with Thalamic Dejerine syndrome?
questions.solution:
Among the options provided, ibuprofen, which is an analgesic (NSAID) is considered the least effective in the management of Thalamic Dejerine Syndrome.

Thalamic Dejerine Syndrome, also known as Thalamic Pain Syndrome or Central Post-Stroke Pain, is a condition characterized by severe and often chronic pain on one side of the body following damage to the thalamus in the brain, commonly due to a stroke.

Occlusion of these thalamic and thalamogeniculate branches results in thalamic pain syndrome. It is characterized by C/L hemi-sensory loss which starts as numbness and progresses to cause severe burning pain in the affected regions.

As the thalamus is the site for the relay of sensory information between the periphery and cortex, a lesion in the thalamus causes a miscommunication between the afferent pathway and the cortex of the brain. Pain occurs during the recovery from the thalamic infarct.

This pain responds poorly to analgesics. 

Anticonvulsants such as carbamazepine, gabapentin, or tricyclic antidepressants like amitriptyline may be beneficial.

Related Pearl: Medullary syndromes and Weber syndrome

Syndrome

Vessel involved

Clinical features

Medial Medullary syndrome / Dejerine syndrome

Vertebral artery/Anterior spinal artery
  • C/L loss of conscious proprioception
  • C/L hemiplegia
  • I/L tongue paralysis

Lateral Medullary syndrome / Wallenberg syndrome

Vertebral artery>Posterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • C/L loss of pain/temperature on the body
  • I/L loss of pain/temperature on face
  • Ataxia
  • Nystagmus
  • Vertigo
  • Horner's syndrome
  • dysphagia
  • Ipsilateral bulbar paralysis
  • Loss of gag reflex

Weber's syndrome

Posterior cerebral artery
  • I/L Oculomotor nerve palsy - ptosis with fixed dilated pupil pointed down and out
  • C/L hemiplegia
  • C/L paralysis of the lower face

C/L- Contralateral

I/L-Ipsilateral

questions.text: Personal monitoring of radiation is done using _______.
questions.solution:
Personal monitoring of radiation is done by a thermoluminescent dosimeter (TLD) badge.

A TLD badge is made up of lithium fluoride or dysprosium.

The badge should be positioned according to local or national practices. In India, one TLD badge has to be worn at the chest level inside the lead apron, if the apron is used. An additional wrist badge has to be worn for procedures requiring hands close to the primary beam. 

The given image shows a TLD badge.

questions.text: Which of the following pairs is incorrect?

choices.text: Rosenbach sign - Pulsations of the liver
Traube's sign - Pulsations of the spleen
Muller's sign - Systolic pulsations of uvula

questions.solution:
The incorrect pair is Traube's sign - Pulsations of the spleen. Traube's sign is a pistol shot sound heard over femoral arteries seen in aortic regurgitation (AR).

Aortic regurgitation (AR) is a valvular disease of the aortic valve caused by primary valve disease, aortic root disease or their combination.

Auscultatory findings in AR are:

  • Soft S1 - due to the early closure of the mitral valve
  • Diminished or absent A2
  • S3 - due to increased left ventricular (LV) end-diastolic volume. The presence of S3 may be a sign of impaired LV function.
  • Early diastolic murmur -
    • High-pitched, blowing, decrescendo, early diastolic murmur
    • Best heard in the left-third intercostal space
    • Heard with the patient sitting up and leaning forward, with breath held in forced expiration
    • Duration of the murmur best correlates with the severity
  • Systolic ejection murmur - It is heard due to increased LV stroke volume and ejection rate.
  • Austin Flint murmur - a low-pitched, mid to late diastolic murmur. It is caused due to the large volume of regurgitant blood, hitting the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve or LV wall.

Other signs :

  • Gerhardt’s sign- Pulsations of the spleen, detected in the presence of splenomegaly (Option B)
  • Rosenbach sign- pulsations are felt over the liver (Option A)
  • Becker's sign is the presence of retinal artery pulsation on fundoscopy (Option C)
  • Muller's sign- systolic pulsations of the uvula (Option D)

Treatment of aortic regurgitation:

In non-severe AR, periodic monitoring can be done. Diuretics and vasodilators can manage the symptoms of dyspnea and decreased cardiac output.

In severe AR, surgery is indicated in the following conditions:

  • The patient is symptomatic
  • The patient is asymptomatic, but the LV ejection fraction is less than 50% or LV end-diastolic diameter is more than 65mm.
  • The patient is asymptomatic and undergoing other cardiac surgeries.

Related Pearl: Different signs in Aortic Regurgitation

Sign

Description

De Musset's sign

  Head nodding with each heartbeat

Collapsing/Water Hammer/Corrigan pulse

 It is a bounding pulse with rapid upstroke  and descent

Lighthouse sign

  Alternate flushing & blanching of the forehead

Landolfi’s sign

  Alternating constriction and dilation of the pupil

Becker’s sign

  Retinal artery pulsations

Quincke’s pulse

 Alternate flushing and paling of the skin at the root of the nail while pressure is applied to the tip of the nail
Rosenbach’s sign  Pulsation of liver
Gerhardt’s sign  Pulsation over the spleen, detected in the presence of splenomegaly

Traube’s sign

 A pistol shot sound over femoral arteries

Durozeiz’s sign

 To-and-fro murmur over the femoral artery when lightly compressed with a stethoscope

Hill’s sign

 The systolic blood pressure of the lower limb exceeds that of the upper limb at least by 20mm Hg

Muller’s sign

Systolic pulsation of the uvula

questions.text: A middle-aged woman who presented with features of tremors, palpitations, weight loss, and menstrual irregularities is diagnosed with Grave's disease. Which of the following statements is true with respect to the thyroid function test report in Graves' disease?

choices.text: Radioactive Iodine Uptake (RAIU) at 24 hours below normal

questions.solution:
The true statement concerning the thyroid function test report in Graves' disease is the level of serum TSH is low.

Grave’s disease is an autoimmune disorder due to the production of TSH-receptor-stimulating immunoglobulins (TSI) which cause hyperthyroidism. It is characterized by the triad of thyrotoxicosis, infiltrative ophthalmopathy (exophthalmos), and dermopathy (pretibial myxedema).

Grossly, there is a diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland and a beefy deep red parenchyma. Histology shows tall crowded follicular cells with scalloped margins and lymphoid infiltrates. Laboratory features include elevations in free T3 and T4 and decreased TSH.

Propylthiouracil is the mainstay of treatment for Graves' disease, but it does not affect Graves' ophthalmopathy. Radioactive iodine is also used as a treatment modality for hyperthyroidism in suitable patients.

Related Pearl: Radioactive iodine uptake scan

Hyperthyroidism with high/ normal uptake Hyperthyroidism with low uptake
Graves’ disease Subacute/ Dequervain thyroiditis
Toxic MNG Thyrotoxicosis factitia
Toxic adenoma Viral
TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma Metastatic follicular thyroid carcinoma
HCG induced thyrotoxicosis Radiation thyroiditis, Struma ovarii

questions.text: Identify the maternal condition that can lead to the findings in the baby as shown below.
questions.solution:
The image showing a poorly developed lower limb suggests the diagnosis of caudal regression sequence/sacral agenesis seen in pregestational diabetes. It is the most specific anomaly seen in diabetes. 

Gastrulation is the process that forms all the 3 germ layers namely, ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm in the embryo. It occurs during the 3rd week of gestation. In cases of caudal dysgenesis, also known as sirenomelia, there is a lack of mesoderm formation in the most caudal region of the embryo. Abnormalities occur in the lower limbs, urogenital system (intermediate mesoderm), and lumbosacral vertebrae due to the contribution of the mesoderm to their creation. Individuals affected with this condition have a diverse array of abnormalities, such as underdevelopment and merging of the lower limbs, defects in the vertebrae, absence of the kidneys, an imperforate anus, and abnormalities in the genital system.

The caudal regression sequence is a rare malformation, frequently associated with maternal pre-gestational diabetes. It consists of a spectrum of structural defects of the caudal region, including incomplete development of the sacrum and the lumbar vertebrae.

Elevated maternal HbA1c levels correlate with fetal malformations. It occurs approximately 200 times more frequently in infants of diabetic mothers than in other infants. 

Overt diabetes (pregestational diabetes) is associated with higher malformation rates than the general population. Neural tube defects (encephalocele, meningomyelocele, anencephaly), transposition of great vessels, ventricular septal defect, atrial septal defect, hypoplastic left heart, aortic stenosis and coarctation of the aorta are commonly seen. Small left colon syndrome is a rare anomaly that develops in the second and third trimesters.

Other options:

Option B: Malformations are not associated with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM). Malformations occur due to the disruption of organogenesis, usually occurring in the first trimester. The abnormal glycemic status in GDM manifests only in the second trimester. 

Option C: Valproate leads to neural tube defects and not sacral agenesis.

Option D: ACE inhibitors can cause oligohydramnios.

questions.text: What is the use of the following instrument used in orthopaedic surgeries ?

choices.text: To cut bone while performing an osteotomy
To scrape tissue from a cavity or nidus
To hold the plate intact with the bone

questions.solution:
The instrument depicted is a bone curette and it is used for curettage or scraping a cavity in the bone or removing fibrous tissue from the ends of a fracture. It is used in the management of enchondroma, GCT, and osteomyelitis.

Other options -

Option A - An osteotome is used for cutting bone in surgeries such as corrective osteotomies and they are bevelled at both sides.

Option C -A periosteal elevator is used to elevate the periosteum, as nerves and vessels are generally on this plane, and once elevated there is a safer plane for surgery.

Option D: A bone and plate holding forceps is used to hold the plate and bone together in alignment during screw fixation.

Related Pearl: Orthopedic Instruments

questions.text: False statement about Proseal LMA is

choices.text: Single use second generation airway device
Gastric drainage tube to remove secretions
Can be used in laparoscopic surgery

questions.solution:
False statement about proseal LMA is, it is a single use second generation airway device.

Proseal laryngeal mask airway (LMA) is a reusable second-generation supraglottic airway device. It has an built in bite block (Option B), a drainage tube to remove gastric secretions (Option C) and an improved cuff design.

This reduces the risk of aspiration and hence may be suitable in non-supine positions (e.g., lateral, prone), in laparoscopic surgery (Option D) and in patients who are obese.

Note: All these features are also present in LMA Supreme, except that it is a single-use second generation supraglottic device.

The images of proseal and supreme LMA's are given below.

Related Pearl: Indications and contraindications of Laryngeal mask airway (LMA)

Indication:

  • Difficult airway management during cardiopulmonary resuscitation.
  • In emergency where intubation & mask ventilation is not possible. 
  • For minor surgeries, where Anesthetist wants to avoid intubation. 
  • As a conduit for bronchoscopes, small size tubes, gum elastic bougies.
  • Mouth opening < 1.5cm

Contraindications:

  • Oropharyngeal abscess or mass
  • Conditions with high risk of aspiration:
    • Hiatus hernia
    • Pregnancy
    • Full stomach patients who are vulnerable to go in bronchospasm
    • Low pulmonary compliance (eg. Obesity)
    • Peak inspiratory pressure > 20 cm of H2O.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents to the casualty with spotting per vagina, preceded by 8 weeks of amenorrhea. Her blood pressure is 80/50 mmHg, pulse rate is 140 beats/minute, and her urine pregnancy test is positive. The most appropriate management for this condition would be ______.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of ruptured ectopic pregnancy and the best management is by immediate laparotomy.

Diagnosis of ruptured ectopic pregnancy is made based on clinical features:

  • Amenorrhoea for 6-8 weeks followed by bleeding PV.
  • Abdominal pain.
  • Hemodynamically unstable.
  • Urine pregnancy test - positive.

Medical management (Option A) is indicated when the patient is asymptomatic and hemodynamically stable. It involves the systemic or local use of chemotherapeutic drugs like methotrexate 50 mg/m2 single dose intramuscularly.

Surgical treatment of ectopic pregnancy includes salpingectomy or salpingostomy(Option c), performed either through laparoscopy or laparotomy.

Management of suspected ruptured ectopic pregnancy consists of initial resuscitation and stabilization, followed by point-of-care ultrasound (FAST) to identify intraperitoneal free fluid and surgical exploration. 

Laparotomy is done for hemodynamically unstable patients with ruptured ectopic pregnancies. Salpingectomy is the treatment of choice and is done with the preservation of the ipsilateral ovary and its vascular supply. 

For patients wishing to preserve future fertility, if the contralateral fallopian tube is damaged, salpingostomy is preferred. However, salpingostomy may result in inadequate evacuation of the products of conception and a recurrence of symptoms. Therefore, after a patient undergoes salpingostomy, it is important to check the β-hCG level every week (Option D) to ensure that it reaches zero.

The image given below shows a laparoscopic visualization of a tubal pregnancy.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the image given below?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis in this patient is bronchiectasis. The CT scan shows the signet ring sign is specific for bronchiectasis where the internal diameter of the bronchi is greater than the adjacent pulmonary artery.

The clinical scenario observed in bronchiectasis is: 

  • Repeated chest infections 
  • Presence of large amounts of yellow sputum 
  • Non-smoker 

Bronchiectasis refers to the irreversible dilatation of one or more bronchi, which occurs due to recurrent cycles of infection, inflammation, and tissue damage. Development of the disease requires an infectious insult in combination with impaired bacterial clearance (eg, impaired immune defences, structural airway defect).

Bronchiectasis is commonly associated with

  • Kartagener syndrome
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis.

Radiological findings - Chest X-ray shows tram track appearance due to the dilated airways. 

CT findings include:

  • Signet ring sign 
  • Lack of bronchial tapering
  • Tree-in-bud pattern - It occurs due to the thickening of the dilated airways along with the inspissated secretions.
  • Cysts originating from the bronchial wall (pronounced in cystic bronchiectasis)

Note: High-Resolution CT (HRCT) is the best method for the diagnosis of bronchiectasis. 

Other options:

Option A: Pulmonary tuberculosis is an infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Patients often present with chronic cough and hemoptysis. Low-grade fever, anorexia, and weight loss are the commonly associated symptoms. CT findings of pulmonary tuberculosis are Ghon focus, Ranke complex, nodal calcifications, cavities, and hilar/paratracheal lymphadenopathy.

Option B: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease[COPD], is inflammation-induced destruction of lung parenchyma resulting from cigarette smoke or other pollutants. Patients typically will be smokers with exertional dyspnea, and cough with productive sputum. Lung hyperinflation (emphysema) and airflow obstruction are characteristic of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. 

Option C: Bronchial asthma is an airway hyperresponsiveness disease characterized by reversible airway narrowing and obstruction by mucus plugging. Patients typically present with symptoms such as wheezing, shortness of breath, chest tightness, and cough usually on exposure to triggering agents. CT findings in bronchial asthma are bronchial wall thickening, mucus plugging, decreased lung attenuation, and gas trapping.

Related Pearl: Investigation of Choice in Respiratory Diseases

Disease Investigation of choice
Interstitial lung disease HRCT
Bronchiectasis HRCT
Pulmonary embolism CT Pulmonary Angiography > Ventilation-Perfusion Scan
Calcification CT
Solitary pulmonary nodule CT > PET
Lung Malignancy CT scan
Superior sulcus tumor MRI scan > CT scan

questions.text: A pregnant lady at 38 weeks of gestation delivered a female baby by spontaneous vaginal delivery. Soon after the delivery of the placenta, she developed profuse bleeding per vaginum. Which of the following drugs is not used in the management of this patient ________
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is of postpartum haemorrhage and the drug not used in the management of this patient is mifepristone. 

Mifepristone is an antiprogestin that competes with progesterone and glucocorticoids to bind to their respective receptors. It is considered a progesterone-receptor modulator (PRM). Mifepristone, in combination with Misoprostol or other prostaglandins, is used for the termination of early pregnancy.

Postpartum haemorrhage (PPH) is defined as a loss of more than 500 ml of blood after completion of the third stage of labour (in vaginal delivery) and blood loss of more than 1000 mL from the genital tract following cesarean section. It can be subdivided into primary and secondary PPH. Primary PPH is bleeding that occurs within 24 hours of the delivery of the baby. Secondary PPH is bleeding that occurs beyond 24 hours of delivery and during puerperium. It is also known as delayed or puerperal haemorrhage.

On examination, a flabby uterus is palpated. In case of an atonic uterus, start the patient on crystalloid IV fluids such as normal saline, blood transfusion, massage the uterus, and administer oxytocin drips at the rate of 40-60 drops/ minute or carbetocin 100 micrograms.

The following are the steps used in controlling postpartum haemorrhage:

  • Feel the uterus to know the cause of the haemorrhage. If the uterus feels flabby, bleeding is likely to be due to atonicity. If it is firm and contracted, it is likely to be traumatic in origin.
  • In case of an atonic uterus, massage the uterus and start the patient on oxytocin drips or methergine.
  • If the uterus remains atonic, manual exploration of the uterus is done to remove any retained placental fragments. Blood transfusion is started and oxytocin drips are continued.
  • Carboprost (Option B) is a 15-methyl PGF2 alpha derivative used as a 2nd line drug in the treatment of PPH that is unresponsive to oxytocin. The normal dosage is 0.25mg. The maximum dose is 2mg. It is contraindicated in patients with asthma, and active cardiac, renal, or hepatic disease.
  • Uterine massage and bimanual compression.
  • Uterine tamponade using a hydrostatic balloon catheter (balloon tamponade).
  • Surgical methods to control PPH are outlined as stepwise uterine devascularization procedures:
  • Compression sutures: B-Lynch suture.
  • Ligation of uterine arteries.
  • Ligation of ovarian and uterine anastomosis.
  • Ligation of internal iliac artery.
  • Angiographic embolization of the bleeding vessel.
     
  • Hysterectomy.
Uterotonic drugs Dose for treatment of PPH Dose for prevention of PPH
Oxytocin 10 IU - IM/IV 10 IU - IM/IV
Carbetocin 250 μg - IM 100 μg - IM/IV
Misoprostol (Option A) 600-1000 μg - oral/rectal/ sublingual 400 μg or 600 μg, per-oral
Ergometrine
/methylergometrine(Option D)		 200 μg - IM 200 μg - IM/IV

To effectively prevent PPH, the WHO recommends the use of only one of the uterotonic agents mentioned above. Of these, oxytocin is used as the first-line agent in preventing postpartum haemorrhage. When oxytocin is not available, the other drugs mentioned above can be used based on the clinical condition and availability of the drug.

questions.text: The lower part of vagina is derived from the _______
questions.solution:
The lower part of the vagina is derived from the urogenital sinus.

The upper part of the vagina is derived from the paramesonephric duct or Mullerian duct(Option C). The uterus develops from two Paramesonephric ducts on either side, which unite to form a single uterus.

The image explaining the formation of the uterus and vagina is given below.

Other options :

Option A: The genital ridge forms around the 5th week of embryonic development as a thickening of the intermediate mesoderm, which lies along the posterior abdominal wall, just medial to the developing kidneys. This ridge is initially undifferentiated and can eventually give rise to either testes or ovaries, depending on the genetic and hormonal influences.

Option C and D: Initially, both male and female embryos possess two sets of ducts, the Mullerian ducts and the Wolffian ducts. The Mullerian ducts are the precursor to the female reproductive system, while the Wolffian ducts are the precursor to the male reproductive system.

questions.text: Which of the following provides long-lasting results in a coronary artery bypass graft (CABG)?
questions.solution:
The left internal mammary artery (LIMA) provides long-lasting results in a coronary artery bypass graft (CABG). The most important criterion in conduit selection is graft patency. The conduit with the highest patency rate is the left internal mammary artery or internal thoracic artery.

Left internal mammary artery > Radial artery > long saphenous vein represents the correct order of graft patency in a patient undergoing a CABG procedure.

Venous grafts:

  • The long saphenous vein is the most common vein used as a conduit as it is straightforward to harvest, provides good length, and is easy to handle.
  • The ten-year patency rate for long saphenous vein grafts is reported to be 50–60 percent.

Arterial grafts:

  • The Left internal mammary artery (LIMA) or internal thoracic artery has become the conduit of choice for the left anterior descending (LAD) coronary artery. The radial artery can be used as a second or alternative arterial bypass graft. Other arterial bypass grafts include the gastroepiploic artery and the inferior epigastric artery.
  • Long patency rates of >98 percent have been reported.

Related Pearl: Indications for Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting (CABG)

Class I indications for CABG from the American College of Cardiology(ACC) and American Heart Association(AHA).

  • Left main disease
  • Three-vessel disease with or without proximal LAD disease
  • Two vessel disease with proximal LAD disease
  • Survivors of sudden cardiac death with presumed ischemia-mediated VT  

Other indications for CABG include the following:

  • Disabling angina
  • Ongoing ischemia in the setting of a non–ST-segment elevation (MI) that is unresponsive to medical therapy
  • Poor LV function but with viable, nonfunctioning myocardium above the anatomic defect that can be revascularized

questions.text: A young patient is admitted to the hospital after ingestion of a large number of acetaminophen tablets. To predict the prognosis using King's College hospital criteria in this patient, all of the following parameters you would use except:
questions.solution:
Serum bilirubin is not included in King's College Hospital's criteria for acute liver failure due to paracetamol overdose.

The King's College Hospital criteria is a prognostic tool for patients with acute liver failure(ALF). The criteria is divided into acetaminophen and non-acetaminophen causes of liver failure.

In acute liver failure due to acetaminophen, liver transplantation is indicated if:

  • pH is <7.25 (irrespective of the grade of encephalopathy)
  • Or all the three:
    • INR> 6.5 or prothrombin time (PT) > 100 seconds.
    • Serum creatinine greater than 3.4 mg/dl.
    • The presence of encephalopathy (of grade III or IV).

Liver transplantation is indicated in non-acetaminophen causes of ALF if there is a presence of:

  • Either prothrombin time >100 sec.
  • Or any three of the following
    • jaundice to encephalopathy time > 7 days.
    • Age < 10 or > 40 years.
    • Indeterminate or drug-induced causes.
    • Bilirubin > 300 μmol/L (>3.4 mg/dL).
    • Prothrombin time > 50 secs.
  • Or Factor V level < 15% and encephalopathy grade 3 or 4.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with a known case of diverticulosis presents to the emergency department with pain abdomen. On per abdominal examination, there is guarding and rigidity. During laparotomy, a diverticular perforation is seen with purulent peritonitis.  What is the Hinchey's stage in this case?
questions.solution:
Purulent peritonitis belongs to stage 3 in the Hinchey classification.

Hinchey classification is the most commonly used classification for the severity and complication of acute diverticulitis. It is used additionally to guide the overall management of acute diverticulitis. 

Hinchey classification of complicated diverticulitis.

Stage 1

Mesenteric or pericolic abscess

Stage 2

Pelvic abscess

Stage 3

Purulent peritonitis

Stage 4

Fecal peritonitis

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true concerning a live-donor kidney transplant?

choices.text: The iliac fossa on the posterior abdominal wall is the usual site for kidney placement
The renal artery is anastomosed end-to-end to the external iliac artery.
The renal vein is anastomosed end-to-side to the internal iliac vein
Right kidney is preferred over the left for transplantation.

questions.solution:
The iliac fossa on the posterior abdominal wall is the usual site chosen for kidney placement during transplantation.

Live donor 

  • The donor renal artery is anastomosed end-to-end with the internal iliac artery.
  • The renal vein is anastomosed end-to-end with the external iliac vein.

Deceased donor

  • The renal artery is anastomosed, in an end-to-side fashion, to the common or external iliac artery.
  • The renal vein is anastomosed end-to-side to the external iliac vein or the common iliac vein.

The left kidney is preferred for transplantation because the left renal vein is longer.

Note: In the case of a deceased donor, the arterial graft is traced until the aorta which makes it longer, and hence end-to-side anastomosis is possible. Whereas, in the case of a live donor, the arterial graft cannot be extended until the aorta.

questions.text:
Which of the following are storage symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia?
  1. Urgency
  2. Enuresis
  3. Hesitancy
  4. Frequency
  5. Dribbling
questions.solution:
Urgency, enuresis and frequency are storage symptoms.

Lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) can be classified as:

Storage Voiding
  • Frequency (earliest symptom in BPH)
  • Nocturia
  • Urgency
  • Urge incontinence
  • Nocturnal incontinence (enuresis)
  • Hesitancy
  • Poor flow
  • Intermittent stream
  • Dribbling
  • Sensation of poor bladder emptying
  • Episodes of near retention

BPH is characterized by symptoms of urinary frequency, urgency, nocturia, incontinence, slow urinary stream, straining to void, urinary intermittency (stream starting and stopping during micturition), or hesitancy, splitting of the voiding stream, and terminal dribbling. Physical examination reveals a smooth enlarged and non-tender prostate. Lab investigations reveal a normal PSA (prostate-specific antigen). Diagnosis is made based on clinical presentation and a lack of lab findings suggestive of malignancy (elevated PSA). A biopsy is rarely indicated.

Conservative treatment is recommended for men with mild symptoms, flow rate >10ml/s, and good bladder emptying with residual urine <100ml. 

Medical management includes alpha-adrenergic blocking agents that inhibit the contraction of smooth muscle that is found in the prostate. Tamsulosin is an adrenoreceptor antagonist with receptor selectivity at α1A. It is used in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia.

The other class of drugs is the 5α-reductase inhibitors, which inhibit the conversion of testosterone to DHT, the most active form of androgen. Finasteride is a 5α-reductase enzyme inhibitor. It is effective in the treatment of palpable enlarged prostate. These drugs result in a 25% shrinkage of the prostate gland.

Indications for surgical management:

  • Lower urinary tract symptoms that are refractory to medical therapy
  • Refractory urinary retention
  • Recurrent urinary tract infection (UTI)
  • Hematuria
  • Stone formation
  • Hydronephrosis, hydroureter with renal functional impairment

Surgical management involves the use of the transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP). Laser ablative techniques using holmium YAG can also be done. 

Storage symptoms are seen in conditions where the bladder is irritated. Voiding symptoms are common in conditions causing bladder outlet obstruction. In benign prostatic hyperplasia, both storage and voiding symptoms are present.

questions.text: Identify the following instrument that is commonly used in a dilatation and curettage procedure.
questions.solution:
The given image shows Hegar's double-ended dilator which is used to dilate the cervix in dilation and curettage procedure. 

Pratt dilator is also a double-ended dilator but has a more linear shape as compared to the curved Hegar's dilators. The image given below shows a Pratt dilator.

Other options:

Option A: Hawkin dilator is a single-ended dilator. The image given below shows a Hawkin dilator.

Option C: Bakes rosebud dilator is a single-ended dilator used to dilate the urethra. It is called so since its tip is similar to a rosebud. The image given below shows a Bakes dilator.

Option D: Fenton dilator is also double-ended but it has a notch in the middle. The image given below shows a Fenton dilator.

questions.text: Alcoholic liver disease is suspected in a patient presenting with abdominal pain and vomiting. Which among the following makes the diagnosis of alcoholic liver disease unlikely?
questions.solution:
An AST: ALT <2 makes the diagnosis of alcoholic liver disease unlikely. 

Alcoholic liver disease is characterised by significant alcohol consumption, often with elevated gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT).In alcoholic liver disease (ALD), usually the AST: ALT is > 2:1. This is because there is a deficiency of pyridoxal 5'- phosphate which is a cofactor for the enzymatic activity of ALT. Therefore, ALT levels fail to rise and there is a reversal of the AST: ALT ratio.

GGT is commonly used in patients with alcoholic liver disease as a marker of excessive alcohol intake. GGT is present in many tissues, including the kidneys, pancreas, and liver. It is mainly derived from the liver and this is often used as a marker of hepatobiliary diseases. Chronic alcohol consumption leads to the induction of hepatic microsomal GGT which leads to a rise in GGT in alcoholics.

Laboratory investigations in patients with alcohol-induced liver dysfunction:

  • AST (SGOT) and ALT (SGPT) elevations that do not exceed 400 IU/L.
  • AST/ALT ratio of >1.5.
  • Serum bilirubin >3 mg/dL. 

Option B: Prothrombin time (PT) is prolonged in alcoholic liver disease due to the decreased synthetic function of the liver.

Option C: Platelet counts are often reduced early in alcoholic liver disease, which is reflective of portal hypertension with hypersplenism.

Option D: Serum total bilirubin may be either normal or elevated in cases of advanced alcoholic liver disease.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with major depressive disorder was prescribed escitalopram. Which of the following adverse effects is least likely to occur?
questions.solution:
Sialorrhea is not a side effect of escitalopram.

Escitalopram is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI). SSRIs are associated with dry mouth, and not sialorrhea.

System Side effects of SSRIs
Sexual Anorgasmia, Decreased libido
Gastrointestinal ( 5-HT3 receptor) Nausea, Diarrhea, Anorexia, Vomiting, Flatulence, and Dyspepsia
Nervous system Extremely vivid dreams or nightmares, Anxiety, Insomnia/sedation, Seizures, Emotional blunting
Anticholinergic Dry mouth, Constipation, Sedation
Cardiovascular Drug induced long QT syndrome
Hematological Easy bruising
Endocrine Mammoplasia, Galactorrhea

questions.text: Angel dust is a street name for which drug?
questions.solution:
Angel dust is the street name for phencyclidine. It is an NMDA antagonist and a dissociative anesthetic that can cause hallucinations, feelings of detachment from reality, and violent or erratic behavior. Originally developed as an anesthetic, its use was discontinued due to severe side effects. On the streets, it is often misused for its hallucinogenic and euphoric effects.

Popular street names of abused drugs:

  • Phencyclidine(PCP)- Angel dust, peace pill
  • Marijuana- Pot, weed
  • Heroin- Smack
  • Cocaine- Crack
  • Methylenedioxymethamphetamine(MDMA)- Ecstasy, X
  • Flunitrazepam- Roofie, forget-me pill

questions.text: A 17-year-old female presents with primary amenorrhea but experiences abdominal pain every month. She has normal secondary sexual characteristics.  On examination, an abdominal lump is noted, and a bluish bulge is observed when parting the labia. Considering the suspected diagnosis, what would be the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
A history of primary amenorrhea, cyclical abdominal pain, presence of a palpable abdominal lump, and visualization of a tense bluish bulging membrane on the separation of the labia suggests the diagnosis of imperforate hymen and the appropriate management would be cruciate incision on the hymen.

Cryptomenorrhoea, also known as hematocolpos, is a condition where menstruation occurs but is not visible due to an obstruction of the outflow tract. The most common cause is an intact (imperforate) hymen or the presence of a vaginal septum. A vaginal septum is differentiated from the imperforate hymen by a pinkish concave covering in contrast to the bluish convex bulge in the latter. An ultrasound scan of the pelvis confirms the diagnosis.

Treatment: A simple cruciate incision of the hymen allows the free drainage of the collected menstrual blood, and leads to normal reproductive function, in cases of imperforate hymen.

Note:

In the case of a vaginal septum (i.e. atresia), more extensive dissection and vaginoplasty are required.

questions.text: The finger-nose test is done to check the integrity of which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
The finger-nose test is done to assess cerebellar function.

Coordination in the upper limb is tested by finger-nose test. The patient is asked to touch his nose with the index finger of one hand. Then he is asked to touch the examiner's index finger. He is asked to do this multiple times, while the examiner keeps moving his index finger from place to place. It is important to ensure that the patient has to stretch his upper limb to reach the examiner's finger, so that the coordination can be assessed over the full range of motion of the upper limb.

Lower limb coordination is tested by heel-shin test. The test is done with the patient lying down on a bed. They are asked to put the heel of one leg onto the shin of the other leg, just below the knee. They are then asked to run the heel down the front of the shin till the dorsum of the foot. Patients with cerebellar lesions will have a tremor when trying to place the heel on the shin, and will be unable to accurately run the heel down the entire length of the shin.

The functioning of the posterior column tracts (option B) is assessed by Romberg's test. While performing Romberg's test, the patient is asked to stand with his feet close together, initially with his eyes open. If the patient is able to maintain their balance with the eyes open, they are asked to close their eyes. If they lose their balance and sway or fall with their eyes closed, the test is said to be positive. The examiner needs to be prepared to support the patient in case they are about to fall. 

Patients with disorders of the posterior column tracts will have impaired proprioception, and will have a positive Romberg's test. If the patient has dizziness or a tendency to fall even with the eyes open, then the lesion is likely to be in the vestibular system or cerebellum, and other relevant tests should be performed.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presented with complaints of easy irritability and insomnia for the past 2 years. The patient's wife states that these episodes usually alternate with periods where her husband complains of feeling hopeless, low mood, and dejected. The patient denies using drugs, or consuming alcohol and states that he has been this way for as long as he remembers. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in a patient experiencing alternate periods of irritability and feeling dejected for a period greater than 2 years is cyclothymic disorder.

Cyclothymia is a mild form of bipolar II disorder, characterized by symptoms of hypomania and mild depression. Hypomania mainly includes symptoms like persistently elevated or irritable mood and abnormally increased energy for a minimum duration of at least 4 days.

The depression seen in cyclothymia does not qualify the criteria for a major depressive episode.

Alcohol abuse and other substance abuse are commonly seen in patients with cyclothymic disorder. These patients use these drugs to self-medicate or to achieve even further stimulation.

Mood stabilizers like lithium and antimanic drugs like sodium valproate are the first lines of treatment. Psychotherapy is a great way for patients to develop coping mechanisms to help with their mood swings. Patients often require life-long treatment.

Option A: Major depressive disorder usually presents with depressed mood, anhedonia, significant change in weight or appetite, insomnia or hypersomnia, fatigue, and feelings of worthlessness nearly every day. These symptoms are present for a minimum of 2 weeks. 

Option C: Adjustment disorder is characterized by emotional or behavioral symptoms that develop within 3 months of exposure to an identifiable stressor and usually do not last more than 6 months after the stressor ends.

Option D: Dysthymic disorder is the presence of a persistently depressed mood that lasts most of the day and is continuous. There are also feelings of guilt, irritability, and anger associated with it. These symptoms are present for at least 2 years. Episodes of mania/hypomania are not seen in this condition.

Related Pearl: Patterns of Mood Disorders

questions.text: The given instrument is _________:
questions.solution:
Image shows sponge holding forceps. It is used to:

  • Clean skin with swab dipped in antiseptic solution during all operations
  • Removing laminated membrane and the daughter cysts during operation of Hydatid cyst.
  • Hold the fundus and Hartmann’s pouch of gall bladder during cholecystectomy
  • Swab an abscess cavity.

Other options:

Option A: Ovum forceps

Identification - has got no catch and the blades are slightly bent and fenestrated. Absence of catch minimizes uterine injury, if accidentally caught.

It prevents crushing of the conceptus.

It is to be introduced with the blades closed, to open up inside the uterine cavity, to grasp the products and to take out the instrument with a slight rotatory movement. The rotatory movements not only facilitate detachment of the products from the uterine wall but also minimize the injury of the uterine wall, if accidentally grasped.

Option C: Cord holding forceps

Option D: Pile holding forceps

questions.text: What is the best position for a conscious patient to be in during the insertion of a Ryle's tube?
questions.solution:
The best position for a conscious patient to be in during the insertion of Ryle's tube is sitting with neck flexion.

RT, also known as nasogastric (NG) tube, measures 120-125 cm. It has 4 markings at 40cm (cardia), 50cm (body), 60cm (pylorus), and 70 cm (duodenum) to indicate the approximate position after the placement.

Indications for NG tube:

  • Feeding in patients with dysphagia, decreased appetite, or those who are nil per os (NPO) for medical or surgical reasons.
  • Aspiration of gastric fluid
  • Gastric decompression in cases of intestinal obstruction and paralytic ileus.
  • Zollinger-Ellison syndrome 
  • Bowel irrigation

The absolute contraindications for an NG tube are severe midface trauma, recent nasal surgery, and basilar skull fractures

Steps for the correct insertion of RT in an adult:

  1. Examination of the patient’s nostril for any anatomical abnormalities and then instillation with 10 ml of 1% lignocaine 
  2. NEX method is used to measure the length of the RT:  Place the exit port of the tube at the tip of the nose. Extend the tube to the earlobe, and then to the xiphisternum.
  3. The patient is asked to sit upright with partial neck flexion. The tip of the Ryle’s tube is lubricated and passed along the floor of the nasal passage until a resistance is felt(corresponds to nasopharynx)
  4. The patient is subsequently asked to swallow water to guide the tube through the esophagus into the stomach until the marked length (based on the NEX method).
  5. NG tube is finally taped to secure it in place.

Confirmation of the correct position is done by

  • Auscultation in the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air
  • X-ray Chest
  • Colorimetric capnography

questions.text: All the following are components of the Kartagener's triad except ________
questions.solution:
Male infertility is typical in Kartagener syndrome, but not a component of the triad.

The primary defect in Kartagener’s Syndrome is primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD). i.e. immotility of cilia. Patients with PCD have the Kartagener triad, characterized by:

  • Situs inversus totalis
  • Bronchiectasis
  • Chronic sinusitis

Defects in ciliary motor proteins lead to ciliary dysfunction. This causes the retention of secretions due to a failed mucociliary clearance mechanism. Clinically, this manifests as chronic sinusitis and recurrent infections that ultimately lead to bronchiectasis.

questions.text: Which of the following is part of trotter's triad, seen in nasopharyngeal carcinoma?

choices.text: Conductive hearing loss, ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia, palatal paralysis
Sensorineural hearing loss, contralateral  temporoparietal neuralgia, palatal paralysis
Sensorineural hearing loss, ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia, epistaxis
Conductive hearing loss, contralateral temporoparietal neuralgia, epistaxis

questions.solution:
Trotter’s triad seen in nasopharyngeal carcinoma consists of conductive hearing loss, ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia, and palatal paralysis.

In nasopharyngeal carcinoma, the tumour's location near these cranial nerves can lead to their compression or infiltration, resulting in the characteristic symptoms of Trotter's triad. Therefore, cranial nerves V (trigeminal nerve) and X (vagus nerve) are commonly affected in this condition.

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma, a malignancy arising from the nasopharynx, can manifest with Trotter's triad, which includes:

  • Conductive deafness: This occurs due to obstruction or dysfunction of the eustachian tube, leading to impaired middle ear function.
  • Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia: This symptom is characterized by sharp, shooting pain in the temporoparietal region of the head. It is primarily caused by the involvement of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V), which carries sensory fibres from the face and certain parts of the head.
  • Palatal paralysis: This condition results from the involvement of the vagus nerve (cranial nerve X), which innervates the muscles of the soft palate. Palatal paralysis can lead to difficulty in swallowing, nasal regurgitation of fluids, and a nasal voice quality

Related Pearl: Triads in Surgery

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented with complaints of a gradually progressive swelling around his wrist joint for 3 months. Given below is the image of the swelling and the X-ray film. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and the x-ray showing an eccentric expansile lesion with a soap bubble appearance in a 30-year-old man are suggestive of osteoclastoma or giant cell tumor (GCT).

Osteoclastoma usually affects young adults in the age group of 20-40 years. The most common location of the tumor is the distal femur followed by the proximal tibia. Involvement of the distal end of the radius is also seen and the tumor is more aggressive in this location.

Radiographic findings in GCT:

  • A solitary, possibly loculated, lytic lesion in the epiphysis
  • Eccentric location, most often subchondral
  • Expansion of the overlying cortex
  • Soap bubble appearance - The tumor is homogeneously lytic with trabeculae of the remnants of bone traversing it, giving it a loculated appearance called soap bubble appearance
  • No calcification within the tumor
  • No or minimal reactive sclerosis around the tumor.

Treatment :

  • Extended curettage and bone grafting. 
  • En-bloc wide resection and reconstruction are done for advanced stages, local recurrence, and tumors not responding to other methods.
  • Resection without reconstruction is done for lesions in expandable bones like distal ulna, clavicle, etc.
  • Irradiation and/or embolization are used for inoperable lesions in the spine and pelvis.
  • Bisphosphonates have been shown to reduce the proliferation of osteoclasts and hence have been shown to stabilize local and metastatic disease.
  • Denosumab is approved for use in unresectable tumors in skeletally mature patients.

Other options:

Option A: Ewing's sarcoma is a primary malignant tumor of the bone commonly involving the age group of 4-25 years involving the diaphysis of the long bones like the femur, tibia, fibula, and humerus.

X-ray shows onion-peel appearance due to deposition of periosteal reaction in layers is the typical finding.

Option B: Osteosarcoma is the most common non-hematologic primary malignancy of bone. It occurs most commonly in the second decade of life and is typically metaphyseal. The distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus are the common sites.

X-ray shows periosteal reaction and it may take the form of a Codman's triangle or have a sunburst (sunray) appearance.

Option D: Osteochondromas are common benign bone tumors. The lesions consist of a bony mass, often in the form of a stalk, produced by endochondral ossification of a growing cartilaginous cap. The common sites of involvement are the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus.

questions.text: The following can be used for induction of anesthesia in pediatric patients except ______
questions.solution:
Desflurane is a highly pungent gas and so it can produce laryngospasm if used for inhalational induction. Hence it is not used as induction agent.

The incidence of laryngospasm following desflurane induction is almost 50%.

Desflurane is usually used for maintenance of anesthesia only and is of particular value in obese patients, neurosurgical and spinal fusion procedures where rapid awakening is required for neurological function assessment.

Other options :

Option A: Halothane has a sweet odor, is non-irritant, and is non-inflammable. Therefore, it can be used both for induction and maintenance of anesthesia in pediatric patients.

Option B: Sevoflurane is a fluorinated volatile anesthetic and is an ideal induction agent. Its non-pungency and rapid onset make it an excellent choice for smooth and rapid inhalation inductions in pediatric and adult patients

Option D: Due to its second-gas effect, nitrous oxide is mainly used as a carrier gas for other inhalational agents and not given alone.

Related Pearl: Inhalational anaesthetic agents

2. Day care surgery Sevoflurane(preferred)/Desflurane
3. Elderly  Desflurane
4. Cardiac disease Isoflurane
5. Renal disease Desflurane
6. Liver disease  Sevoflurane
7. Neurosurgery    Sevoflurane(preferred)/Isoflurane
8. Asthmatics Sevoflurane
9. Obese patients Desflurane

Least potent

questions.text: What is the most common symptom of peripheral occlusive vascular disease?
questions.solution:
The most common symptom of peripheral obstructive vascular disease is intermittent claudication. 

Intermittent claudication is the debilitating cramp-like pain in the leg muscles due to reduced blood flow brought on by peripheral arterial disease. It usually signifies mild to moderate chronic vascular occlusive disease.

The pain classically occurs during activity and is relieved with rest. The distance that a patient can walk without stopping till the pain is experienced in the muscles is known as claudication distance. This distance varies only slightly from day to day. The muscle group affected is one anatomical level below the arterial disease.

Boyd’s classification :

Class l - Pain on walking but pain decreases on continuation of walking.

Class ll - Pain on walking, but continues to walk despite the pain.

Class lll - Pain forces the patient to stop walking.

Class lV - Pain at rest.

It is worsened by health conditions such as anaemia and heart failure.

Other options :

Option A: Rest pain is when the disease progresses to a degree that perfusion is severely reduced and cramp-like pain in the calf is felt even at rest. 

Option C: Severe arterial insufficiency leads to tissue ulceration and gangrene.

Option D: A swollen and erythematous limb is seen in critical limb ischemia. When the limb is in the dependent position, there is pooling of blood which causes the limb to appear red and swollen(sunset foot sign).

questions.text: A case of Gestational Trophoblastic Neopalsm(GTN) is detected to have metastasis in the lungs. It is considered as stage ____
questions.solution:
According to the International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics (FIGO), metastases to the lungs are considered stage III.

International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics (FIGO) Staging for GTN is as follows:

Stage I Disease confined to the uterus

Stage II

GTN extends outside of the uterus but is limited to the genital structures    

(adnexa, vagina, broad ligament)
Stage III GTN extends to the lungs, with or without known genital tract involvement
Stage IV All other metastatic sites

The given chest X-ray shows multiple, bilateral metastatic nodules, of varying sizes.

Related Pearl: Risk factors and FIGO staging of Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia

Risk factors

  • Older age
  • β-hCG levels > 100,000 mIU/mL
  • Uterine size that is large-forgestational age
  • Theca-lutein cysts > 6 cm
  • Slow decline in β-hCG levels
  • Postevacuation uterine sonographic surveillance showing myometrial nodules or hypervascularity may be a predictor of subsequent neoplasia.

FIGO staging:

Stage I Disease confined to the uterus
Stage II GTD extends outside of the uterus but is limited to the genital structure
Stage III Lung metastasis with or without genital tract involvement
Stage IV Other metastasis

questions.text: During rounds, you have been asked to examine a patient with an ulcer over the face. Which of the following features will raise the suspicion of it being a squamous cell carcinoma?
questions.solution:
On examination of an ulcer, everted margins will be suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma (SCC).

SCC is the second most common skin cancer, while BCC is the most common skin cancer. Variants of SCC in-situ include:

  • Bowen's disease
  • Erythroplasia of Queyrat

SCC initially presents as smooth nodular, verrucous, papillomatous lesions. These lesions then ulcerate and form a characteristic, everted edge, surrounded by inflamed, indurated skin.

Surgical excision is the treatment of choice. Other modalities of treatment include:

  • Cautery ablation
  • Cryotherapy
  • Drug therapy including imiquimod
  • Moh’s microsurgery
  • Radiation therapy

The below image shows SCC with everted margins:

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image.
questions.solution:
The condition given in the image is ankyloblepharon. 

Ankyloblepharon is the adhesion between the margins of the upper and lower eyelids. It may occur as a congenital anomaly or as acquired adhesions after healing of chemical burns, ulcers, or traumatic wounds of the lid margins. Treatment is the excision of the adhesions between lid margins. Epithelial grafts should be used if adhesions extend to angles.

Other options : 

Option A: Symblepharon is the adhesion between the palpebral and bulbar conjunctiva in which the eyelids become adherent to the eyeball.

The image given below shows symblepharon.

Option C: Congenital blepharophimosis is a condition in which the extent of the palpebral fissure is decreased. It can be congenital or acquired and is due to a vertical skin fold at the lateral canthus. No treatment is required. In some cases, canthoplasty is done.

The image below shows blepharophimosis.

Option D: Congenital ptosis is associated with developmental defect and weakness of the levator palpebrae superioris (LPS) muscle. Drooping of one or both of the upper eyelids is seen since birth. Lid lag on downward gaze is present. Treatment involves surgical correction. 

The image below shows ptosis of right eye.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with bad behaviour and complaints of stealing, lying to parents and not listening to them for the past 6 months. He also demonstrates cruel behaviour and physically harmful activities. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
History of stealing, bad behaviour, lying to parents in a 5-year-old child for more than 6 months is suggestive of conduct disorder. If it persists beyond 18 years of age it is referred to as anti-social personality disorder.

Conduct disorder is diagnosed when at least 3 behaviours have been present within the previous 12 months, with at least 1 present in the past 6 months.

Onset of Conduct Disorder:

  • Childhood-onset type: Individuals show at least one symptom characteristic of conduct disorder before the age of 10 years.
  • Adolescent-onset type: Individuals show no symptom characteristic of conduct disorder before the age of 10 years.
  • Unspecified onset: Criteria for a diagnosis of conduct disorder are met, but there is not enough information available to determine whether the onset of the first symptom was before or after the age of 10 years.
DSM-5 criteria for Conduct Disorder  
Aggression towards people and animals

Initiating physical fights, bullying, threatening, or intimidating others

Using a weapon to cause serious harm to others

Being physically cruel to people

Being physically cruel to animals

Stealing while confronting a victim

Forcing someone into sexual activity
Destruction of property

Setting fires

Intentionally destroying the property of others
Serious violation of rules

Running away overnight at least twice or once without returning for a lengthy period.

Being truant from school often starting before age 13.

Frequently staying out at night despite parental prohibitions starting before age 13
Deceitfulness or theft

Frequently lying to obtain goods or favors

Breaking into a car or building

Stealing items of nontrivial value without confronting a victim

Oppositional defiant disorder(ODD):

  • Persistent pattern, lasting at least 6 months, of negativistic, hostile, and defiant attitude/behaviour towards adults, including arguments, temper outbursts, vindictiveness, and deliberate annoyance.
  • Seen in children less than 10 years of age.

NOTE: Unlike conduct disorder, children with ODD do not indulge in destructive and physically harmful activities.

questions.text: An elderly female patient presented to the surgeon with a history of breast pain and a lump in her right breast for the past 2 months. On examination, the breast appears red, swollen and has an orange peel-like appearance, as shown in the image below. This finding occurs due to:

choices.text: Infiltration of tumour cells in intralobular stroma

questions.solution:
The image depicts a patient with peau d'orange or skin of an orange appearance, caused due to obstruction of subcutaneous lymphatics.

The blockage of subcuticular lymphatics leads to oedema, which deepens the mouth of the sweat glands and hair follicles. This gives rise to a typical orange peel appearance called peau d'orange, as shown in the image below. It is a classical sign of breast carcinoma.

Breast cancer is a commonly seen neoplasm in women of advancing age. Patients present with a breast lump and significant axillary lymphadenopathy, and in rare cases, breast pain may be seen. 

Inflammatory breast carcinoma (stage T4d) is an aggressive form of locally advanced breast cancer (LABC) and is associated with the worst prognosis among all subtypes of breast cancer. It accounts for <3% of breast cancers. It is characterized by skin changes of brawny induration, erythema, and edema (peau d’orange). The term peau d’orange describes the orange-peel appearance of the skin resulting from oedema and dimpling at sites of hair follicles.

Other options :

Option A: Infiltration of Cooper’s ligaments leads to dimpling of the skin.

Option C: Infiltration of the lactiferous ducts leads to nipple retraction.

Option D: Infiltration of tumour cells in intralobular stroma leads to phyllodes tumour. It is a fibroepithelial tumour arising from the intralobular stroma. It presents as a smooth, rapidly growing, multinodular, painless breast lump that is usually palpable.

Note: While Peau d’orange indicates skin involvement, dimpling of the skin and nipple retraction do not indicate skin involvement.

questions.text: A patient presenting with high-grade fever and altered sensorium was diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis. Which of the following is the most appropriate empirical treatment option?
questions.solution:
Ceftriaxone or cefotaxime is the drug of choice for empirical treatment of Meningococcal meningitis but Penicillin G remains the antibiotic of choice for Meningococcal meningitis caused by susceptible strains.

  • Empirical antimicrobial therapy is initiated in patients with suspected bacterial meningitis before the results of CSF Gram stain and culture are known.
  • Pneumoniae and N. meningitidis are the most common etiologic organisms of community-acquired bacterial meningitis.
  • Due to the emergence of penicillin- and cephalosporin-resistant S. pneumoniae, empirical therapy of community-acquired suspected bacterial meningitis in children and adults should include a combination of dexamethasone, a third- or fourth-generation cephalosporin (e.g., ceftriaxone, cefotaxime, or cefepime), and vancomycin, plus acyclovir, as HSV encephalitis is the leading disease in the differential diagnosis, and doxycycline during tick season to treat tick-borne bacterial infections.

questions.text: All of the following are true about the instrument shown in the image given below except that ______.

choices.text: It is used for the localization of a foreign body.
It is used for the measurement of the angle of the posterior chamber.
It is used for the demonstration of the extent of peripheral anterior synechiae.
It provides a mirror image of the opposite angle.

questions.solution:
The given instrument is an indirect gonioscope, which is used to visualize the angle of the anterior chamber, i.e., for gonioscopy, and not the angle of the posterior chamber.

Types of gonioscope:

  • Indirect gonioprism: provides mirror image of the opposite angle (Option d).
  • Direct goniolens: provides a direct view of the angle.

Application:

  • To view the angle of the anterior chamber.
  • Localization of the foreign body (Option a), abnormal blood vessels, or tumors in the angle
  • Demonstration of the extent of peripheral anterior synechiae (Option c).
  • Direct goniolens can be used during goniotomy

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presented with dysphagia and postprandial chest pain that is relieved on loud belching. On examination, the patient had pallor. Chest radiography showed an intrathoracic gas bubble. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of a hiatus hernia. Hiatus hernia is the protrusion of any abdominal structure other than the esophagus into the thoracic cavity through a widening of the hiatus of the diaphragm.

Type 1 - Sliding hernia:

Gastroesophageal junction or cardia migrates into the thoracic cavity. The length of intra abdominal esophagus is reduced leading to GERD. Most of the patients are asymptomatic. The treatment of choice in symptomatic patients is fundoplication.

Type 2 - Rolling hiatus hernia:

Gastroesophageal junction or cardia is normal but a portion of the stomach migrates into the thoracic cavity. The length of intra abdominal esophagus remains the same in a true rolling hiatus hernia.

Clinical features:

  • Chest pain or fullness relieved on belching.
  • Dysphagia.
  • Longitudinal ulcers (Cameron’s ulcer) that bleed lead to anemia.

Surgical reduction of hernia and tightening of diaphragmatic crura is the best treatment modality even in asymptomatic patients to avoid life-threatening complications like volvulus.

Type 3 - Mixed hiatus hernia:

A combination of sliding and rolling hiatus hernia. Treatment is the same as rolling hiatus hernia.

Type 4 Hiatus hernia:

Other contents of GIT herniates into the thoracic cavity. Eg: Colon.

CT with oral contrast is the best method of diagnosis of hiatus hernia. It highlights gastric anatomy and also helps to identify other structures involved. Chest X-ray shows an intrathoracic gas bubble.

questions.text: A 40-year-old ironsmith came to the ENT clinic with complaints of dry nose, nasal crusting and bleeding on removal of the crusts. A diagnosis of rhinitis sicca was made. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: More common in people working in hot, dry, dusty surroundings
Antibiotic & steroid ointment is used for treatment

questions.solution:
Rhinitis sicca affects the anterior 1/3rd of the nose since this part is exposed to the effect of the dry, dusty air.

Rhinitis sicca is a crust-forming disease seen in patients who work in hot, dry, and dusty surroundings, e.g. bakers, iron- and goldsmiths. It is usually confined to the anterior third of the nose particularly of the nasal septum. The ciliated columnar epithelium undergoes squamous metaplasia with atrophy of the seromucinous glands.

Treatment consists of correcting occupational surroundings and application of bland ointment with an antibiotic and steroid combination to the affected part.

questions.text: In your university practical exams, the external examiner displays the following retractors on the desk and asks you to pick the Deaver's retractor. What would you pick?
questions.solution:
If you were asked to pick Deaver's retractor you would pick the instrument labeled '1'.

The given image shows

1 - Deaver's retractor

2 - Doyen's retractor

3 - Morris retractor

4 - Czerny's retractor

Deaver’s retractor: It is used to retract the liver, spleen, and other abdominal viscera. It is atraumatic and gives adequate exposure of the surgical field.

Doyen's retractor: It is used in pelvic surgeries.

Morris retractor: It is used to retract the abdominal wall.

Czerny's retractor: It is used in surgeries like hernia, and laparotomy, especially during closure.

questions.text: A worried mother brings her 18-month-old son to OPD with complaints of repeated urinary tract infections. During diagnostic work-up, pelvic USG shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the USG showing the key-hole sign is suggestive of the posterior urethral valve (PUV). It is seen due to dilatation of the bladder and the proximal urethra.

The posterior urethral valves are membranes that have a small posterior slit, which lies just distal to the verumontanum. They function as flap valves and are obstructive to antegrade urinary flow.

The posterior urethral valve is the most common congenital cause of bladder outlet obstruction in males. PUV is classified into three types based on Young's classification.

Diagnosis is made antenatally with ultrasound, which demonstrates bilateral hydronephrosis above a distended bladder. If the diagnosis is not made antenatally, then neonates typically present with urinary infection or uremia and renal failure. 

The investigation of choice for a posterior urethral valve is micturating cystourethrography (MCUG).

Initially, the obstruction is relieved by catheterization to preserve renal function. Definitive treatment is by urethroscopic destruction of the valves with lifelong supportive treatment. 

The following MCUG shows vesicoureteric reflux due to posterior urethral valves:

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient with NYHA class III heart failure presents with dyspnea, pedal edema, potassium level of 5.5 mmol/L, and creatinine of 1.1 mg/dL. Which of the following drugs can be used in this patient?
questions.solution:
Furosemide can be used in this patient. All the other drugs mentioned are avoided due to the risk of hyperkalemia.

The drugs used in heart failure that can cause hyperkalemia include:

  • β-blockers - Interferes with β2 mediated intracellular potassium uptake
  • ACE inhibitors - Inhibition of angiotensin II formation with a decrease in aldosterone secretion
  • Angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs) - Blocks AT1 receptor decreasing aldosterone secretion
  • K+ sparing diuretics - Inhibition of aldosterone
  • Digoxin - Inhibition of Na+/K+/ATPase pump

NYHA classification of heart failure:

NYHA class Description
I
  • No limitation of physical activity
  • Ordinary physical activity does not cause symptoms
II
  • Slight limitation of physical activity
  • Comfortable at rest, but ordinary physical activity causes symptoms
III
  • Marked limitation of physical activity
  • Comfortable at rest, but less than ordinary physical activity causes symptoms
IV
  • Unable to carry out any physical activity without symptoms or symptoms at rest
