questions.text: A 26-year-old baseball player sustains a head injury from being struck by a ball, resulting in a fracture of the optic canal. Which pair of structures is most likely to be damaged?
questions.solution:
Ophthalmic artery and optic nerve are the pair of structures damaged due to fracture of optic canal.

The optic canal allows the passage of the following structures :

  • Optic nerve.
  • Ophthalmic artery and its sympathetic plexus.

The superior orbital fissure is bounded by the greater and lesser wings of the sphenoid. It transmits the following structures :

  • Through the annulus of Zinn (a common tendinous ring from which the recti muscles originate)
      • Superior and inferior divisions of the oculomotor nerve.
      • Nasociliary nerve
      • Abducens nerve
  • Outside the annulus of Zinn :
      • Lacrimal Nerve
      • Frontal Nerve
      • Trochlear Nerve
      • Recurrent meningeal branch of the ophthalmic artery.
      • Superior ophthalmic vein.

Other options :

Option A : Optic nerve passes through optic canal and opthalmic vein passes through superior orbital fissure.

Option B : Opthalmic vein  and opthalmic nerve passes through superior orbital fissure.

Option D : Opthalmic nerve passes through superior orbital fissure and optic nerve passes via optic canal.

questions.text: Which of the following incisions would be used during an open appendicectomy procedure?
questions.solution:
McBurney's incision (also called gridiron incision), marked 3 in the image, is popularly used for open appendicectomy. It is an oblique incision (superolateral to inferomedial) passing along McBurney's point. 

The major anterior abdominal incisions have been illustrated below:

  • 1 is Kocher incision - A subcostal incision used to gain access for gall bladder and/or biliary tree pathology.
  • 2 is midline incision - The most common incision for laparotomy, a vertical incision that follows the linea alba which is particularly favoured in diagnostic laparotomy, as they allow wide access to most of the abdominal cavity.
  • 3 is McBurney's incision (also called gridiron incision) is an oblique incision (superolateral to inferomedial) passing along McBurney's point. It is popularly used for open appendicectomy.
  • 4 is a battle incision a lower right paramedian incision but placed more laterally than the standard paramedian incision. It is suitable for dealing with acute appendicitis and pathologies in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen.
  • 5 is Lanz incision, a transverse or skin crease incision for appendicitis, 2 cm below the umbilicus, centred on the midclavicular–mid-inguinal line. Due to its continuation with Langer’s lines, the Lanz incision produces much more aesthetically pleasing results with reduced scarring.
  • 6 is a paramedian incision - this incision is used to access much of the lateral viscera, such as the kidneys, spleen, and adrenal glands.
  • 7 is transverse incision - A supraumbilical transverse incision offers excellent exposure of the upper abdomen. A transverse incision may be superior to a midline incision in terms of recovery and complications postoperatively.
  • 8 is Rutherford Morrison incision, an oblique muscle cutting incision used for access to the sigmoid colon and pelvis in patients where the midline is scarred due to previous surgery. Rutherford Morison’s incision is useful if the appendix is para- or retrocaecal and fixed. It is essentially an oblique muscle-cutting incision with its lower end over McBurney’s point and extending obliquely upwards and laterally as necessary
  • 9 is Pfannenstiel incision - An infraumbilical transverse incision in the lower abdomen, often used for gynecological and obstetric procedures.

questions.text: When is the ideal time to repair old complete perineal tears which had occurred during delivery?
questions.solution:
In case of an old complete perineal tear, the optimum time for operative repair is after 3-6 months post-delivery.

The best time of repair is, however, within 24 hours of the injury. If not done within 24hrs, then the better option is to do it 3-6 months after delivery. By 3 months' time, the local infection subsides, the general condition of the patient improves and the baby can be kept at home.

If kept for more than 6 months, there is more fibrosis on the margins and unnecessary prolonged inconvenience to the patient.

Related Pearl: Degrees of perineal laceration

Degree
Description
First-degree
Injury to the skin and subcutaneous tissue of the perineum and vaginal epithelium only. The perineal muscles remain intact.
Second-degree
Extends into the fascia and musculature of the perineal body. The anal sphincter muscles remain intact.
Third-degree 
3a
<50% of EAS thickness is torn
3b
>50% of EAS thickness is torn
3c
Both EAS and IAS are torn
Fourth-degree
Involves the perineal structures, EAS, IAS and rectal mucosa.

questions.text: A newborn is found to have a congenital urethral abnormality as shown in the image. It results in difficulty directing the urine stream. Which of the following statements regarding this condition is true?

choices.text: Dorsal chordee is a common association
Dorsal aspect of the prepuce is poorly developed
Circumcision should not be performed before corrective surgery

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the image showing a urethral meatus that opens on the underside of the penis suggest hypospadias. Circumcision should not be done in hypospadias as the foreskin will be used for surgical reconstruction.

Hypospadias is the most common congenital abnormality of the urethra. It occurs due to the incomplete fusion of the urethral folds.

Hypospadias is characterized by: 

  • A ventrally placed urethral meatus (underside of penis or perineum)
  • Poor development of the ventral aspect of the prepuce (resulting in hooded foreskin)
  • Ventral chordee (bending of the penis)

Hypospadias can be classified into the following types based on the meatal location:

  • Anterior (distal)
    • Glanular (most common)
    • Coronal
  • Middle
    • Middle penile shaft
    • Distal penile shaft
  • Posterior (proximal)
    • Proximal penile shaft
    • Penoscrotal
    • Scrotal
    • Perineal

The image given below shows classification of hypospadiasis.

Surgery for correction of hypospadias are routinely performed when the patient is between 6 and 18 months of age. The infant has good tolerance to surgery by the age of 6 months. The child is well aware of his genitalia and will be toilet trained by the age of 18 months.

Surgery in hypospadias is done to correct problems with the urinary stream and for cosmetic reasons. Surgery depends on the site of the hypospadias. 

The main principles of surgery in hypospadias include:

  • Orthoplasty - Chordee correction
  • Urethroplasty - To reposition the urethral opening and tubularize urethra
  • Glanuloplasty - Reconstruction of glans
  • Skin cover and scrotoplasty

Complications of hypospadias surgery include:

  • Urethrocutaneous fistula (most common)
  • Recurrence of chordee
  • Urethral stricture
  • Meatal stenosis
  • Infection

Tubularized incised plate (TIP) urethroplasty is the most commonly done procedure. It is done for distal hypospadias.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman was diagnosed with Hashimoto's thyroiditis and started on levothyroxine 2 weeks ago. She now presents to your clinic with abdominal pain, dizziness and weight loss. Her current appearance and her appearance last month are shown below respectively. Which of the following is not a feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with severe dizziness, weight loss and a history of autoimmune thyroiditis with the image showing hyperpigmentation of the skin, points to a diagnosis of Addison’s disease and hyperglycemia is not a feature of this condition.

The clinical features of Addison’s disease include:

Hormone

Clinical features
Hypoaldosteronism

Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, salt craving
Dizziness, postural hypotension
AKI due to volume depletion
Hyponatremia
Hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis
Hypocortisolism Anorexia, weight loss, fatigue, myalgia, arthralgia
Fever (increased IL-1)
Depression
Postural hypotension
Hypoglycemia
Hyponatremia (loss of feedback inhibition of ADH)
Slightly increased TSH (loss of feedback inhibition)
Hypoandrogenism Loss of libido
  Loss of pubic and axillary hair
Elevated ACTH Hyperpigmentation

Levothyroxine can precipitate adrenal insufficiency or crisis in undiagnosed patients. In patients with concurrent adrenal insufficiency and hypothyroidism, a course of steroids must be given before giving thyroid replacement.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of dark urine and abdominal distension. On examination, she has an icterus but normal mental status. Laboratory findings include a hematocrit of 26%, reticulocyte count of 5%, platelets at 130,000, ALP of 30 IU/L, ALT of 110 IU/L, AST of 220 IU/L, total bilirubin of 13 mg/dL, negative HBsAg, and a negative urine drug screen. An abdominal ultrasound shows a nodular liver and an enlarged spleen. What is the most likely clinical diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with lab findings of low hematocrit value, elevated reticulocyte count, and increased indirect bilirubin may point to copper-induced hemolysis, which is indicative of Wilson's disease.

Wilson's disease is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, which encodes a copper-transporting ATPase found in cell membranes. Clinical manifestations include hepatitis, cirrhosis, behavioural changes, wing-beating tremors, and ophthalmic features such as copper deposition in the posterior lens capsule, leading to sunflower cataracts and the presence of Kayser-Fleischer rings.

The laboratory findings of Wilson’s disease include:

  • Low hematocrit value, increased reticulocyte – Indicative of hemolytic anaemia.
  • Unconjugated jaundice – Hemolytic anaemia and defective conjugation in the liver.
  • Mild elevation in the level of aminotransferase.
  • Nodular liver – Indicating a chronic condition.

Diagnosis is made by the presence of KF rings, decreased serum ceruloplasmin (copper-containing enzyme/ferroxidase) levels, liver biopsy and increased 24-hour urine copper excretion.

Trientine and Zinc are the first choice of drug regimen to be used for treating mild hepatic decompensation in Wilson’s disease. 

Other options :

Option A: Acetaminophen intoxication is ruled out since the Urinary screen is negative.

Option B: Acute viral hepatitis can be ruled out since there is a nodular liver indicative of cirrhosis and an enlarged spleen which implies chronicity. Aminotransferases are not grossly elevated.

Option C: Primary biliary cirrhosis (PBC) can also be ruled out since Alkaline phosphatase activity is normal. Additionally, there is no mention of mitochondrial antibody screening. History is not a characteristic of PBC.

questions.text: During spinal anesthesia, the following structures are pierced except______
questions.solution:
During spinal anesthesia, the posterior longitudinal ligament is not pierced.

The following structures are pierced during spinal anesthesia, in that order:

  • Skin
  • Subcutaneous tissue
  • Supraspinous ligament
  • Interspinous ligament
  • Ligamentum flavum 
  • Dura mater
  • Arachnoid

Note: Resistance or first snap is offered by the ligamentum flavum, as this layer is tough and dense.

While, the “click” or “pop” give-away sensation is encountered on piercing the dura, which indicates the needle is in the subarachnoid space. The stylet is then removed from the spinal needle, and CSF should appear at the needle hub.

questions.text: The given image illustrates a flap used for breast reconstruction. Name the flap.
questions.solution:
The image illustrates a deep inferior epigastric perforator (DIEP) flap.

In the above image, it is clearly seen that only skin and subcutaneous fat are moved. In contrast, the skin, fat, and muscle are moved in a TRAM flap.

Deep inferior epigastric perforator (DIEP) flap

  • It is a free flap.
  • Only subcutaneous fat and skin is taken.
  • The rectus abdominis muscle is not removed, and hence, there is no abdominal wall weakness.
  • Cosmetically, it is the best flap, and it has the advantage of giving a "tummy tuck" to the patient as well.

 Transverse rectus abdominis myocutaneous (TRAM) flap

  • Either based on superior epigastric or inferior epigastric or both (supercharged TRAM)
  • Skin, fat, and muscle are moved to the chest.
  • The rectus abdominis muscle is excised, and hence, the procedure leads to abdominal wall weakness (hernias can occur).

Latissimus dorsi flap:

  • Based on the thoracodorsal pedicle
  • It is an Axial flap

questions.text: All of the following isotopes are used for thyroid imaging except:
questions.solution:
Iodine 127 is the stable isotope and does not emit radiation, so is not useful for thyroid imaging.

Iodine-123: A radioactive isotope used for diagnostic imaging. Emits gamma rays and has a short half-life (~13 hours), and provides detailed imaging with minimal radiation exposure.

Iodine-131: A radioactive isotope used for both imaging and therapeutic purposes. Emits both beta and gamma rays, with a longer half-life (~8 days), making it suitable for treating hyperthyroidism and thyroid cancer.

Tc 99m pertechnetate is also used for thyroid imaging. It is a radioactive tracer that provides valuable information about thyroid function and structure. Tc-99m pertechnetate is actively taken up by the thyroid gland through the sodium-iodide symporter (similar to iodine). However, unlike iodine, it is not incorporated into thyroid hormones. Tc-99m has a half-life of about 6 hours, minimizing radiation exposure.

questions.text: All of the following are contraceptive methods used post-coitus except:
questions.solution:
Danazol is not used as a post-coitus contraceptive.

Danazol has androgenic activity. It is used in abnormal uterine bleeding, endometriosis, and cyclic mastalgia. It has no role as a post-coitus contraceptive.

Emergency contraceptives, also known as postcoital contraceptives are used to prevent conception after unprotected intercourse. They include:

  • RU 486 (Mifepristone): 25 mg single dose is effective in 99.1% as a postcoital drug. 
  • Prostaglandins 
  • Copper T
  • Yuzpe method: Combined high dose estrogen-progestin pills are used as post-coitus contraceptives.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man comes with a history of painless foul-smelling ear discharge and loss of hearing for 1 year. He also presented with a history of ear surgery in the same ear 3 years back. The most likely diagnosis is_____
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 34-year-old man presenting with a history of painless foul-smelling ear discharge and loss of hearing for 1 year with a history of ear surgery is suggestive of secondary acquired cholesteatoma. 

Cholesteatomas are abnormal collections of keratinised squamous epithelium, usually in the middle ear and mastoid. 

Clinical features of cholesteatomas include hearing loss (due to perforation of the tympanic membrane and middle ear bone destruction) and otorrhea. Cholesteatomas have a high potential to destroy the bone due to invasion and enzymatic bone destruction. 

Diagnosis of cholesteatoma can be done by history, examination, and radiography. CT can demonstrate bony defects such as ossicular erosion, mastoid aditus widening, and bony ear canal erosion. Surgery is the only treatment for cholesteatoma. The procedure of choice is modified radical mastoidectomy (MRM), a type of canal wall-down tympanomastoidectomy.

On otoscopy, it shows the presence of a large mass of white keratin debris, as shown in the image given below.

Related Pearl: Classification and theories for origin of cholesteatoma

Classification:

Congenital cholesteatoma is that which has its nidus of trapped squamous epithelium present at birth.

Primary acquired cholesteatoma is associated with a defect in the pars flaccida. 

Secondary acquired cholesteatoma is associated with a defect in the pars tensa.

Tertiary acquired cholesteatoma is defined as that which occurs behind a normal-appearing tympanic membrane as the result of implantation or an antecedent middle ear inflammation.

Type
Theory
Description
Congenital Cholesteatoma
Congenital cell rests
The presence of congenital epithelial cell rests within the middle ear cleft/ temporal bone.
Primary Acquired Cholesteatoma
Wittmaack’s theory of retraction pockets
Negative middle ear pressure leads to the formation of retraction pockets (usually in the posterosuperior part of pars tensa and the pars flaccida) which accumulates keratin debris.
Ruedi’s theory of basal cell hyperplasia
The basal cell layer of the germinal layer of skin proliferates in response to infection & other stimuli.
Sade’s Metaplasia theory
Repeated infections (Otitis media with effusion) lead to metaplasia of middle ear epithelium into squamous type.
Secondary Acquired Cholesteatoma
Habermann’s theory of epithelial invasion
Marginal perforation leads to ingrowth of squamous epithelium of the meatus or outer surface of the tympanic membrane into middle ear.
Sade’s Metaplasia theory
Repeated infections (ASOM/CSOM) lead to metaplasia of middle ear epithelium into squamous type.

questions.text: A man presents with a slowly progressive swelling over the past 1 and 1/2 years. On examination, it has a variable consistency and appears as shown in the image. What is the probable cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image showing the swelling lifting the ear lobe is suggestive of pleomorphic adenoma.

Pleomorphic adenoma is a painless, slowly growing, benign tumor that usually affects females more than males. It most commonly arises from the superficial lobe. It is unicentric in origin with a pseudo-capsule present. It is a radioresistant tumor.

Clinical features:

  • Lobulated, firm, elastic-to-hard in consistency
  • Well-defined margins
  • Free from deeper structures
  • With no facial nerve involvement

In case of deep lobe involvement, tonsils and faucial pillars will be pushed medially.

All tumors of the superficial lobe of the parotid gland should be managed by superficial parotidectomy.

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: A patient presented with extensive burns and was started on ringer's lactate. Which of the following is the most appropriate way to assess adequate fluid correction in this patient?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate way to assess adequate fluid correction in a burn patient is by measuring urine output. 

The urine output should be maintained between 0.5 to 1mL/kg body weight/hour.

Urine output is an indicator of kidney perfusion, which is an indicator of overall organ perfusion. Maintaining organ perfusion is the primary goal of IV fluid therapy in burn patients. If the urine output is low and the patient presents with signs of hypoperfusion (restlessness with tachycardia, cool peripheries, high hematocrit). A bolus of 10 mL/kg body weight should be administered. 

Other options: 

Option A: The parkland formula is a tool to estimate fluid requirement, and not assess the adequacy of fluid correction.

Option B: Mean arterial blood pressure is measured when the patient has a complex burn with cardiac dysfunction. 

Option D: Hematocrit values are measured when overhydration or dehydration is suspected in complex burns.

questions.text:
Which of the following changes can be seen in the quadruple screening for Down syndrome?

AFP- Alpha-fetoprotein

PAPP-A- Pregnancy Associated Plasma Protein A

β-hCG- Beta human chorionic gonadotropin

choices.text: Elevated β-hCG, PAPP-A and lower estriol, AFP
Elevated β-hCG, Inhibin and lower estriol, AFP
Lower β-hCG, PAPP-A and elevated estriol, AFP
Lower  β-hCG, Inhibin and elevated estriol, AFP

questions.solution:
The changes seen in quadruple screening in downs syndrome include, elevated β-hCG, Inhibin and lower estriol, AFP.

Pregnancies with Down syndrome are characterized by elevated β-hCG, Inhibin, and low estriol, AFP levels.  It is performed from 15 to 21 weeks of gestation. 

The abnormalities seen on the quadruple screen are tabulated below:

  Trisomy 21 Trisomy 18 Neural tube defect or abdominal wall defect
MSAFP Low Low High
β hCG High Low Normal
Unconjugated estriol Low Low Normal
Inhibin A High Low Normal

questions.text: All of the following statement regarding ranula are true except

choices.text: It is a mucous extravasation cyst
It arises from submandibular salivary gland
It presents as a bluish, translucent, cystic swelling in the floor of mouth
Treatment includes excision of the gland

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement regarding ranula is it arises from the submandibular salivary gland. It is a mucous extravasation cyst occurring as a result of obstruction of one of the sublingual salivary glands in the floor of the mouth.

They are translucent, bluish, soft, cystic fluctuant swelling in the anterior floor of the mouth. They are usually painless unless infected. It resembles the belly or air sac of a frog. It pushes the tongue upwards and medially thus interfering with speech, mastication, respiration, and swallowing. They can remain localised or occur beyond the confines of the floor of the mouth through the mylohyoid muscle to present as a submental swelling called a plunging ranula. 

Management: Both simple and plunging ranulas should be excised along with the cyst wall and the sublingual gland. Incision, drainage and marsupialisation (unroofing the cyst and tacking the edges of the cyst to adjacent tissues) have low success rates as this gland has multiple ducts and ranulas can recur if the gland is left behind.

The image of oral ranula is given below.

questions.text: You see a resident use the following instrument to grasp the anterior lip of the cervix in a patient posted for a vaginal hysterectomy. What is this instrument known as?
questions.solution:
The image shows vulsellum forceps. It is used to grasp the cervical lip and steady the cervix during vaginal surgery. It is a long instrument with a gentle curve so that the line of vision is not obstructed.

Option A: Allis forceps can be identified by continuous teeth, equal on both ends. It is used to hold structures with a firm grip.

Option C: Kocher's artery forceps are non-traumatic with a single tooth at the tip. They are used to achieve hemostasis by holding bleeding vessels. They are also used in low rupture of membranes to augment labour or for the surgical induction of labour. 

Option D: Lahey's tissue grasping forceps has teeth similar to dinner forks. They are used to hold fibrous tissue and they give a firm grip without slippage.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old smoker and hypertensive male, complaints of exertional angina. He says it occurs almost daily now, from a very long time. ECG shows ST depression. On cardiac evaluation, there is no increase in the levels of cardiac biomarkers. What could be the most probable diagnosis of the patient?

Non-ST elevation myocardial infarction- NSTEMI

ST-elevation myocardial infarction- STEMI
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is unstable angina.

Unstable angina is chest discomfort or pain due to insufficient blood flow and oxygen to the heart. It occurs due to the development of the thrombus on a pre-existing disrupted atherosclerotic plaque and is non-occlusive. The patients develop chest pain radiating to the jaws or arms and shortness of breath. 

An electrocardiogram may show hyperacute T-wave, T-wave flattening, inverted T-waves, and ST depression in unstable angina. Unstable angina is diagnosed in patients with symptoms suggestive of acute coronary syndrome with no elevation of cardiac biomarkers. If cardiac biomarkers are elevated in these patients, then the diagnosis of myocardial infarction is considered.

Acute coronary syndromes (ACS) include:

  • Unstable angina(UA).
  • Non-ST elevation myocardial infarction(NSTEMI).
  • ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI).

Other options:

Option A: NSTEMI is one of the components of ACS in which there are ST-segment depression and deep T-wave inversions. The cardiac biomarkers are elevated in NSTEMI unlike in unstable angina.

Option B: STEMI is one of the components of ACS in which there is ST-segment elevation with T-wave changes. The cardiac biomarkers are elevated in STEMI.

Option C: Left heart failure results due to dysfunction of the left ventricle, leading to insufficient delivery of blood to vital organs. The electrocardiogram shows non-specific ischemic changes, left ventricle hypertrophy or arrhythmias. The cardiac biomarker like brain natriuretic peptide may be elevated.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man underwent coronary artery bypass graft and has been in the hospital for the past 3 days. The patient is acutely confused with a temperature of 102°F and oxygen saturation of 91%. Blood test reveals raised inflammatory marker and chest X-ray shows a new right-sided infiltrate. Which of the following is the next best step in the diagnosis and/or management of this patient?

choices.text: Perform needle decompression and start antibiotics
Start treatment as per the local antibiotic policy for hospital acquired pneumonia after sending appropriate cultures
Perform  CT pulmonary angiogram to rule out pulmonary embolism
Immediately take the patient to theatre

questions.solution:
The clinical findings and radiological presentation are suggestive of pneumonia. Also, the patient has been in the hospital for > 2 days. The priority, in this case, is to start antibiotics for hospital-acquired pneumonia after sending appropriate cultures.

Pneumonia is defined as the presence of new lung infiltrates along with clinical evidence of its infectious origin, which manifests with fever, purulent sputum, leucocytosis, and a decrease in oxygen saturation.

Hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) or nosocomial pneumonia is a lower respiratory infection that presents clinically 2 or more days after hospitalization and was not there at the time of admission.

  • Early-onset HAP (occurring within 4-5 days) is most commonly caused by S. aureus, P. aeruginosa, Enterobacter species, K pneumoniae, and Escherichia coli
  • Late-onset HAP (> 5 days) is usually caused by Gram-negative bacteria (ex: Escherichia coli, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Klebsiella spp, and Acinetobacter baumannii), S. aureus, and anaerobes.

Management:

  • The mainstay of management includes adequate oxygenation, appropriate fluid balance and antibiotics. The choice of antibiotics is most appropriately guided by knowledge of local patterns of microbiology and antibiotic resistance.
  • Co-amoxiclav or cefuroxime are the preferred agents in early HAP. If the patient has recently received antibiotics, then piperacillin/tazobactam or a third-generation cephalosporin should be considered.
  • In late HAP, an anti-pseudomonal cover may be provided by meropenem, cephalosporin or piperacillin-tazobactam. MRSA cover may be given by glycopeptides such as vancomycin or linezolid. A baumannii is usually sensitive to carbapenem but may require colistin in resistant cases.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of hypertension presented to the emergency room with loss of consciousness, chest pain, and diaphoresis. On examination, she was grossly unstable and the bilateral pulses were unequal. ECG showed nonspecific ST-T changes. What is the next best investigation?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation with acute onset chest pain, loss of consciousness and diaphoresis with bilaterally unequal pulses and ECG showing nonspecific ST-T changes is suggestive of aortic dissection, and as the patient is hemodynamically unstable, the next best investigation is transesophageal ECHO.

Aortic dissection occurs when a defect or flap occurs in the intima of the aorta. Predisposing factors include mainly age, hypertension, Marfan syndrome, and pregnancy. The most typical presentation of aortic dissection is a tearing interscapular pain. The dissection may also result in aortic wall rupture into the pericardium (cardiac tamponade) or mediastinum (left haemothorax).

Contrast-enhanced CT(CECT) is currently the most preferred imaging modality for aortic dissection. A double-lumen aorta is seen on CECT. Transesophageal echocardiography is preferred for patients who are unstable for transportation.

Acute aortic dissection can be classified by the original DeBakey system, based on the location of the proximal tear and distal extent of the dissection flap, or the Stanford system, which uses the location of the proximal tear alone.

The classification and management of aortic dissection is explained in the images given below.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female patient came with complaints of floaters and blurring of vision of both eyes for a few weeks.  Fundoscopic examination shows inferior snow banking.  What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with fundoscopy showing snow banking is suggestive of intermediate uveitis or pars planitis.

Intermediate uveitis is the inflammation involving pars plana ciliaris, peripheral retina, choroid, and vitreous base. It is predominantly seen in young females and most often presents with floaters and bilateral blurring of vision. Snow banking is the hallmark of intermediate uveitis. It refers to greyish white fibrovascular plaques over the pars plana, with or without peripheral retinal periphlebitis.

Intermediate uveitis is managed  by the Kaplan 4-step protocol, Periocular steroid, Cryotherapy in cases with a snow banking and Pars plana vitrectomy.

The image below shows the snowball opacities and snow banking in intermediate uveitis.

Other options:

Option A: Anterior uveitis or iridocyclitis is the inflammation of tissue from the iris up to the pars plicata of the ciliary body. It is the most common form of uveitis. They present with circumcorneal conjunctival hyperemia, aqueous flare, keratin precipitates and posterior synechiae as shown in the image below.

Option C: Posterior uveitis is the inflammation of the choroid with or without inflammation of the retina. 

Option D: Fuchs' uveitis or Fuchs heterochromatic iridocyclitis is a chronic non-granulomatous condition. They are usually unilateral. A difference in color between the iris of both eyes termed heterochromia iridis is characteristically seen here. Posterior synechiae are absent. A characteristic stellate-shaped keratic precipitates are located diffusely over the entire corneal epithelium.

questions.text: Identify the pathology in the given image.
questions.solution:
The image depicts a ring lesion (stromal infiltrate) of acanthamoeba keratitis.

Acanthamoeba keratitis

  • Rare protozoal infection of the cornea.
  • Occurs in soft contact lens users who wash their lens with tap water.
  • Pain is disproportionate to the degree of keratitis due to perineural invasion.
  • Presents as
    • Ring lesion (most common): Ring stromal infiltrates lead to ring stromal abscess
    • Pseudo-dendrites
    • Reticular pattern
  • Investigation
    • Staining: Calcoflour white, acridine orange, lactophenol blue
    • Culture: Non-nutrient agar with Escherichia coli overlay.
  • Treatment is with Polyhexamethyl biguanide (PHMB).

Other options :

Option A: Bacterial keratitis is most commonly caused by staphylococcus aureus. It is associated with stromal edema, folds in the Descemet membrane, and anterior uveitis. 

An image of a bacterial corneal ulcer with hypopyon is shown below.

Option B: Fungal keratitis is usually is caused by filamentous septate organisms such as Aspergillus, Fusarium, or yeasts such as Candida albicans.They are characteristically seen after injury with vegetative matter like thorns or wooden sticks. Patients may present with pain, watering, and photophobia, but these are usually milder in comparison to bacterial ulcers. They are dry-looking ulcer with feathery irregular margins and wessely's immune ring is seen as shown in image below.

Option D:  Herpes simplex keratitis is caused by recurrent herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection in the cornea characterised by a superficial dendritic ulcer, epithelial keratitis, reduction in corneal sensation and geographic ulcer.

The below image shows the characteristic dendritic ulcers of herpes simplex keratitis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with easy fatiguability, weight loss, and anorexia. On examination, he is found to have generalised lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly. The total leucocyte count is 1 lakh per microliter, with 80% lymphocytes. The peripheral smear shows increased lymphocytes with many smudge cells. Identify the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 65-year-old male patient with hepatosplenomegaly, increased WBC count with characteristic smudge cells on the peripheral smear is suggestive of chronic lymphocytic leukaemia.

Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL) is a peripheral B-cell neoplasm usually affecting adults, more commonly men. It is asymptomatic at diagnosis, but some features include easy fatigability, weight loss, anorexia, generalised lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly. 10% to 15% of patients develop hemolytic anaemia or thrombocytopenia due to autoantibodies made by nonneoplastic B cells; leukocyte count is variable. 

A lymph node biopsy in CLL reveals small lymphocytes mixed with varying numbers of larger, activated lymphocytes that frequently cluster in proliferation centres. These centres, containing mitotically active cells, are considered pathognomonic for CLL.

Peripheral smear shows predominantly small lymphocytes with smudge cells/ basket cells or parachute cells. It is given below.

Other options :

Option A: Chronic myeloid Leukemia(CML) is a hematopoietic stem cell disorder and it occurs due to the translocation between the long arms of chromosomes 9 and 22, forming the Philadelphia chromosome. The image below shows peripheral smear findings of CML with neutrophils, myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and band cells.

Option C: Mantle cell lymphoma usually presents in the 5th to 6th decades of life and shows a male predominance. The most common presentation is painless lymphadenopathy. On HP examination, homogeneous small lymphocytes with irregular/deeply cleaved nuclear contours are seen. The image given below shows a histopathology slide depicting mantle cell lymphoma:

Option D: Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL) arises from immature B (pre-B) or T (pre-T) cells called lymphoblasts. Immunohistochemistry for terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT) is positive in pre-B and pre-T lymphoblasts.

Peripheral smear shows lymphoblasts that have condensed chromatin, less conspicuous nucleoli, and smaller amounts of cytoplasm which lacks granules as shown below.

questions.text: Mrs. Latha presents to the clinic at 12 weeks of gestational age with a history of a lump in her right breast for the past 2 months. On examination, you find a lump of 2 X 1 cm in the upper outer quadrant of her right breast. Which of the following investigations would you initially advise her for the assessment of the breast lump?
questions.solution:
Ultrasonography (USG) is the preferred initial investigation in pregnant women who present with a breast lump. It can differentiate between solid and cystic lesions of the breast and is able to detect abnormal axillary lymph nodes.

USG is preferred in pregnant women, lactating women, and young women (less than 40 years) since breast tissue is dense in these populations.

Other options:

Option A- Mammography is less useful in pregnant women due to the increased density of breast tissue.

Option C- MRI is not the initial investigation used for the assessment of breast lumps. It can be used in cases where metastasis or spread to other breast is suspected.

Option D- Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC)  is not recommended in pregnant women. It is difficult to distinguish breast cancer from the normal cellular proliferation in the breast tissue due to hormonal changes.

questions.text: A patient stopped alcohol consumption for 3 days and presented with irritability, disorientation, paranoid delusions, agitation, visual hallucinations, and altered sensorium. What is the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient who has not consumed alcohol for the past 3 days with disorientation, paranoid delusions, visual hallucinations, and altered sensorium is suggestive of delirium tremens.

Delirium tremens is a medical emergency that occurs during alcohol withdrawal. It is an acute condition and usually develops within 72 hours after the last drink. It has symptoms of both delirium and alcohol withdrawal. The clinical features of delirium tremens are:

  • Altered sensorium with disorientation
  • Perceptual distortions, most frequently tactile or visual hallucinations
  • Autonomic hyperactivity with tachycardia, fever, anxiety, insomnia, hypertension. And sweating
  • Fluctuating levels of psychomotor activity, ranging from agitation to lethargy
  • Altered sleep-wake cycle

Other options:

Option B - Wernicke’s encephalopathy (alcoholic encephalopathy) is associated with thiamine deficiency. Alcohol abuse may lead to thiamine deficiency because of poor nutritional habits, or malabsorption. It is an acute neurological disorder characterized by:

  • Global confusion
  • Ocular abnormalities like horizontal nystagmus, gaze palsy, anisocoria, and sluggish pupillary reflex
  • Ataxia - mainly affecting the gait
  • Vestibular dysfunction

It may resolve with thiamine therapy or progress to Korsakoff's syndrome.

Option C - Korsakoff’s psychosis can follow Wernicke’s encephalopathy due to thiamine deficiency. It is a chronic amnestic syndrome that is characterized by the following clinical symptoms in an intact and responsive patient:

  • Impaired mental syndrome, especially recent memory
  • Anterograde amnesia
  • Confabulation

Option D - Alcohol-induced psychosis is characterized by the development of auditory hallucinations or paranoid delusions in the context of a heavy drinking or alcohol withdrawal. These patients have a clear sensorium, unlike the patients having delirium tremens.

Note: Tremulousness is the first alcohol withdrawal symptom.

questions.text: A woman presents with a history of recurrent abortions. A hysterosalpingogram is done and shown below. The intercornual angle mentioned in the report is 70 degrees, and the cleft depth is reported to be <1cm.  Ultrasound reveals an intercornual distance of less than 4 cm. What is the treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a history of recurrent abortion with the given hysterosalpingogram and intercornual angle of 70 degrees, a cleft depth of less than 1cm, and intercornual distance of less than 4 cm suggests a diagnosis of a septate uterus, for which transcervical hysteroscopic resection of the septum is the appropriate method of treatment.

The procedure involves the resection of the septum under hysteroscopic guidance. Hence, it doesn't scar the uterus and avoids the necessity of cesarean sections for future pregnancies, improving the outcomes.

The following table differentiates the septate and bicornuate uterus:

Study and parameter Septate Bicornuate
Hysterosalpingography(HSG) - cornua position Horns do not diverge Widely diverging horn
Intercornual angle - coronal plane (MRI/3D USG) <75 degrees >105 degrees
Intercornual distance <4 cm >4 cm
Fundal contour Convex, flat or minimally indented Fundal cleft >1 cm from the intercornual line
Intervening myometrium Thin (fibrous) Thick

Other options:

Option A and C: Jones and Tompkins metroplasty are surgeries that involve a transabdominal approach, which causes uterine scarring and is hence not preferred.

Option B: Strassmann's metroplasty is a unification procedure for the bicornuate uterus.

Related Pearl: Mullerian Anomalies

 

Class Mullerian anomaly Reason/Feature Treatment Complications
I Uterine hypoplasia or uterine agenesis Underdeveloped or non-developed paramesonephric duct

Surrogacy for treatment of infertility 

Vaginal hypoplasia is surgically corrected at the time of marriage

 Infertility

 
II Unicornuate uterus Non-developed paramesonephric duct Excision of rudimentary horn, if any   Uterine rupture, abortions, risk of miscarriage, preterm, and malpresentation
III Uterus didelphys Unfused paramesonephric duct Metroplasty (Resection of membrane and fundal recombination) Risk of miscarriage, preterm, and malpresentation 
IV Bicornuate uterus  Lower part fused where as upper part unfused Metroplasty in selected cases  Risk of miscarriage, preterm, and malpresentation
V Septate uterus  Septa of fused part persists Hysteroscopic septal resection 

Diminished fertility, Risk of miscarriage, preterm, and malpresentation

 
VI Arcuate uterus A small indentation at upper part    
VII Diethylstillbesterone (DES), drug related T-shaped uterus, shortened and narrow fallopian tubes, cervical collars (cockscomb cervix)   Ectopic pregnancy,  cervical incompetance,  clear cell adenocarcinoma of vagina and cervix 

A common complication is an abortion in the second trimester.

Arcuate uterus: Some studies report no increase in adverse outcomes, whereas some studies have shown excessive second trimester loss, preterm labor and malpresentations.

questions.text: Which of the following devices can be used in a patient with severe bilateral sensorineural hearing loss?
questions.solution:
Device 2 shown in the above image represents a cochlear implant, which can be used in a patient with bilateral severe sensorineural hearing loss.

A cochlear implant is a medical device that uses electricity to stimulate the spiral ganglion cells of the auditory nerve to restore sensorineural hearing loss. It converts sound to an electrical signal (transduction) and delivers this to the hearing nerve, which bypasses the damaged hearing apparatus. It cannot be used in patients with cochlear aplasia or without the VIIIth cranial nerve.

Other options: 

Option B: Device 3 is a picture of a stapedectomy piston, used in patients with otosclerosis.

Option C: Device 1 is a picture of a Bone Anchored Hearing Aid (BAHA), which can be used in a patient with bilateral external auditory canal atresia. It consists of three parts, an innermost titanium fixture in the bone, a middle abutment and an outer hearing aid fixed to the abutment.

Option D: Device 4 is a picture of a partial ossicular replacement prosthesis that is designed for situations when the incus and/or malleus are eroded but the stapes is structurally intact.

questions.text: In the given image, the artery of epistaxis is indicated by _____.
questions.solution:
Structure marked C is the sphenopalatine artery which is called the “artery of epistaxis”.

It is called the artery of epistaxis since the majority of the blood supply to the nasal cavity is by the sphenopalatine artery and it is the most commonly involved artery in epistaxis.

Other structures marked in the diagram are as follows:

  • A: Anterior ethmoidal artery
  • B: Posterior ethmoidal artery
  • D: Greater palatine artery

questions.text: A 22-year-old patient is assessed with an ECG during his wellness check-up visit. Calculate the heart rate from the ECG given below.
questions.solution:
The RR interval has 19 small boxes in between, and hence the heart rate is 1500/19~79/min.

The relationship between the heart rate and the RR interval is given by: 

Heart rate = 1500/(number of small boxes (1mm each) in between successive R waves) 

Methods to calculate heart rate from ECG: 

Box counting methods: This can be done via the number of small boxes or the large boxes between two successive R waves. If using the large boxes, the equation is  

Heart rate = 300/(number of big boxes (5mm each) in between successive R waves) 

QRS counting methods: This is used when the heart rate is irregular. Thus there will be a variability in the RR intervals, making the box-counting method unreliable. Here, the number of QRS intervals in a set interval, for example, 10 seconds, is counted. This number is then multiplied by an appropriate factor to get an estimate for 60s. In this example, we would multiple the number of QRS complexes in 10s by 6. 

Tachycardia is defined as a heart rate of more than 100 beats/minute and bradycardia is defined as a heart rate of less than 60 beats/minute.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought with recurrent episodes of blood in his stool. Meckel’s diverticulum is suspected. Which of the following can be used to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Tc-99m pertechnetate scanning is used to confirm the diagnosis of Meckel's diverticulum.

Meckel's diverticulum is a congenital anomaly of the gastrointestinal tract, resulting from incomplete obliteration of the vitelline duct during embryonic development. It is a true diverticulum, meaning it contains all layers of the intestinal wall (mucosa, submucosa, and muscularis).

Rule of Twos:

2% prevalence.
2 feet from the ileocecal valve.
2 inches in length.

Other uses of Tc-99m pertechnetate include

  • Thyroid imaging
  • Parathyroid imaging for distinguishing from the thyroid gland
  • Testicular imaging
  • Gastric emptying studies; intestinal and rectal functional studies

questions.text: A 28-year-old man sustained a road traffic accident and has a large wound on the thigh. After initial wound management, the plastic surgeon decides to cover the wound with a split skin graft. The order by which split skin graft survives is by_________
questions.solution:
Split skin graft survives by imbibition- inosculation-neovascularization.

Split skin graft survives the transplantation surgery by the following process:

  • The graft survives the first 48 hours because of the imbibition of plasma from the wound bed.
  • After 48 hours, fine anastomotic connections are made, which leads to the inosculation of blood.
  • Neovascularization is the process by which new blood vessels formed will directly invade the graft and restore the pink colour of the skin.

Related Pearl: Skin graft : phases of uptake of the graft

The take of skin graft occurs in three phases:

  1. Imbibition (Plasmatic circulation): during the first 48 hours, the graft is nourished with plasma exudate from host bed capillaries.
  2. Inosculation, in which cut vessels from the host bed line up with the cut ends of the vessels of the graft to form anastomoses
  3. Neovascularization, in which blood vessels grow from the recipient bed into the graft

Sensibility returns to the graft over time, with reinnervation beginning at approximately 4 to 5 weeks and being completed by 12 to 24 months. Pain returns first, with light touch and temperature returning later.

Note: some books give that the 3 phases are imbibition,revascularisation (inosculation+neovascularisation) and organisation (fibrin layer holds the graft in place and this is replaced by postgraft day 7 with fibroblasts)

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the image given below.
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the MRI of the brain is the Internal capsule.

The image below shows parts of the brain in an axial section of an MRI.

The internal capsule is a component of the white matter of the brain. They contain projection fibers. It can be divided into the following parts:

  • Anterior limb
  • Genu
  • Posterior limb
  • Retrolenticular/retrolentiform portion
  • Sublenticular/sublentiform portion

The anterior limb of the internal capsule carries the fronto-pontine fibers, a lesion here produces confusion, impaired attention, agitation, and dysarthria.

Genu carries fibers of the corticonuclear tract. 

The posterior limb of the internal capsule carries cortico-spinal motor fibers in the anterior part and the lesion here produces contralateral hemiparesis. The posterior part of the posterior limb carries sensory fibers and lesions here may produce contralateral hemi-sensory deficits.

The retro-lenticular part carries fibers mainly from optic radiation. A lesion here produces homonymous hemianopia, superior quadrantanopia, or inferior quadrantanopia.

The sub-lenticular part contains temporopontine and some parietopontine fibers.

Related Pearl: Blood supply of internal capsule.

 
Blood supply of internal capsule.

Anterior limb 

  • Recurrent artery of Heubner
Genu 
  • Recurrent artery of Heubner
  • Charcot's artery (lenticulostriate artery or artery of cerebral hemorrrahge)
Posterior limb
  • Charcot's artery (branch of Middle cerebral artery)
  • Anterior choroidal artery ( branch of internal carotid artery)
  • Posterolateral branches of posterior cerebral artery
Sublentiform part
  • Anterior choroidal artery
  • Posterior cerebral artery
Retrolentiform part
  • Posterolateral branches of posterior cerebral artery
