questions.text: A 55-year-old lady presents with third degree uterine prolapse. Which of the following is the best management for her?

choices.text: Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair

questions.solution:
The best management for third degree uterine prolapse is vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair.

Uterine prolapse is the descent of the uterus from its normal position which usually occurs due to laxity of ligaments that offer support, seen often due to childbirth, aging, or trauma. The uterine descent is clinically categorized into:

  • First degree : the external os remains above the vaginal introitus.
  • Second degree : The external os protrudes below the vaginal introitus but the uterine body remains inside the vagina.
  • Third degree : The uterine, cervix, body, and fundus descend to lie outside the introitus.
  • Procidentia involves prolapse of the uterus with the entire vagina everted.

The patient usually presents with a sense of heaviness in the pelvic region with lower back discomfort. Based on the structures involved the patient can additionally have urinary symptoms like incontinence and urgency, bowel disturbances (constipation and tenesmus), or sexual discomfort during intercourse.

Symptomatic uterine prolapse is managed surgically with different procedures based on the profile of the patient. Conservative management is done for old asymptomatic women with mild degree prolapse. 

A vaginal hysterectomy is recommended for patients who satisfy the following criteria, >40 years of age, have completed their families and do not wish to preserve menstrual and child-bearing function.

Other options:

Option A: Fothergill repair or Manchester operation is a procedure done to preserve the reproductive function and vaginal prolapse with supravaginal cervix elongation. It initially involves preliminary curettage with low amputation of the cervix. After Mackenrodt's ligament is plicated,  anterior colporrhaphy and colpoperineorrhaphy are performed.

Option B: Sling operation (Purandare's operation) is indicated in congenital or nulliparous prolapse without cystocele. The procedure involves the extraperitoneal passage of rectus sheath strips joined to the anterior surface of the cervix by silk sutures.

Option D: Shirodkar procedure is a type of abdominal sling surgery done in young women to retain menstrual and reproductive function. It involves using a sling to fix the cervix to the lumbosacral fascia. 

Related Pearl: Management of Uterine prolapse

Congenital/ Nulliparous (young) uterine prolapse: Sling/ cervicopexy

Uterovaginal uterine prolapse:

Age/condition Desire for pregnancy Desire for menstruation Surgery
<40 No Yes Fothergill's operation
>40 No No  Ward Mayo's vaginal hysterectomy
>60(medically unfit for hysterectomy)        -      - Le Forts repair
Prolapse during pregnancy /puerperium     -       - Ring Pessary

questions.text:
A 20-year-old race car champion is brought by his manager to the ENT surgeon for the correction of the condition shown below, which occurred after sustaining a blow to the face by the runner-up two months prior. The driver is asymptomatic and is scheduled to undergo an SMR operation. Identify the false statement about this procedure.

SMR - Submucous Resection of Nasal Septum

choices.text: Most of the bone and cartilage are preserved
Not done before the age of 17 years
Periosteal flaps raised on both sides of septum
Greater chance of complications compared to septoplasty

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette with an image showing the midline deviation of the dorsum of the nose is indicative of a deviated nasal septum (DNS). The false statement about the SMR (submucous resection of nasal septum) procedure is that most of the bone and cartilage are preserved.

DNS is an important cause of nasal obstruction. It is associated with the following symptoms:

  • Nasal obstruction
  • Chronic sinusitis
  • Headache
  • Epistaxis
  • Anosmia
  • External deformity. 

The indications for an SMR are:

  • DNS causing symptoms of nasal obstruction and recurrent headaches.
  • DNS obstructing paranasal sinuses and middle ear, resulting in recurrent sinusitis and otitis media.
  • Recurrent epistaxis from a septal spur.
  • As a part of septorhinoplasty, for cosmetic correction of external nasal deformities.
  • As a preliminary step in hypophysectomy or Vidian neurectomy.

It is contraindicated in children below 17 years of age (Option B), during acute respiratory infection, bleeding diathesis, untreated diabetes, or hypertension.

In this procedure, mucoperichondrial and mucoperiosteal flaps are raised on both sides of the septum (Option C). Bony and cartilaginous parts of the septum are excised. This is followed by extensive dissection of the septum removing all deformed bony and cartilaginous parts of the septum and preserving only a caudal and a dorsal strut of cartilage.

Re-operating following an SMR is difficult compared to a septoplasty, which involves fewer complications and an easier re-operation. (Option D)

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic male presents with a history of decreased vision. Fluorescein angiography showed the following image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image of fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) depicts neovascularization, which is the hallmark of proliferative diabetic retinopathy.

The neovascularization arises from the optic nerve head; there is neovascularization of the disc (NVD) along the large vessels and neovascularization elsewhere (NVE).The treatment available for proliferative diabetic retinopathy is photocoagulation of the ischaemic areas to reduce the metabolic demand and decrease or prevent the release of vasoproliferative factors.

Stages and fundus picture in diabetic retinopathy:

Background Diabetic Retinopathy:

  • Microaneurysms 
  • Dot and Blot hemorrhages 
  • Exudates

Preproliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (indicates progressive retinal ischemia):

  • Intra-retinal microvascular abnormalities
  • Venous changes (such as beading)
  • Cotton wool spots
  • Deep retinal hemorrhages

Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy:

  • NeoVascularization of the optic Disc (NVD)
  • NeoVascularization Elsewhere in the periphery of the fundus (NVE)

Advanced Diabetic Eye Disease:

  • Tractional retinal detachment
  • Vitreous hemorrhage
  • Neovascular glaucoma

Diabetic Maculopathy is a separate entity that is applied to the changes that occur in the macula such as macular edema or ischemia.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male is overly conscious about perfection in all the work he does. He is very concerned about strictly following rules and becomes intolerant when the rules are not followed. Which of the following best describes this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario describes obsessive compulsive personality disorder. 

Obsessive compulsive /Anankastic personality disorder:

  • Obsessive-compulsive personality disorder is characterized by emotional constriction, orderliness, perseverance, stubbornness, and indecisiveness. The essential feature of the disorder is a pervasive pattern of perfectionism and inflexibility. It is ego-syntonic: behavior consistent with one’s own beliefs and attitudes (vs OCD which is ego dystonic and will cause distress to the patient).

Obsessive compulsive disorder:

  • It is characterised by the presence of obsessions and compulsive acts. In the given history, there are no obsessions or compulsions.

Related Pearl: Personality Disorders

Key features of Personality disorders

Cluster A (Odd, Weird, Eccentric)
Paranoid
Suspicious, distrustful, hypervigilant
Schizoid
Prefers to be loner, detached, unemotional
Schizotypal
Eccentric & odd thoughts, perceptions & behavior, magical thinking and beliefs

Cluster B (Dramatic, Emotional and Erratic)
Antisocial
Disregard for and violation of rights of others, illegal activities
Borderline
Chaotic relationships, sensitivity to abandonment, labile mood, impulsivity, inner emptiness, self-harm
Histrionic
Dramatic, superficial, attention-seeking
Narcissistic
Grandiosity, lack of empathy

Cluster C (Anxious, Fearful, Introvert)
Avoidant
Avoidance due to fears of criticism and rejection
Dependent
Submissive, clingy, needs to be taken care of
Obsessive-compulsive
Rigid, controlling, perfectionist

questions.text: A 51-year-old man complains of abdominal pain and blood-stained stools. The barium study of his intestines shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the radiological images suggest intussusception.

In intussusception, the occluding mass prolapsing into the lumen has been termed the coiled spring appearance (barium in the lumen of the intussusceptum and in the intraluminal space). In adults, it develops due to a tumor of the bowel.

Causes of intussusception are:

Idiopathic - most common cause in children
Pathological lead points include enlarged submucosal Peyer's patch, lymphoma, intestinal polyp, leiomyomas, etc.
Meckel's diverticulum
A recent upper GI or respiratory infection, rotavirus vaccination has also shown some association with intussusception in children
In adults, it develops due to a tumor of the bowel.

The intussusception appears as a sausage-shaped mass in a longitudinal plane or a target mass in the transverse plane on CT and USG. 

Ultrasound signs include:

  • Target sign (also known as the doughnut sign)
  • Pseudokidney sign- this is seen in the longitudinal section of the bowel
    • the edematous bowel resembles renal parenchyma and
    • the mesentery which is dragged into the intussusception resembles renal hilum

Crescent in a doughnut sign.
The following ultrasound image shows the target sign seen in intussusception. 

Option B: Volvulus presents with constipation, abdominal bloating, nausea, and/or vomiting. It shows a coffee bean sign

Option C: Diverticulitis presents with pain in the left iliac fossa

Option D: Ulcerative colitis causes backwash ileitis.

questions.text:
Which of the following conditions is/are not associated with secondary Raynaud's phenomenon?
  1. Systemic lupus erythematosus
  2. Scleroderma
  3. Buerger disease
  4. Raynaud's disease
  5. Atherosclerosis
questions.solution:
Raynaud’s disease is a primary Raynaud's phenomenon, and all others are associated with secondary Raynaud's phenomenon.

Raynaud's Phenomenon refers to exaggerated vasoconstriction of arteries and arterioles in the extremities, particularly the fingers and toes, but also occasionally the nose, earlobes, or lips.

The restricted blood flow induces paroxysmal pallor, and even cyanosis in severe cases. The involved digits classically show red, white, and blue color changes from the most proximal to most distal regions. This correlates with proximal vasodilation, central vasoconstriction, and more distal cyanosis.

Raynaud phenomenon can be a primary entity or secondary to other disorders.

Primary Raynaud

Secondary Raynaud

Caused by exaggerated central and local vasomotor responses to cold or emotion.

Has a predilection for young women.

Results from vascular insufficiency due to arterial disease.

Raynaud disease

Systemic lupus erythematosus, scleroderma, Buerger disease, atherosclerosis

Symmetrically affects the extremities

Asymmetric involvement of the extremities

The severity and extent of involvement typically remain static over time

Progressively worsens in extent and severity over time

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common site of ectopic parathyroid gland?
questions.solution:
The most common site of the ectopic parathyroid gland is paraesophageal.

The common sites of ectopic parathyroid glands are

  • Paraesophageal - most common
  • Mediastinal 
  • Intrathymic 
  • Intrathyroidal 
  • Carotid sheath 
  • High cervical or undescended 

Ectopic parathyroid is the most common cause of persistent or recurrent hyperparathyroidism. In such cases, treatment involves surgical removal of the gland.

questions.text: Identify the stage of senile cataract depicted in the given image.
questions.solution:
The stage of cataract in the given image is characteristic of Morgagnian hypermature cataract.

Morgagnian cataract is a form of hypermature senile cataract formed by liquefaction of the cortex and sinking of the dense nucleus to the bottom of the capsular bag. The liquefied cortex is milky, and the nucleus is usually seen as a brown mass limited above by a semicircular line. Changes in the position of the head cause alteration of the position of the nucleus.

Other options :

Option A: Intumescent cataract is also known as immature senile catarct. It is associated with greyish white lens and clear cortex with iris shadow visible.

Option B: Mature senile cataract / ripe cataract has pearly white lens due to complete opacification. 

Option D:  In the sclerotic type of hypermature cataract, the lens hardens entirely, becoming densely white and significantly impairing vision.

Related Pearl: Maturation of Cortical Cataract

  • Stage of lamellar separation
  • Stage of incipient cataract
    • Cuneiform and cupuliform patterns can be made out at this stage.
  • Immature senile cataract/ Intumescent cataract:
    • Lens is greyish white.
    • Clear cortex is still present, so iris shadow is visible.
  • Mature cortical cataract
    • Mature senile cataract/ripe cataract
    • Opacification is complete
    • Lens is pearly white

Morgagnian hypermature cataract

  • The whole cortex liquifies and the lens is converted into a bag of milky fluid.
  • The small, brownish nucleus settles at the bottom, altering its position with change in the position of the head.

The image below depicts a Morgagnian hypermature cataract.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman who is a known smoker presents with slit-like retraction of the right nipple. She gives a history of chronic greenish discharge from the same site previously. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of chronic greenish discharge followed by slit-like retraction of the nipple in a middle-aged woman is suggestive of duct ectasia.

Duct ectasia is the dilatation of major breast ducts. It is a common cause of nipple discharge in non-lactating women. This disease's initial stage consists of dilating one or more lactiferous ducts. These ducts fill with stagnant brown or green-coloured secretions, and discharge from the collection may occur.

In the later stages, fluid accumulation in the lactiferous ducts leads to inflammation causing periductal mastitis. If the condition does not resolve, it can lead to the formation of a subareolar mass or abscess, and even mammary duct fistulas. The persistence of this condition eventually leads to fibrosis, which can cause slit-like retraction of the nipple.

Initial episodes can be managed with antibiotics. Recurrent episodes of the disease are best managed by Hadfield operation. This operation consists of the excision of all the major lactiferous ducts.  If a single duct is involved, then a microdochectomy is performed.

The mammography image of broken-needle calcification seen in duct ectasia is seen below.

Other options:

Option A: Intraductal papilloma is a benign condition wherein a wart-like growth occurs within the mammary ducts. They are made up of glandular and fibrous tissue and vascular vessels. It is associated with blood-stained discharge.

Option C: Fibroadenoma presents as a breast lump in women aged 15–25 years. The ultrasound image depicts a well-circumscribed oval mass with uniform hypoechogenicity as given in the image below.

Option D: Paget’s disease is a type of in-situ carcinoma arising in the nipple characterized by nipple erythema and irritation. It is associated with pruritus and slowly destroys the nipple and the areola. The image below shows Paget's disease of the breast.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient complains of decreased distant vision but now he does not use spectacles for near vision. The image of his ocular examination is given below. What is this type of refractive error called?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario and the image is index myopia seen in nuclear senile cataracts.

Index myopia occurs due to an increase in the refractive index of the crystalline lens due to nuclear sclerosis. Nuclear sclerosis is an ageing process in which the lens becomes hard and inelastic resulting in an increase in the refractive index, causing progressive myopia (decreased distant vision). A patient with presbyopia may be able to read again, without the aid of spectacles. This improvement in vision is termed second sight.

Other options:

Option B: Axial myopia is the most common type of myopia resulting due to an increase in the anteroposterior length of the eyeball. 

Option C: Curvatural myopia results due to increased curvature of the cornea, lens, or both.

Option D: Positional myopia results due to anterior placement of the crystalline lens in the eye.

Related Pearl: Important symptoms and their occurrence in cataract

Symptom Condition
Monocular diplopia or polyopia Cortical cataract (Incipient stage)
Color shift Nuclear cataract
Index hypermetropia Cortical cataract
Loss of ability to see objects in bright sunlight, blinded by the light of oncoming headlamps when driving at night Posterior subcapsular cataract and Nuclear cataract
Second sight/ Myopic shift/ Index myopia Nuclear cataract
Fluctuating refractive error Diabetic cataract (due to fluctuating blood sugar levels)

Related Pearl: Causes of Myopia

Myopia

Etiology

Axial myopia

(Most common)

Increase in the anteroposterior length of the eyeball.

Curvatural myopia

Increased curvature of the cornea, lens, or both

Positional myopia

Anterior placement of the crystalline lens in the eye

Index myopia

Increase in the refractive index of crystalline lens

Nocturnal myopia

Due to spherical aberration and accomodation

questions.text: An infant presents with copious bilious vomiting and abdominal distension on the 5th day of life. He had not passed meconium for the first 3 days after birth. An abdominal radiograph shows the presence of dilated bowel loops. What is the gold standard investigation for the given condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Hirschsprung's disease. A rectal biopsy is the gold standard for the diagnosis of Hirschsprung’s disease.

A rectal biopsy 2 cm above the dentate line is the ideal area for a biopsy.

Hirschsprung’s disease is a developmental disorder characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the myenteric (Auerbach) plexus and submucosal (Meissner) plexus. Most infants present with abdominal distention and bilious emesis with failure to pass meconium within the first 24 hours of life.

The initial investigation is a contrast enema. The area between the dilated and contracted segments is referred to as the transition zone. The affected part shows the absence of ganglion cells and hypertrophy of nerve trunks in the rectal biopsy.

Other investigations for Hirschsprung’s disease include:

  • Water-soluble contrast enema - shows the presence of contracted aganglionic rectum, transition zone, and a dilated normally innervated colon.
  • Anorectal manometry - shows the failure of the relaxation of the internal anal sphincter.

 Definitive surgeries for Hirschsprung disease are as follows:

  • Swenson procedure, where aganglionic bowel is removed and a coloanal anastomosis is performed.
  • Duhamel procedure, where the aganglionic rectal stump is left in place and the ganglionated normal colon is pulled posterior.
  • Soave procedure, where endorectal mucosal dissection is done within the aganglionic distal rectum. The ganglionated normal colon is pulled through the remnant muscular cuff, and a coloanal anastomosis is performed.

questions.text: A female presents with hirsutism, delayed periods & obesity. USG findings are given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the ultrasound image given below showing an enlarged ovary with multiple follicles in the periphery(a string of pearls) is indicative of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS).

PCOS is an endocrinopathy seen in women of reproductive age, affecting multiple systems. The Rotterdam criteria are used to diagnose PCOS. The presence of any two of the three components of this criteria establishes the diagnosis of PCOS:

  • Clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism (hirsutism, acne)
  • Menstrual abnormalities (oligo/amenorrhoea), anovulation, infertility
  • Polycystic ovaries on ultrasonography.

Sonographic criteria for polycystic ovaries include ≥ 12 small cysts, an increased ovarian volume (> 10 mL) or both. 

Management:

  • Weight reduction alone is beneficial in mild hirsutism and lifestyle changes (like smoking cessation) are advised in the management of PCOS.
  • Oral contraceptive pills (OCP), preferably fourth-generation pills with 30 mcg E2 and 2-3 mg drospirenone are used to treat menstrual abnormalities. It also reduces acne and further hirsutism.
  • Anti-androgens are useful in treating hirsutism. OCP with cyproterone acetate is prescribed for PCOS patients with hirsutism. 
  • Patients with PCOD are more prone to developing insulin resistance which can be controlled with metformin. Acarbose can be used if metformin is contraindicated
  • Patients presenting with infertility are treated by inducing ovulation using clomiphene as a first-line drug, along with dexamethasone and letrozole.

Surgical options include laparoscopic ovarian drilling or puncture of not more than four cysts in each ovary. This is done either by laser or by unipolar electrocautery. It restores the endocrine levels and improves fertility.

Surgery is indicated only if,

  • Medical therapy fails
  • Hyperstimulation occurs
  • Infertile women
  • Previous pregnancy losses

Other Options:

Option B: Molar Pregnancy will produce a characteristic Snowstorm appearance on ultrasound.

Option C: Enlarged ovaries meeting in the midline having large cysts are suggestive of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome.

Option D: The image below depicts multiple theca lutein cysts.

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 - 70 ng/dL)
    • Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor
    • DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

Related Pearl: Management of PCOD

Complaint Management  
Irregular periods OCPs
Obesity Lifestyle modification
Insulin resistance Metformin
Hirsutism /acne OCPs with cyproterone acetate
Infertility Clomiphene

Note: Letrozole is as effective as Clomiphene in treating infertility in PCOD with fewer side effects. However, it's pending FDA approval and is used off-label.

questions.text: The following finding in pigmentary glaucoma is _______.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a pattern of the deposition of pigments on the back of the cornea in pigmentary glaucoma which is called as Krukenberg spindles. 

Pigmentary glaucoma is a type of open-angle glaucoma characterized by several key features. These include Krukenberg spindles, which are found on the corneal endothelium, and pigment accumulation along the inferior Schwalbe line, known as the Sampaolesi line, as seen during gonioscopy.

A distinctive pathognomonic sign is the presence of radial transillumination defects in the iris. Additionally, pigment granules may deposit on the anterior surface of the lens. Pigment may also form a Scheie line or a Zentmayer ring around the zonular insertions on the peripheral or equatorial surface of the lens.

Other options : 

Option A:  Ferry line is the corneal epithelial iron line at the edge of filtering blebs of glaucoma surgery.

Option B:  Kayser-Fleischer ring is observed in Wilson's disease, due to intraocular deposition of copper. A brownish-yellow zone is seen in the peripheral Descemet membrane of the cornea. 

Option C: Hudson–Stahli line is an iron deposition line in the corneal epithelium, which is commonly seen in the junction between the middle and lower third cornea. It is age related condition.

questions.text: A 37-week primigravida has mild labor pains for 20 hours and the cervix is persistently 1 cm dilated but non-effaced. What will be the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical case of a primigravida with mild labour pains for 20 hours and the cervix is persistently 1 cm dilated but, non-effaced is suggestive of a prolonged latent phase of labour or false labour pain and appropriate management would be sedation and wait.

False labour can be differentiated from the latent phase of labour by therapeutic rest i.e. the patient is sedated with morphine.

The first stage of labour is divided into the latent and active phases. The latent phase is defined as the period of cervical dilation up to 4 cm. If the latent phase exceeds 20 hours in a primigravida or 14 hours in a multigravida, it is termed a prolonged latent phase. It is not an indication of a C-section.

  Normal latent phase Prolonged latent phase
Primigravida 10-12 hours >20 hours
Multigravida 6-8 hours >14 hours

Causes of a prolonged latent phase include:

  • An unripe cervix.
  • Malposition or malpresentation of the fetus.
  • Cephalopelvic disproportion.
  • Premature rupture of membranes.
  • Induction of labor.
  • Early use of regional anaesthesia.

Other options :

Option B: Augmentation with oxytocin is done only in those patients who even after therapeutic rest continue to be in prolonged latent phase.

Option C: There is no indication of cesarean section unless cephalopelvic disproportion is present.

Option D: Amniotomy is not useful and should be avoided in patients with prolonged latent phase.

Related Pearl: Abnormalities of first stage of labor

Labor pattern Criteria- Nullipara Criteria-Multipara Treatment
Prolonged latent phase >20 hrs >14hrs

Bed rest

Oxytocin or cesarean delivery 
Protraction of dilatation <1.2cm/hr 1.5cm/hr

Expectant management and support

Cesarean delivery for CPD
Protraction of descent <1cm/hr <2cm/hr
Secondary arrest of dilatation >2hr >2hr

Check for CPD:

If no CPD- administer oxytocin

If CPD present- cesarean delivery

 
Arrest of descent >1hr >1hr
 CPD- Cephalopelvic disproportion

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of torsion of the testis in adolescents?

choices.text: Seperation of the epididymis from the body of the testis
Abnormal contraction of the cremastric muscles

questions.solution:
The most common cause of torsion of the testis is the high investment of tunica vaginalis which causes the testis to hang within the tunica like a clapper in a bell (bell­clapper abnormality). This is typically a bilateral abnormality.

For torsion to occur one of the following abnormalities must be present:

  • High investment of the tunica vaginalis causes the testis to hang within the tunica like a clapper in a bell. This is the most common cause in adolescents and is typically a bilateral abnormality
  • Inversion of the testis. The testis is rotated so that it lies transversely or upside down.
  • Separation of the epididymis from the body of the testis. This allows torsion of the testis on the pedicle that connects the testis with the epididymis.

Testicular torsion is typically seen in adolescence and presents with the sudden onset of testicular pain.

Twisting of the spermatic cord typically cuts off the venous drainage of the testis. But, thick-walled arteries remain patent, producing intense vascular engorgement, followed by hemorrhagic infarction.

The morphologic changes range from intense congestion to widespread hemorrhage to testicular infarction depending on the duration of torsion. In advanced stages, the testis is markedly enlarged and consists entirely of soft, necrotic, hemorrhagic tissue.

If the testis is manually untwisted within approximately 6 hours of the onset of torsion, there is a good chance that the testis will remain viable. Contralateral orchiopexy is performed to prevent recurrence in the unaffected testis.

Neonatal torsion can occur either in utero or shortly after birth and the cause is unknown.

The below image shows a gross specimen of torsion testis.

questions.text: Given below is the pin index for which gas:
questions.solution:
The given image shows the Pin index system (3,5) of Nitrous oxide. 

PIN index system (PISS) is a safety measure to prevent incorrect cylinder attachment.

  • Each gas cylinder has two holes (except entonox) in its cylinder valve that fits the corresponding pins in the yoke of the anesthesia machine. The relative positioning of the pins and holes is unique for each gas which constitutes the pin index system.
  • The PISS should only be considered as partial protection because pin index failures have been reported due to bent or broken pins.

Related Pearl: PIN index system (PISS):

Note:

  • Mixtures of CO2 and O2 with more than 7% CO2: 1,6
  • Mixtures of CO2 and O2 with less than 7% CO2: 2,6

questions.text: An alcohol addict presented with easy fatiguability. On examination, he is found to have pallor. Peripheral smear showed macrocytes and anisocytosis. Which of the following findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of megaloblastic anemia likely due to folate deficiency caused by alcohol addiction.

Megaloblastic anaemia may be caused by vitamin B12 deficiency or folic acid deficiency. Cyanocobalamin (vitamin B12) and folic acid are co-factors required for DNA synthesis. Thus, in B12 deficiency there is impairment of DNA synthesis that leads to defective nuclear maturation, ineffective hematopoiesis, and distinctive morphologic changes. These include abnormally large erythroid precursors and red cells. 

Peripheral smears in megaloblastic anemia show hypersegmented neutrophils, with five or more nuclear lobules instead of the normal three to four.

Folate deficiency leads to atrophic glossitis because of damage to the epithelial surfaces as shown in the image below.

Other options:

Option B: Migratory glossitis/geographic tongue is due to rapid loss and regrowth of filiform papillae of the tongue. It is a benign inflammatory condition of the tongue associated with psoriasis and reactive arthritis.

The image below shows migratory glossitis.

Option C: Strawberry tongue is due to the hypertrophy of fungiform papillae. It is seen in scarlet fever and Kawasaki disease.

The image below shows the strawberry tongue.

Option D: Macroglossia is an abnormal enlargement of the tongue and can be congenital or acquired. New-onset macroglossia in adults is highly suggestive of amyloidosis.

The image below shows macroglossia.

Related Pearl: Vitamin Deficiency States (Water-soluble Vitamins)

Vitamin

Deficiency State

Thiamine (B1)

Beriberi

Wernicke–Korsakoff’s syndrome

Riboflavin (B2)

Cheilosis, Magenta-coloured tongue, 

Glossitis, Seborrheic dermatitis

Niacin (B3)

Pellagra

Dermatitis, Diarrhea, Dementia

Pantothenic acid (B5)

Burning foot syndrome (historically called as "Nutritional melalgia")

Dermatitis, enteritis, alopecia, ataxia

Pyridoxine (B6)

Microcytic anemia, convulsions, depression

Relatively unknown

Dermatitis, atrophic glossitis, alopecia, paraesthesia, muscle pain, anorexia, hallucinations

questions.text: Which of the following findings would you least expect to observe while evaluating a case of Conn's syndrome?
questions.solution:
The findings least expected to observe while evaluating a case of Conn's syndrome are low aldosterone: renin ratio.

Patients with Conn's syndrome exhibit primary hyperaldosteronism, characterised by low serum renin levels and an elevated aldosterone: renin ratio.

Primary hyperaldosteronism is due to autonomous overproduction of aldosterone with resultant suppression of RAAS. It can occur due to adrenal hyperplasia, adenoma, or carcinoma. The increase in aldosterone results in a modest increase in plasma sodium, usually less than 4-6 mEq/L over the normal range, hypokalemia (due to increased K+ excretion), hypertension (due to slight increase in ECF volume), metabolic alkalosis because increased hydrogen ions are secreted in the urine.

When primary hyperaldosteronism is due to an aldosterone-secreting adenoma, it is called Conn's syndrome. Patients are usually treated with spironolactone followed by surgical removal of adenoma. In patients treated with spironolactone, the adenomas contain eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions called spironolactone bodies.

questions.text: The surgical site infection rate expected in a patient with a clean-contaminated wound that is operated upon after antibiotics prophylaxis is:
questions.solution:
The surgical site infection (SSI) rate expected in a patient with a clean-contaminated wound that is operated upon after antibiotics prophylaxis is 3%.

A clean-contaminated wound is an incision through which the respiratory, alimentary or genitourinary tract is entered and no contamination is encountered

questions.text: As per Sunderland's classification criteria for nerve injuries, injury to the endoneurium and the perineurium with an intact epineurium would be classified as:
questions.solution:
Injury to the endoneurium and the perineurium with an intact epineurium would be classified as grade 4.

Sunderland Classification of nerve injuries is based on the anatomical structure of the nerve. The degrees of injury are: 

  • 1°= Flow of axoplasm is partially blocked with no morphological changes. Recovery of function is complete ~ neurapraxia.
  • 2°= Axon loss occurs, but endoneurial tubes remain intact. Axons grow into their respective tubes during recovery, and the result is good ~ axonotmesis.
  • 3°= Injury to the endoneurium. During recovery, the axons of one tube can grow into another resulting in synkinesis.
  • 4°= Injury to perineurium in addition to above. Scarring impairs the regeneration of nerve fibers ~ partial transection.
  • 5°= Injury to epineurium in addition to above ~ complete nerve transection.
 

Related Pearl: Sunderland Classification of Nerve Injuries

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is popularly used in clinical anaesthesia to monitor neuromuscular blockade?
questions.solution:
Ulnar nerve stimulation at wrist is popularly used to assess the adequacy of neuromuscular blockade.

Neuromuscular blockade is measured using a peripheral nerve stimulator.

Nerve Response
Ulnar nerve Contraction of adductor pollicis
Facial nerve Contraction of orbicularis oculi
Posterior tibial nerve Contraction of flexor hallucis brevis

questions.text: A patient involved in a road traffic accident (RTA) presents with signs of seat belt abdominal trauma on the anterior abdominal wall. What should be the primary concern in terms of potential injuries?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a seat belt injury most likely indicates a hollow viscus injury. In cases of blunt abdominal trauma, particularly those involving seat belt injuries, there is a risk of sustaining injuries to the hollow viscera, which includes organs such as the stomach, small intestine, large intestine, and bladder.

Seat belt injuries can lead to compression forces against the abdomen, potentially causing shearing or tearing injuries to these structures.

Hollow viscus injuries can be challenging to diagnose clinically and may require imaging studies such as CT scans or exploratory surgery for confirmation.

Other Options:

Options A & B: While liver and spleen injuries are also common in blunt abdominal trauma, especially in cases of seat belt injuries, the question specifies signs of seat belt abdominal trauma on the anterior abdominal wall, which suggests a concern beyond these solid organs.

Option C: While the pancreas can be injured in cases of blunt abdominal trauma, the primary concern in this scenario, given the history of RTA and signs of seat belt abdominal trauma, should be focused on potential injuries to hollow viscera rather than the pancreas specifically.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about radiotherapy?

choices.text: Intensity is inversely proportional to squared distance
Vomiting is a late adverse reaction
Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant
Radiation-induced skin changes is a reversible adverse effect

questions.solution:
The intensity of radiation is inversely proportional to the squared distance from the source of radiation. This is known as the inverse square law in radiotherapy.

Inverse square law - the intensity of radiation is inversely proportional to the squared distance from the source of radiation. This principle is unsuitable for large tumors and has potential risks of radiation exposure to medical staff.

Other options: 

Option B: Vomiting can be an acute (early) adverse reaction to radiation therapy, occurring shortly after treatment.

Option C: Permanent non-dividing cells are more radioresistant than rapidly proliferating cells.

Option D: Not all the adverse effects of radiation therapy are reversible. Some of the adverse effects of radiation therapy, such as fibrosis, radiation-induced skin changes, late radiation enteritis, etc are irreversible.

questions.text: As an intern you are told to examine a patient diagnosed with Kienböck's disease. Which of the following best describes this condition?

choices.text: Stenosing tenosynovitis of the extensor tendons
Abnormally dense bone due to defective osteoclast

questions.solution:
Kienböck's disease involves avascular necrosis of the lunate.

This condition is usually seen in young adults, who present with pain and stiffness in the wrist. A history of trauma may be present. On examination, localized tenderness can be appreciated over the lunate, and a reduction in grip strength can be noted. Limited and painful wrist movements are noted in the later stages of the disease.

It involves four stages: 

  • Stage 1 involves ischemia of the bone, without any clinical or radiographic abnormality
  • Stage 2 shows trabecular necrosis with reactive new bone formation. There is increased radiographic density, but little/no distortion of the shape
  • Stage 3 involves the collapse of the bone
  • Stage 4 is characterized by disruption of radiocarpal congruence and secondary osteoarthritis

In the initial stages, an X-ray might be normal, therefore a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) with gadolinium enhancement is the investigation of choice. 

Management includes the use of splints and vascularized bone grafts for the early stages of the disease and total wrist fusion/replacement for advanced disease.

Below is an image of a patient with Kienböck's disease in the left hand.

Other options:

Option B:  Stenosing tenosynovitis of the extensor tendons is seen in De Quervain's disease.

Option C: Osteochondritis of the navicular bone is known as Kohler's disease.

Option D:  Abnormally dense bone with poor or absent medullary canal formation due to defective osteoclast function is seen in osteopetrosis. 

Related Pearl: Avascular Necrosis (AVN)

It is a rare but severe complication of certain fractures when the blood supply to a segment of bone is affected. 

Common sites of AVN are:

  • Head of femur in fracture neck of femur and posterior dislocation of hip
  • Body of talus in fracture through the neck of talus
  • Proximal pole of scaphoid in fracture through the waist of the scaphoid

Non-traumatic causes of AVN are:

  • Idiopathic
  • Steroids
  • Sickle cell disease
  • Caisson's disease
  • Gaucher's disease
  • Lupus Erythematosus
  • Radiation therapy
  • Alcoholism
  • Hyperlipidemia

Important signs related to avascular necrosis:

  • Crescent sign- Seen in osteonecrosis of the femoral head
  • Hawkin's sign- Seen in the fracture of neck of talus. Presence of this sign indicates that blood supply to the talus is adequate.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic presented with severe pain in ear and otorrhoea not responding to antibiotics. Facial nerve palsy is noted. On examination, granulation tissue is seen in the external auditory canal. What is the most common organism responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Elderly diabetic with severe otalgia, otorrhoea, granulation tissue in the external auditory canal and facial nerve palsy indicates malignant otitis externa. The most common causative agent remains Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

Malignant (necrotizing) otitis externa is associated with Pseudomonas infection in elderly diabetics and those on immunosuppressive drugs. It is termed malignant, though being an infection due to the high mortality rate and poor response to treatment.

Patients present with excruciating pain, profuse discharge & granulations on the floor of EAC. Necrosis of bone aids in the spread of infection. Facial paralysis is common.  Infection may spread to the skull base and jugular foramen causing multiple cranial nerve palsies.

Gallium-67 is more useful in the diagnosis and follow-up of the patient. Technetium 99 bone scan reveals bone infection, but the test remains positive for a year or so and cannot be used to monitor the disease. 

Treatment includes:

  • Diabetic control.
  • Ear toileting
  • Antibiotic treatment against the causative organism (P. aeruginosa) for 6–8 weeks or more.
Antibiotics found effective are:
  • Gentamicin combined with ticarcillin (intravenous).
  • Third-generation cephalosporins combined with an aminoglycoside (intravenous).
  • Quinolones combined with rifampin (oral). 
If the patient is not responsive, culture and sensitivity of ear discharge should be done. Prolonged antibiotic treatment has replaced radical surgery and resections done earlier for this condition.

questions.text: Identify the lesion in the given image.
questions.solution:
The given condition in the image is of arcus senilis.

Arcus senilis, also known as gerontoxon,  is an age-related lipid degeneration of the peripheral cornea. It is the most common corneal degeneration. It is present in 50% of individuals over the age of 60 years.

It starts in the superior and inferior perilimbal cornea. The peripheral border is separated from the limbus by a clear zone of the cornea. Lucid interval of Vogt is the clear cornea between limbus and arcus senilis. Lipid is deposited in the Bowman's layer and anterior stroma. Similar changes may occur in young persons called arcus juvenilis. 

Other options :

Option A : The Kayser- Fleischer (KF) ring is a dark brown ring caused by the deposition of excess copper in the Descemet membrane. It is classically seen in Wilson's disease. It may also be seen in certain chronic, cholestatic liver conditions such as primary biliary cirrhosis. 

Option C : Keratoglobus is a familial disorder, marked by thinning and hemispherical protrusion of the entire cornea. It can be congenital or acquired. A globular protrusion is seen here, in contrast to the conical ectasia seen in keratoconus. Intrastromal ring segments and cross-linking can be used for management.

Option D : Band-shaped keratopathy(BSK) is a corneal degenerative condition associated with the deposition of calcium salts in the deeper layers of corneal epithelium, Bowman's membrane and superficial part of the stroma.

questions.text:
A patient with uncontrolled hypertension and creatinine- 4.5 mg/dL was found to have unequal sized kidneys. Renal USG shows right kidney 9cm and left kidney 7cm in size. There was no evidence of any obstruction. The investigation of choice for the patient is______

IVP-intravenous pyelogram
questions.solution:
In this clinical scenario, a patient presents with uncontrolled hypertension, a creatinine level of 4.5 mg/dL, and a renal ultrasound showing a right kidney measuring 9 cm and a left kidney measuring 7 cm, with no signs of obstruction. The preferred investigation for this patient is an isotope renogram.

The most appropriate initial imaging test for a patient with hypertension and elevated creatinine is an abdominal ultrasound to assess renal size and morphology. If the ultrasound reveals a size discrepancy >1 cm between the kidneys, potential causes include unilateral developmental abnormalities, underlying disease processes, or renovascular disease leading to arterial insufficiency.

The diagnosis of renovascular hypertension can be made by Doppler ultrasound of the renal vasculature. As it is not given in the option the next choice for a patient with increased creatinine is an isotope renogram.

After USG, the next investigation of choice would be, Doppler USG  >  Isotope renogram  >  MRI studies.

Other options:

Option B: MR angiography cannot be done as there is a risk of nephrogenic fibrosis with gadolinium in patients with increased creatinine.

Option C: Retrograde pyelography is used for vesicoureteral reflux and would not be helpful. Obstruction is already ruled out. 

Option D: IVP(Intravenous pyelogram) is not done these days due to the risk of anaphylaxis.

questions.text:
A patient with asthma is being evaluated. His FEV1 values were measured before and after the administration of a short-acting beta-agonist. Which of the following values represents the minimum change required to demonstrate the reversibility of obstruction after administration of bronchodilators in this condition?

FEV1 - Forced expiratory volume in the first minute

FVC - Forced vital capacity

choices.text: > 12% increase in FEV1/FVC ratio and 200 mL increase in FEV1
> 50% increase in FEV1/FVC ratio and 500 mL increase in FEV1
> 20% increase in FEV1/FVC ratio and 410 mL increase in FEV1
> 6% increase in FEV1/FVC ratio and 100 mL increase in FEV1

questions.solution:
Reversibility of obstruction in asthma has to be demonstrated by a minimum of 12% increase in FEV1/FVC ratio and 200 mL increase in FEV1 in response to inhalation of short-acting beta-agonist (SABA).

In asthma, there is reversible bronchoconstriction leading to wheezing, breathlessness, and cough. Thus, on administering an SABA, there is bronchial relaxation and relief of symptoms. 

Asthma is generally diagnosed clinically based on symptoms alone. However, some other conditions can be misdiagnosed as asthma such as causes of wheezing (bronchogenic carcinoma, foreign body aspiration), cough (gastroesophageal reflux, chronic bronchitis, rhinitis), and dyspnea (chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, pulmonary edema, or obesity). Misdiagnosis would lead to a delay in management. Thus, it is ideal that the clinical diagnosis of asthma is confirmed by pulmonary function tests. 

  • Spirometry: It is a non-invasive investigation that can be used to approximate lung volumes. This shows an obstructive pattern
    • Decreased FEV1.
    • Decreased or normal FVC.
    • Decreased FEV1/FVC.
  • Bronchodilator reversibility: Spirometry is performed both before and after inhalation of a short-acting bronchodilator (400 mcg of β2 agonist or 160 mcg of anticholinergic). A 12% and 200 mL increase in FEV1 compared to pre-bronchodilator value is diagnostic of asthma in adults. 
  • Bronchial provocation test: Provocative stimulus (histamine, methacholine, inhaled mannitol, exercise, eucapnic hyperventilation with dry or cold air) is used to test the presence of airway hyperresponsiveness.  A fall of ≥20% in FEV1 from baseline, with a standard dose of methacholine (methacholine challenge test), is diagnostic of asthma.
  • Peak expiratory flow (PEF): PEF readings are taken twice daily for over 2 weeks. The average daily diurnal PEF variability of >10% is diagnostic of asthma in adults.

Related Pearl: PFT for obstructive vs restrictive diseases

  • Normal or increased in asthma

questions.text: Which of the following peaks marked in the image below is responsible for ovulation ?
questions.solution:
The label marked 2 represents the LH surge ,which is responsible for ovulation.

Phases of the menstrual cycle :

Follicular phase (days 0–14)

  • A primordial follicle develops to the Graafian stage, with atresia of neighboring follicles.
  • LH and FSH receptors are up-regulated in theca and granulosa cells.
  • Estradiol levels increase and cause proliferation of the uterus.
  • FSH and LH levels are suppressed by the negative feedback effect of estradiol on the anterior pituitary.
  • Progesterone levels are low.

Ovulation (day 14)

  • Occurs 14 days before menses, regardless of cycle length. Thus, in a 28-day cycle, ovulation occurs on day 14; in a 35-day cycle, ovulation occurs on day 22.
  • A burst of estradiol synthesis at the end of the follicular phase has a positive feedback effect on the secretion of FSH and LH (LH surge).
  • Ovulation occurs as a result of the estrogen-induced LH surge.
  • Estrogen levels decrease just after ovulation (but rise again during the luteal phase).
  • Cervical mucus increases in quantity; it becomes less viscous and more penetrable by sperm.

Luteal phase (days 14–28)

  • Progesterone levels are high.
  • The corpus luteum begins to develop, and it synthesizes estrogen and progesterone. Vascularity and secretory activity of the endometrium increase to prepare for receipt of a fertilized egg.
  • Basal body temperature increases because of the effect of progesterone on the hypothalamic thermoregulatory center.
  • If fertilization does not occur, the corpus luteum regresses at the end of the luteal phase. As a result, estradiol and progesterone levels decrease abruptly.

Menses (days 0–4)

  • The endometrium is sloughed because of the abrupt withdrawal of estradiol and progesterone.

A schematic diagram of the menstrual cycle and the changes occurring are shown below:

Related Pearl: Hormonal Regulation of Menstrual Cycle

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with malodorous vaginal discharge that began a week ago. On examination, the Whiff test is positive, and a Gram stain reveals the presence of clue cells. Which of the following is the most common treatment for this infection?
questions.solution:
Foul-smelling frothy vaginal discharge and a positive whiff test with clue cells in the gram staining suggest bacterial vaginosis and it is treated with metronidazole.

Bacterial vaginosis is caused due to the alteration in the normal vaginal flora. There is a decrease in the number of lactobacilli. These lactobacilli reduce the pH and release hydrogen peroxide which is antibacterial. Therefore, a decrease in the number of lactobacilli leads to an increase in the number of other organisms like Hemophilus vaginalis, Gardnerella, Mobiluncus, and Mycoplasma hominis. 

According to Amsel's criteria, the discharge has the following characteristics:

  • White milky non-viscous discharge, adherent to the vaginal wall.
  • The pH of the discharge is >4.5.
  • Fishy odor when mixed with 10% KOH. This is called the Whiff test.
  • Presence of clue cells-the epithelial cells have a fuzzy border due to the adherence of bacteria.
  • Decrease in the number of lactobacilli and increase in the number of Gardnerella and other bacteria.

It is treated with 500 mg of metronidazole twice daily for 7 days.

The below image shows the presence of clue cells.

Other options:

Option B: Nystatin pessary is used in the treatment of candidal vaginitis. They present with severe itching, dysuria, and passage of thick curdy discharge. On examination, the vagina is congested and thick curdy discharge can be seen at the vulval mucocutaneous junction and posterior fornix.

Options C and D: Tetracycline and azithromycin are used in the treatment of chlamydial infection. They usually present with vaginal discharge, dysuria, increased urinary frequency, and sometimes cervicitis. 

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

questions.text: What is the function of utricle and saccule?
questions.solution:
The function of utricle and saccule is linear acceleration.

Utricle and saccule which contain sensory epithelium called macula that are stimulated by linear acceleration and deceleration or gravitational pull during the head tilts.

The ampullated end of each semicircular canal contains a thickened ridge of neuroepithelium called crista ampullaris that respond to angular acceleration and deceleration.

Hearing is mediated by the organ of Corti on the basilar membrane of the inner ear.

questions.text: Examination of a patient with cervical carcinoma revealed a 6 cm cervical lesion, extending to the upper part of the vagina and parametrium. What is the stage of the disease?
questions.solution:
The stage of cervical carcinoma is 2 B as it extends beyond the uterus, i.e., the upper part of the vagina and parametrium and the lesion is > 4 cm.

This question and the pearl is according to the recent guidelines by FIGO for cancer cervix.

Related Pearl: Staging of Ca.Cervix

Clinical staging of Ca.Cervix

Stage 1: Limited to the cervix( extension to the uterine corpus should be disregarded)

  • A: Microscopic lesion
    • A1: Measured stromal invasion <3mm depth
    • A2: Measured stromal invasion 3-5mm depth
  • B: Macroscopic lesion ( lesion limited to cervix uteri)
    • B1: Invasive carcinoma ≥5mm in depth of stromal invasion, <2cm in greatest dimension
    • B2: Invasive carcinoma ≥2cm to <4cm in greatest dimension
    • B3: Invasive carcinoma ≥4cm in greatest dimension

Stage 2 

  • A: extends to the upper two-thirds of the vagina without parametrial involvement
    • A1: Invasive carcinoma <4cm in greatest dimension
    • A2: Invasive carcinoma ≥4cm in greatest dimension
  • B: extends to parametrium but not upto the pelvic wall.

Stage 3

  • A: extends to lower 1/3 of the vagina
  • B: extends to the pelvic wall (Hydronephrosis/ non functioning kidney)
  • C: Involvement of the pelvic and or para-aortic lymph nodes, irrespective of the tumor size and extent. 

             C1: pelvic lymph node metastasis only.

             C2: para-aortic lymph node metastasis

Stage 4

  • A: Bladder + Bowel involvement
  • B: Distant metastasis

Note:

Most common stage of presentation: IIIB

Inguinal lymph node is involved very rarely in Ca. Cervix.

The involvement of vascular/ lymphatic spaces do not change the staging. The lateral extent of the lesion is no longer considered.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with daytime sleepiness, impaired concentration, and impaired memory. On examination, her BMI is 43 kg/m2, blood pressure is 170/100 mm of Hg. Her awake arterial blood gas analysis shows bicarbonate - 33 mEq/L, PaCO2 - 53 mmHg,  PaO2 - 70 mmHg. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis of this patient with awake high pCO2, low pO2, and BMI of 41 is obesity hypoventilation syndrome.

Obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS) or Pickwickian syndrome is defined as the presence of awake alveolar hypoventilation in an obese individual which cannot be attributed to other conditions associated with alveolar hypoventilation.

Patients with OHS are obese and have a history of daytime hypersomnolence, loud snoring, choking during sleep fatigue, impaired concentration and memory, a small oropharynx, and a thick neck.

OHS may be associated with the following findings:

  • Elevated serum bicarbonate (>27 mEq/L)
  • Hypercapnia (PaCO2 >45 mmHg)
  • Hypoxemia (PaO2 <70 mmHg)
  • Polycythemia

Other options:

Option A: Central sleep apnea is characterized by a lack of respiratory effort during sleep, leading to recurrent pauses in breathing. It's less likely in this case due to the hypercapnia (elevated PaCO2) seen.

Option B: Narcolepsy involves excessive daytime sleepiness, sudden loss of muscle tone (cataplexy), sleep paralysis, and hallucinations during sleep onset. It doesn't typically cause elevated PaCO2.

Option D: Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA) involves repeated episodes of partial or complete upper airway obstruction during sleep. While obesity is a risk factor for OSA, the arterial blood gas analysis findings are more consistent with OHS.

questions.text: What is the refractive power of a lens whose focal length is 0.75 m?
questions.solution:
If the focal length of the lens is 0.75m, then the refractive power would be 1.33D.

Based on the given formula, Refractive power (dioptre) =  1/focal length in metres.

So, for the given question, refractive power (D) = 1/0.75 = 1.33 D.

questions.text: A female patient presents to you with fever, arthralgia, fatigue for the past six months, and new-onset hematuria. The patient has a rash on her face as shown in the image below. Urine examination reveals RBC casts and proteinuria. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of lupus nephritis.

Lupus nephritis is a common complication of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). It results from immune complex deposition containing DNA and anti-DNA. 

Clinical features include proteinuria, hematuria, and hypertension. The disease is divided into 6 classes based on severity. Patients with class V disease are at an increased risk of thrombotic complications. Lupus nephritis can result in end-stage disease warranting dialysis or transplantation.

SLE is an autoimmune condition more commonly seen in women. Antinuclear antibodies, anti-dsDNA, and anti-Sm are the autoantibodies implicated. Symptoms include maculopapular butterfly rash, photosensitivity, oral or nasal ulcers, fever, and intermittent polyarthritis. Pleuritis and pericarditis can also be associated. Systemic glucocorticoids, cyclophosphamide, or mycophenolate mofetil are used for management. Due to the possible teratogenic effects of these drugs, hydroxychloroquine is the mainstay in pregnancy.

Other options:

Option A - Acute interstitial nephritis is a type of acute kidney injury. It is marked by oliguria and raised creatinine. Various causes of interstitial injury include the use of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), pyelonephritis, leukemia, and sepsis. White blood cell (WBC) casts and granular casts may be seen.

Option B - Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis usually affects male children between the age of 2-14. Skin or pharyngeal infection with M types of the organism is implicated. Symptoms include hematuria, pyuria, and hypertension. Flank pain and headache are also associated symptoms. Red blood cell (RBC) casts are seen in the urine.

Option D - IgA nephropathy arises due to mesangial IgA deposition. It is characterized by recurrent macroscopic hematuria after an upper respiratory infection associated with proteinuria. Mesangial proliferation is a distinctive feature. Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors and steroids can be used for management.

Related Pearl: Classification of Lupus Nephritis (International Society of Nephrology and Renal Pathology Society)

 

Class 

Findings

Minimal mesangial lupus nephritis (class I)

Immune complex deposition in the mesangium without structural changes by light microscopy.

Mesangial proliferative lupus nephritis (class II)

Mesangial cell proliferation, accumulation of mesangial matrix, and granular mesangial deposits of immunoglobulin and complement

Focal lupus nephritis (class III)

Involvement of fewer than 50% of all glomeruli.

Endocapillary proliferation associated with focal necrosis and crescent formation.

Diffuse lupus nephritis (class IV)

Most common and severe form of lupus nephritis

>50% glomeruli are affected.

Diffuse endocapillary and extracapillary proliferation with cellular crescents

“Wire loop” structures on light microscopy (Subendothelial deposits).

Membranous lupus nephritis (class V)

Diffuse thickening of the capillary walls due to deposition of subepithelial immune complexes.

Advanced sclerosing lupus nephritis (class VI)

Sclerosis of more than 90% of the glomeruli 

 

 

The image below shows extensive deposition of immune complexes in the thickened glomerular capillary loops in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), giving a "wire loop" appearance:

questions.text: A female presents with hearing loss. A tympanogram is performed, and the results resemble the pattern shown in the image. Which of the following conditions does the patient most likely have?
questions.solution:
The image above shows a B-type tympanogram, which indicates tympanic membrane perforation.

A tympanogram is a measure of the tympanic membrane’s compliance or deflection to changes in pressure. There are 5 types of graphs seen:

  • A: Normal individuals. It is the most common graph in general population.
  • As: Otosclerosis/ Thick TM (Option D)
  • Ad: Ossicular discontinuity (Option B)/ Thin TM
  • B: Perforation of TM
  • C: Eustachian tube obstruction (Option C)

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: Which nerve is involved in Frey’s syndrome?
questions.solution:
The auriculotemporal nerve (V3 nerve) is involved in Frey's syndrome.

Frey’s syndrome is also known as Dupuy syndrome or auriculotemporal syndrome. It commonly develops post parotid surgery or other surgeries that cause an opening of the parotid capsule. It is caused by an aberrant regeneration of post-ganglionic parasympathetic nerve fibres, along the sympathetic pathways to the sweat glands near the parotid region. 

Clinical features as a result of salivary stimulation by the smell or taste of food include:

  • Sweating
  • Warmth
  • Redness of the face 

Diagnosed using a starch-iodine test. Denervation by a tympanic neurectomy or auriculotemporal nerve avulsion has been advocated in management but is often not curative. The symptoms can be managed by the subcutaneous infiltration of purified botulinum toxin into the affected area and the use of antiperspirant.

Related Pearl: Parasympathetic/ secretomotor (general visceral efferent) innervation of glands

  • Nervus intermedius, also called the nerve of Wrisberg, is the sensory & secretomotor component of the facial nerve.
  • The main trunk of the facial nerve, as it exits the brainstem, only carries motor fibers.
