questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presented to the clinic with the lesions shown below. She has been taking oral contraceptive pills. Identify the following lesions?
questions.solution:
The lesions shown in the image are spider naevi. They are seen in:

  • Estrogen excess states such as pregnancy and OCP use
  • Chronic liver disease - especially alcoholic liver disease
  • Thyrotoxicosis

They are vascular lesions characterized by the tortuous dilatation of arterioles just underneath the skin. On applying and releasing pressure over the lesion they typically fill from the center outward.

questions.text: A worried mother brought her 6-year-old unimmunized child to the ER with complaints of fever, cough, and shortness of breath. Examination reveals a bull-neck appearance and a pseudomembrane over the tonsils that bleeds when removed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 6-year-old suffering from fever, cough, and shortness of breath with a pseudomembrane and bull neck appearance on examination is suggestive of diphtheria.

Diphtheria is caused by the bacteria Corynebacterium diphtheriae which spreads via droplets through the respiratory tract (most important), cutaneous lesions, and fomites.

Respiratory tract diphtheria is characterized by a thick, adherent pseudomembrane (grey or white) on one/both tonsils and adjacent pharynx. Underlying soft tissue oedema and enlarged lymph nodes can cause a bull-neck appearance. 

Patients with laryngeal diphtheria are at risk for suffocation because of local soft-tissue oedema and airway obstruction by the diphtheritic membrane.

Management includes antitoxin therapy as a single empirical dose of 20,000-100,000 units and antibiotics. Penicillin G/ Benzylpenicillin is the drug of choice for diphtheria. However, in case of an allergy to the same, Erythromycin is used. Other antibiotics used are clindamycin, rifampin, and tetracycline.

A greyish-white membrane forms over the tonsils in the oropharynx and spreads to the soft palate and posterior pharyngeal wall. The membrane in diphtheria extends beyond the tonsils onto the soft palate and is dirty grey. It is adherent, and its removal leaves a bleeding surface. In the larynx, the diphtheritic membrane may cause airway obstruction.

Cervical lymph nodes, particularly the jugulodigastric, become enlarged and tender, sometimes presenting a bull-neck appearance. The patient is ill and toxaemic, but fever seldom rises above 38°C.

D/D for membrane over tonsil:

  • Streptococcus & other pyogenic organisms
  • Diphtheria
  • Infectious mononucleosis
  • Vincent’s angina
  • Leukaemia
  • Candida
  • Agranulocytosis
  • Malignancy
  • Aphthous ulcer
  • Traumatic ulcer

Other options :

Option A: Infectious mononucleosis most commonly presents in adolescents with initial symptoms of fever, sore throat, fatigue, myalgia, and malaise. Pharyngitis is often the most prominent sign, with the enlargement of the tonsils and an exudate resembling that of streptococcal pharyngitis. It can be associated with tender, posterior cervical lymphadenopathy. 

Option B: In acute membranous tonsillitis, exudates from the crypts coalesce to form a membrane on the surface of the tonsil that is easily wiped away without any bleeding.

Option D: Oral candidiasis/Oral thrush associated with candida albicans presents as white plaque-like lesions with cheesy exudate on an erythematous mucosa. They are typically painful and can be easily brushed off.

questions.text: A 65-year-old hypertensive patient presents with chest pain and dyspnea following an alcohol binge. His ECG is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with ECG showing narrow QRS complexes with irregular RR intervals and no distinct P waves is suggestive of atrial fibrillation.

Atrial fibrillation is the most common sustained arrhythmia. There is rapid and irregular atrial activation which is transmitted through the atrioventricular node. The conducted ventricular rate is usually rapid and irregularly irregular. It can vary from 110-160 beats/minute. A pulse deficit is an important clinical finding associated with the condition. This arises due to preload reduction. 

Symptoms include palpitations, fatigue, presyncope, and dyspnea. An ECG shows the absence of P waves. 

In acute atrial fibrillation with hemodynamic instability, electrical or chemical cardioversion is the first step. The latter is done by intravenous administration of class III antiarrhythmic - ibutilide. In a stable patient, ventricular rate control is the primary aim. This is done by intravenous or oral administration of beta-blockers. Calcium channel blockers such as verapamil and diltiazem can also be used. 

If the current episode duration is >48 hours, cardioversion can precipitate thromboembolic complications. In such cases, cardioversion should be carried out only after 3 weeks of anticoagulation. It has to be continued for 4 weeks after cardioversion. Another option is to evaluate the presence of a thrombus in the left atrial appendage. This can be done either by transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) or high-resolution CT.

If the duration is <48 hours and there are no high-risk factors, cardioversion can be done. The CHA2DS2-VASc scoring system is used to assess stroke risk. 

Warfarin is recommended in patients with rheumatic mitral stenosis or mechanical heart valves who present with atrial fibrillation. In mitral stenosis, thrombi arise frequently from the dilated left atrium. Atrial fibrillation in the absence of mitral stenosis is known as nonvalvular atrial fibrillation. Oral factor Xa inhibitors such as apixaban, edoxaban, or rivaroxaban can be used in such cases.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to you with complaints of recurrent swelling of his knees following minor traumas. The mother reports similar symptoms in her brother. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has prolonged partial thromboplastin (PTT) time due to Hemophilia A. 

This patient with a history of recurrent joint swelling on minor trauma with a positive family history on his mother's side and an abnormal coagulation panel raises suspicion for Hemophilia A. This condition is caused due to an X-linked recessive mutation leading to a deficiency of Factor VIII of the coagulation factors. This leads to a prolonged partial thromboplastin time. 

Hemophilia A is an X-linked recessive disorder. It occurs due to a deficiency of clotting factor VIII which causes inadequate thrombin generation and thus the inability to form a tight fibrin clot to support the platelet plug.

Symptoms include easy bruising, intramuscular hematomas, hemarthroses, hematuria, and bleeding from minor traumatic lacerations of the mouth can persist for hours or days. Retroperitoneal hemorrhages can accumulate large volumes of blood and may cause a hypovolemic shock.

Laboratory findings in hemophilia A:

  • Factor VIII - reduced
  • Partial thromboplastin time (PTT) - prolonged
  • Platelet count- normal
  • Bleeding time- normal
  • Prothrombin time- normal

A defect in platelet adhesion causes Von Willebrand's disease due to a deficiency of the Von Willebrand factor(VWF). These patients can develop a prolonged PTT as VWF also carries factor VIII so a deficiency of VWF can lead to a relative deficiency of Factor VIII.

Other options:

Option B: Glanzmanns disease is a condition caused by abnormalities of the GpIIBIIIA receptors on platelets and presents with a prolonged bleeding time. It does not cause a prolonged PTT.

Option C: Buerger's disease is a progressive nonatherosclerotic segmental inflammatory disease that most often affects small- and medium-sized arteries, veins, and nerves of the lower extremities. It is characterized by occlusive disease of small- and medium-sized arteries, thrombophlebitis of the superficial or deep veins, and Raynaud’s syndrome.

Option D: Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) is an IgA-mediated hypersensitivity reaction that presents with abdominal pain, palpable purpura, and glomerulonephritis. It does not have a prolonged PTT.

questions.text: A 17-year-old patient visits an adolescent clinic with complaints of nausea and vomiting. She has a positive home pregnancy test but does not recall her last menstrual period. Ultrasound reveals a viable pregnancy at 8 weeks gestation. Which of the following statements about the first trimester ultrasound is accurate?

choices.text: A gestational sac can be first seen 2 weeks after LMP
The accuracy of determining gestational age using ultrasound begins to decrease after the 1st trimester
Yolk sac is the first sign of pregnancy on USG
A normal gestational sac implants in the midline of the endometrial cavity

questions.solution:
The accurate statement about the first trimester ultrasound is, the accuracy of determining gestational age using ultrasound begins to decrease after the 1st trimester.

The best time to determine gestational age is 1st trimester and the accuracy decreases afterwards. 

Other options:

Option A: Gestational sac is reliably seen at 5 weeks via a transvaginal sonography

Option C: 1st evidence of pregnancy on sonography is the gestational sac. Visualisation of the yolk sac confirms an intrauterine location for pregnancy normally seen by middle of 5th week.

Option D: A normal gestational sac implants eccentrically in the endometrium, whereas a pseudosac is seen in the midline of endometrial cavity.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic patient presents with extreme pain in the right side of his trunk. On examination, blisters and a woody surface are noted. The image of his trunk is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of necrotizing fasciitis, which is most commonly caused by Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A β-hemolytic Streptococcus). 

Necrotizing fasciitis is a rapidly progressive necrosis of the subcutaneous tissues and fascia. The source of the infection is either the skin following trauma or a surgical incision. Diabetes mellitus is the most common comorbidity associated with the condition.

Local symptoms and signs are pain, erythema, edema, warmth, crepitus, blisters, bullae, greyish drainage (‘dishwater pus’), necrosis, and gangrene. Systemic features are fever, tachycardia, tachypnea, shock, coagulopathy, and multiorgan failure.

Treatment involves appropriate intravenous antibiotics with urgent radical surgical debridement.

Other options:

Option A: Gas gangrene is a form of myonecrosis caused by Clostridium perfringens. Patients who are immunocompromised are at a greater risk. Features are severe local wound pain and crepitus. Large doses of intravenous antibiotics and aggressive debridement of affected tissues are required.

The below image shows bluish-black discoloration and hemorrhagic bullae due to gas gangrene.

Option C: Cellulitis is an infection involving the skin and subcutaneous tissues. The point of entry may be a traumatic or surgical wound. Group B streptococci are the major causative organism. There is poor localisation and tissue destruction, gangrene and ulceration may follow, which are caused by the release of proteases. 

Option D: Erysipelas is an infection of the superficial epidermis. It presents as an erythematous raised lesion with sharply demarcated edges that differentiate it from the surrounding skin. The given image shows erysipelas.

questions.text: When providing CPR to an adult, what is the ratio of chest compressions to rescue breaths if there are 2 rescuers?
questions.solution:
During cardiopulmonary resuscitation of adults, the ratio of chest compression to rescue breaths is 30:2 (30 compressions followed by 2 rescue breaths)irrespective of the number of rescuers. 

In infants and children, the ratio is 30:2 for a single rescuer and 15:2 if 2 or more rescuers are present. This means when there are 2 rescuers, rescue breaths can be given more frequently(double the number of breaths when compared to a situation with just one rescuer). This is different from adult CPR.

Related Pearl: High quality CPR for adults

  • Push hard: 5-6cm depth
  • Push fast: 100-120/min frequency
  • Allow for complete chest recoil
  • Minimize interruptions in compressions <10 seconds
  • Avoid excessive ventilation
  • Rotate compressor every 2 min or earlier if fatigued
  • If no advanced airway, 30:2 compression-ventilation ratio

Attempt to improve CPR quality if :

  • Quantitative waveform capnography - PETCO2 <10mmHg, 
  • Intra-arterial pressure - If relaxation phase (diastolic) pressure <20mmHg

Related Pearl: Adult cardiac arrest algorithm (Updated as per 2020 guidelines)

questions.text: Identify the neurological test being performed.
questions.solution:
The image shows extensor plantar response, which is a positive Babinski sign.
 
The normal response to uncomfortable or painful cutaneous stimulation of the file of the foot includes plantar flexion of the toes. This can be accompanied by flexion withdrawal of the limb. If there is an upper motor neuron lesion affecting the leg being tested, there will be an extensor plantar response, which is a positive Babinski sign. The minimum extensor response to be looked for is at least the extension of the great toe. It can be accompanied by fanning of other tows and contraction of the tensor fascia lata. Other features which may be seen in UMN lesions are spasticity of the leg, pathologically brisk reflexes, and ankle clonus.
 
The below image shows the positive and negative Babinski signs.

The image below shows a positive Babinski sign in an adult, which is abnormal and indicative of a UMN lesion. 

In infants whose corticospinal tracts are still underdeveloped, dorsiflexion of the great toe and fanning of other toes is a normal response to scratching of the sole of the foot. The image below shows an extensor response in an infant, which is normal.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old primigravida at 38 weeks gestation presents to the antenatal clinic with complaints of feeling dizzy when lying down for the past week. She experiences relief when she turns to her side or sits up. What is the cause of her symptoms?

IVC-Inferior vena cava

choices.text: Excessive venous pooling at the feet

questions.solution:
The most likely reason a woman at 38 weeks of gestation complains of dizziness when she lies on her back but feels alright if she lies on her side or walks is inferior vena cava (IVC) compression.

During late pregnancy, when the patient is in a supine position, the gravid uterus exerts pressure on the inferior vena cava (IVC). This pressure stimulates the opening of collateral circulation through the paravertebral and azygos veins. However, in some cases, the collateral circulation may not be able to compensate, leading to severe impairment of venous return to the heart. As a result, the patient may experience syncope, tachycardia, and hypotension. The patient is rapidly turned to a lateral posture to return the blood pressure to normal. This phenomenon is called supine hypotension syndrome (postural hypotension).

Other options :

Option A: The pressure in the femoral vein noticeably increases, especially in the later months of pregnancy. The gravid uterus exerts pressure on the common iliac veins, particularly on the right side, due to the dextrorotation of the uterus. In a lying down position during pregnancy, the femoral venous pressure increases from 8 to 10 cm of water to around 25 cm of water. In a standing position, it increases to approximately 80 to 100 cm of water. This excessive pooling of the blood in the lower limbs explains the physiological edema observed during pregnancy.

Option C: Individuals with increased intracranial pressure may experience papilledema, neck stiffness, and visual problems. Several herniation syndromes can result from brain matter being forced through the fixed cranial apertures as the mass grows.

Option D: Abdominal aortic syndrome, also known as abdominal aortic aneurysm, is a life-threatening condition. Abdominal aortic aneurysms are mostly asymptomatic and are often detected as incidental findings during investigations for other complaints. In some cases, they present with pain and a pulsatile abdominal mass. The rupture of an aneurysm presents with acute pain and hypotension. Vigilant monitoring or treatment is required, depending on the size of the aneurysm and the presence of symptoms.

questions.text: A patient with a history of chronic liver disease presents with abdominal distension, jaundice, and pruritis. Ascitic fluid analysis revealed neutrophil count > 650 per cubic mm. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario and image of a patient with abdominal distension, jaundice, pruritus, and neutrophil count >650 per mm3, the likely diagnosis is spontaneous bacterial peritonitis.  

Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) is an acute bacterial infection of the ascitic fluid. It is commonly seen in adults in association with liver cirrhosis. The pathogens involved are Escherichia coli, streptococci, enterococci, and pneumococci. 

In a patient with ascites, SBP presents with fever, and acute abdominal pain. On examination, tachycardia, tachypnea, and signs of peritonitis are seen. Hepatic encephalopathy and gastrointestinal bleeding may also occur. 

Diagnosis is by paracentesis, and an ascitic fluid neutrophil count of >250/mm3 is suggestive of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis. Ascitic fluid culture may reveal pathogenic organisms.

Management is mainly by third-generation cephalosporins such as cefotaxime. Albumin infusion can be given as it decreases the risk of renal failure and improves patient survival. Early diagnosis and treatment improve the prognosis.

Other options:

Option B: Malignant ascites occurs as a complication of intra-abdominal and extra-abdominal malignancies. Patients can present with increasing abdominal girth, generalized abdominal pain, and shortness of breath. Weight loss may be more common. Ascitic fluid analysis reveals a milky or bloody appearance with elevated levels of tumor markers and VEGF (vascular endothelial growth factor). Treatment is by paracentesis and peritoneovenous shunt.

Option C: Ascites is often seen in patients with tubercular peritonitis. Multiple tubercles are seen on the peritoneum. Ascitic fluid analysis reveals a straw-colored fluid with a white blood cell count >500 mm3. Laparoscopy and peritoneal biopsy may be helpful in diagnosis. Management is by supportive and anti-tubercular therapy.  

Option D: Intestinal obstruction can present as pain, abdominal distension, vomiting, and absolute constipation. Abdominal radiographs taken in a supine position are useful in diagnosis. Abdominal radiograph in erect posture shows fluid levels. Management is mainly by insertion of a nasogastric tube, replacement of fluid and electrolytes, and surgery.

questions.text: A patient presented with weight loss and easy fatiguability.  A bone marrow aspirate is shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and peripheral smear showing faggot cells are suggestive of acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

AML is a hematopoietic progenitor malignancy that causes immature myeloblast accumulation in the bone marrow. Occupational exposure to benzene leads to epoxide formation which in turn predisposes to the development of AML. Clinically, the patients present with symptoms resulting due to pancytopenia (anemia, neutropenia, thrombocytopenia). There is generalised fatigue, bone pain, bleeding tendencies and an increased risk of recurrent infections. Hemorrhagic complications such as disseminated intravascular coagulation may be seen more commonly in a subtype of AML, acute promyelocytic leukemia.

Other distinctive features of AML include

  • Bone marrow/peripheral smear shows a large, uniform population of cells (myeloblasts) with prominent nucleoli (yellow arrow). It shows the presence of primary cytoplasmic granules
  • Auer rods: needle-shaped azurophilic intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies formed by the fusion of lysosomes. (black arrow)
  • Multiple Auer rods clustered together within a single cell resembling a bundle of sticks known as faggot cells (seen in peripheral smear). This is characteristic of acute promyelocytic leukemia (AML M3) or AML associated with PML-RARɑ fusion gene or t(15;17). Other cytogenetic abnormalities, seen in AML are t(8;21) and inversion 16. 

For acute myeloblastic leukemia (AML) diagnosis, the blast cell count should be ≥20% in the peripheral blood or bone marrow

Other options:

Option A- Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) arises from immature B (pre-B) or T (pre-T) cells called lymphoblasts. Immunohistochemistry for terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT) is positive in pre-B and pre-T lymphoblasts. Peripheral smear shows lymphoblasts that have condensed chromatin, less conspicuous nucleoli, and smaller amounts of cytoplasm which lacks granules as shown below.

Option B- Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia is associated with the deletions of 13q, 11q, 17q, and trisomy 12q. Lymph nodes are diffusely effaced by small lymphocytes with proliferation centres. The image shows small round lymphocytes and smudge cells seen in CLL.

Option D- Chronic myeloid leukemia is characterised by the presence of a Philadelphia chromosome resulting from reciprocal translocation t(9;22) forming the BCR-ABL fusion gene. They have a hypercellular marrow due to a massively increased number of maturing granulocytic precursors. The image below shows peripheral smear findings of CML with neutrophils, myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and band cells.

Related Pearl: WHO classification of Acute Myeloid Leukemia

The WHO system divides acute myeloid leukemia (AML) into several groups:

AML with certain genetic abnormalities (gene or chromosome changes)

  • AML with a translocation between chromosomes 8 and 21 [t(8;21)]
  • AML with a translocation or inversion in chromosome 16 [t(16;16) or inv(16)]
  • APL with the PML-RARA fusion gene
  • AML with a translocation between chromosomes 9 and 11 [t(9;11)]
  • AML with a translocation between chromosomes 6 and 9 [t(6:9)]
  • AML with a translocation or inversion in chromosome 3 [t(3;3) or inv(3)]
  • AML (megakaryoblastic) with a translocation between chromosomes 1 and 22 [t(1:22)]
  • AML with the BCR-ABL1 (BCR-ABL) fusion gene*
  • AML with mutated NPM1 gene
  • AML with biallelic mutations of the CEBPA gene (that is, mutations in both copies of the gene)
  • AML with mutated RUNX1 gene*

*This is still a "provisional entity," meaning it is not yet clear if there's enough evidence that it is a unique group.

AML with myelodysplasia-related changes

AML related to previous chemotherapy or radiation

AML not otherwise specified (This includes cases of AML that do not fall into one of the above groups and is similar to the FAB classification.)

  • AML with minimal differentiation (FAB M0)
  • AML without maturation (FAB M1)
  • AML with maturation (FAB M2)
  • Acute myelomonocytic leukemia (FAB M4)
  • Acute monoblastic/monocytic leukemia (FAB M5)
  • Pure erythroid leukemia (FAB M6)
  • Acute megakaryoblastic leukemia (FAB M7)
  • Acute basophilic leukemia
  • Acute panmyelosis with fibrosis

Myeloid sarcoma (also known as granulocytic sarcoma or chloroma)

Myeloid proliferations related to Down syndrome

Undifferentiated and biphenotypic acute leukemias are not strictly AML, but are leukemias that have both lymphocytic and myeloid features. They are sometimes called mixed phenotype acute leukemias (MPALs).

questions.text: If histopathological examination of a 2-day-old forearm laceration is done, which of the following would be seen?
questions.solution:
Neutrophil peak is seen on day 2 of the inflammatory phase of wound healing.

Wound healing has three phases: The inflammatory phase, proliferative phase, and maturation phase. The inflammatory phase lasts 2-3 days.

Wound healing has 3 phases. The first phase is marked by hemostasis and inflammation. Polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMN)s are the first infiltrating cells to enter the wound site, peaking at 24 to 48 hours. The second population of inflammatory cells that invade the wound are macrophages which peak in 48-96 hours. T lymphocytes routinely invade the wound and peak at about 1-week postinjury and truly bridge the transition from the inflammatory to the proliferative phase of healing.

The second phase of proliferation roughly spans days 4-12 days. Fibroblasts and endothelial cells are the last cell populations to infiltrate the healing wound. The strongest chemotactic factor for fibroblasts is PDGF (Platelet-derived growth factor).

The third phase is characterized by the maturation and remodeling of the scar which involves reorganization of previously synthesized collagen.

The phases of wound healing and the levels of infiltrating cells are represented in the graph below.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presented with chronic projectile vomiting and weight loss. What is the expected metabolic abnormality to be seen here?

choices.text: Hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hyponatremia
Hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hypernatremia
Hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hypercalcemia
Hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic acidosis with hyponatremia

questions.solution:
The expected metabolic abnormality to be seen in this patient is hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hyponatremia.

The persistent vomiting results in these abnormalities along with paradoxical aciduria. 

  • Persistent vomiting results in loss of hydrochloric acid leading to the development of metabolic alkalosis (due to loss of H+) and hypochloremia (due to loss of Cl-).
  • Kidneys try to compensate for alkalosis by secreting Na+ and HCO3- causing hyponatremia. However, loss of sodium stimulates the secretion of aldosterone through the RAAS pathway.
  • The aldosterone causes active reabsorption of sodium in exchange for K+ and H+ ions.
  • Loss of potassium ions leads to the development of hypokalemia.
  • Loss of H+ ions in urine lowers the urinary pH resulting in aciduria. It is called paradoxical aciduria since the body initially loses H+ ions due to the loss of HCl, and instead of compensating for that loss, the body is losing more H+ ions through urine.

Related Pearl: Causes of Acid-Base Disorders

Metabolic acidosis

Metabolic alkalosis

Respiratory acidosis

Respiratory alkalosis

Ketoacidosis

Lactic acidosis

Chronic renal failure

Salicylate intoxication

Methanol/formaldehyde intoxication

Ethylene glycol intoxication

Diarrhoea

Renal tubular acidosis

Vomiting

Hyperaldosteronism

Loop or thiazide diuretics

Opiates, sedatives, anesthesia

Guillain- Barre syndrome, Polio, ALS, multiple sclerosis

Airway obstruction

Adult respiratory distress syndrome, COPD

Pneumonia, pulmonary embolism

High altitude

Psychogenic

questions.text: Which of the following laryngeal rehabilitation methods is depicted in the given image?
questions.solution:
The given image represents oesophageal speech

Vocal rehabilitation after total laryngectomy is broadly divided into:

  • Esophageal speech
  • Artificial larynx
  • Tracheo-oesophageal speech         

Oesophageal Speech-  the patient is taught to swallow air and hold it in the upper oesophagus and then slowly eject it from the oesophagus into the pharynx. The patient can speak 6-10 words before re-swallowing air. The voice is rough but loud and understandable.

Other options:

Options A & C: Electrolarynx and transoral pneumatic devices are methods of artificial larynx.

Option D: Tracheo-Oesophageal Speech- Here the air is diverted from the trachea to the oesophagus or hypopharynx by the creation of a skin-lined fistula or by the placement of a prosthesis. The vibrating column of air entering the pharynx is then modulated into speech. The prostheses used are Blom-Singer and Panje devices. They have inbuilt valves which work only in one direction thus preventing problems of aspiration.

questions.text: Identify the obstetric device given in the image below.
questions.solution:
The obstetric device given in the image above is of cervidil vaginal insert.

Cervidil vaginal insert is a thin, flat, rectangular polymeric wafer held within a small, white mesh polyester sac. It contains 10 mg of dinoprostone (PGE2) released at a rate of 0.3 mg/hour. The sac has a long attached tail to allow easy removal from the vagina.

Following insertion, the woman should remain recumbent for at least 2 hours. The insert is removed after 12 hours or with labour onset and at least 30 minutes before the administration of oxytocin. It is used for cervical ripening before induction. A possible side effect of dinoprostone is uterine tachysystole.

Other options :

Option A: The Lippes Loop is a first-generation intrauterine device (IUD) available in four sizes- A, B, C, and D. It is an S-shaped device, typically made of polyethene, with a tail made of fine nylon that extends into the vagina after insertion. While larger loops tend to have higher removal rates due to side effects, they offer stronger anti-fertility effects. Larger loops are generally recommended for multiparous women. The device contains a small amount of barium sulfate, which enables X-ray visualization.

The image of the Lippes loop is given below.

Option C: Misoprostol is a methyl ester of PGE1, used in the induction of labour and the management of postpartum haemorrhage. Side effects include fever, tachysystole (hyperstimulation), fetal heart rate changes and meconium passage. It should not be used for cases with previous cesarean birth because the risk of uterine rupture is high.

Option D: Mirena is a third-generation intrauterine contraceptive device, containing 52mg of levonorgestrel. Its approved life span is 5 years. Apart from contraception, it is used for the treatment of menorrhagia, endometrial hyperplasia without atypia, and dysmenorrhea secondary to endometriosis and adenomyosis.

The image of Mirena is given below.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl was brought by her mother with complaints of abnormal gait. On examination, the child had a waddling gait and exaggerated lumbar lordosis. The mother gives a history of breech delivery and remembers that the pediatrician diagnosed a hip condition at that time, but it was ignored by the family. What should be the management at this stage?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of developmental or congenital dysplasia of the hip (DDH). In a child of age 18-36 months (2 years old), open reduction with osteotomy is done.

This osteotomy can be either femoral or pelvic or both. 

Pelvic osteotomies are of varieties as follows:

  • Salter's
  • Pemberton
  • Chiari
  • Steel
  • Shelf operations

Developmental dysplasia of the hip or congenital dysplasia of the hip is characterized by spontaneous dislocation of the hip joint before, during, or shortly after birth.

Risk factors for DDH include:

  • Sex of the baby- females are more susceptible to DDH due to the action of maternal relaxin on the fetal joints in-utero predisposing it to dislocation. It is 3-5 times more common in females.
  • Intrauterine positioning- breech position is associated with a higher incidence of DDH
  • Genetic predisposition- DDH is more common in children of parents who had DDH themselves.
  • First born child.

Examination of the developmental dysplasia of the hip:

1) Newborn to 3 months of age. Tests to check instability of the hip:

  • Asymmetrical skin creases in the inguinal, gluteal, and thigh regions.
  • Ortolani test: To perform this test, the infant is supine, with the hip and knee flexed. With the thumb placed over the medial thigh and the index finger on the greater trochanter, the hip is gently abducted. This reduces the femoral head into the acetabulum producing a palpable "clunk".
  • Barlow test: This test is done within 2–3 days of birth. To perform this test, the infant is supine with the knees fully flexed and the hip at 90° of flexion. Gentle adduction results in a posterior subluxation or dislocation of an easily dislocatable femoral head, producing a palpable "clunk".

2) At 3-6 months of age:

  • Galeazzi's test 
  • Marked asymmetry of the inguinal, gluteal, thigh, or popliteal folds.
  • Decreased abduction on the affected side.

3) In children of walking age:

  • Trendelenburg gait
  • Positive Trendelenburg sign
  • Limb-length discrepancy

Treatment of DDH includes early closed reduction with splinting or casts. If closed reduction cannot be achieved in long-standing dislocations, an open reduction may become necessary.

Related Pearl: Age wise management of DDH

AGE OF THE PATIENT                 MANAGEMENT
Less than 6 months Closed reduction with Pavlik harness or von Rosen splint
6-18 months Closed or open reduction followed by hip spica after reduction
18-36 months Open reduction with femoral osteotomy and pelvic osteotomy (Salter's osteotomy, Pemberton osteotomy, Steel osteotomy)
3-8 year Open reduction with femoral shortening and pelvic osteotomy 
8-18 year

Open procedure with femoral shortening with pelvic osteotomy or total hip replacement

questions.text: Which among the following is not a feature of pulmonary arterial hypertension?

choices.text: Mean pulmonary arterial pressure >20 mm Hg
Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure ≤ 25 mm Hg

questions.solution:
Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) ≤ 15 mm Hg is a feature of pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH).

The table below shows the hemodynamic classification of pulmonary hypertension. PAH belongs to WHO group 1.

Related Pearl: Classification of Pulmonary Hypertension & its Causes

Based on underlying mechanisms, the World Health Organization has classified pulmonary hypertension into five groups.

Classification

questions.text: An elderly patient is brought to the emergency in a comatose state. Examination reveals serum glucose levels of 500 mg/dL, arterial pH of 7.33, elevated plasma ketones, and normal serum potassium levels. What should be added to the saline in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, the patient has diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). The patient needs to be started on IV fluids and insulin at a dose of 0.1 unit per kg. 

Diabetic ketoacidosis is an acute complication of type 1 diabetes mellitus. The symptoms include nausea, vomiting, and severe abdominal pain.

Signs:

  • Kussmaul breathing
  • Fruity odor on the patient’s breath
  • Tachycardia
  • Dehydration
  • Hypotension

Blood parameters:

  • Hyperglycemia – 250 – 600 mg%
  • Pseudohyponatremia- There is 1.6-mmol/L reduction in serum sodium level for each 5.6-mmol/L rise in the serum glucose level.
  • Overall total-body K+ deficit, however, the serum K+ at presentation may be mildly elevated, secondary to the acidosis
  • Osmolality– 300–320 mOsm/kg
  • Plasma ketones– Positive
  • Metabolic acidosis– Increased anion gap
  • Serum bicarbonate <15 meq/L– Best initial investigation
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Hyperamylasemia

Management of DKA

  • Admit to hospital assess for serum electrolytes and acid-base status
  • Replace fluids- 2-3 liters (10-20 mL/kg/hr) of normal saline should be administered over 1-3 hours. Subsequently 0.45% saline at 250-500 mL/hr. It can be changed to 5% glucose and 0.45% saline at 150–250 mL/h when plasma glucose reaches 250 mg/dL.
  • Administer IV short-acting insulin regular insulin. 0.1 units/kg of insulin should be administered immediately as a bolus dose. This is followed by an intravenous infusion of 0.1 units/kg. Serum potassium levels should be checked before initiating insulin. If the levels are high, then it has to be corrected and then insulin should be started.
  • The above measures should be continued until the serum glucose levels reach 150–200 mg/dL, and acidosis is resolved. Insulin infusion may be decreased to 0.02–0.1 units/kg per hour.
  • Long-acting insulin can be started when the patient starts eating.

The chart shows the management algorithm for DKA.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with a right convergent squint of 6 months duration. The appropriate management would be ______.

choices.text: Immediate surgical correction followed by amblyopia therapy
Proper refractive correction, amblyopia therapy followed by surgical correction
Prescription of spectacles and defer surgery until 5 years
Botulinum toxin injection followed by occlusion therapy

questions.solution:
The appropriate management, in this case, would be proper refractive correction, amblyopia therapy followed by surgical correction.

Accommodative esotropia (convergent squint) is a common type of squint due to the overaction of convergence associated with accommodation. This overaction is usually to overcome a hyperopic refractive error. It presents at around 2 to 3 years of age.

Types of accommodative esotropia include:

  • The refractive type is associated with high hypermetropia (+4 to +7 D) and is fully correctable by spectacles.
  • The non-refractive type occurs independent of refractive errors and a small increase in accommodation is accompanied by a dis­proportionately large increase in convergence. The abnormal accommodative convergence/accommodation (AC/A) ratio is fully corrected by bifocal glasses.

The algorithm for the management of accommodative squint is as follows:

  • R: Refractive correction: Glasses/Miotics.
  • O: Orthoptics/Occlusion: For amblyopia.
  • O: Operative correction: For non-accommodative component.
  • P: Prism correction: For the remaining error.

Image: Accommodative esotropia with and without correction

Related Pearl: Classification of Strabismus

  • Pseudostrabismus—Apparent squint
    • Pseudo esotropia
    • Pseduo exotropia
  • Heterophoria—Latent squint
    • Esophoria: Convergent
    • Exophoria: Divergent
    • Hyperphoria: Deviation upwards
    • Hypophoria: Deviation downwards
    • Cyclophoria: Rotation around AP axis
  • Heterotropia—Manifest squint
  • Concomitant
    • Amount of deviation remains constant in all directions of gaze.
    • Esotropia: Convergent
      • Infantile
      • Accommodative
      • Sensory
      • Consecutive
    • Exotropia: Divergent
      • Congenital
      • Primary
      • Secondary: Sensory deprived
      • Consecutive
    • Hypertropia: Vertical squint
  • Incomitant
    • Amount of deviation varies in different directions of gaze
      • Paralytic squint
      • Restrictive squint
      • A and V pattern heterotropia

questions.text: A male patient came with a history of unprotected sexual intercourse around 20 years ago. Now, he complains of neurological symptoms and visual disturbances. Which of the following will be seen on exposure of his pupils to light?

choices.text: Pupils react but do not accommodate.
Pupils accommodate but do not react.

questions.solution:
The patient most likely has acquired syphilis due to unprotected sex and has developed the complication of neurosyphilis (neurological and visual disturbances); therefore, he will show features of an Argyll Robertson pupil, where his pupils accommodate but do not react to light.

Argyll Robertson pupil (ARP) is a feature of neurosyphilis that includes general paresis and tabes dorsalis. It results from damage to the relay paths in the tectum between the afferent and efferent tracts that interrupt pupillary light reflex. But the ventral pathway of the pupillary near reflex is spared resulting in an intact accommodation reflex. 

Clinical features in the eyes include an intact accommodation reflex i.e eyes converge and constrict on seeing a near object. But absent light reflex as they do not constrict when exposed to bright light (i.e., they do not react to light). This is also known as light-near dissociation. These patients also have bilateral small irregular pupils. Optic atrophy is another common feature of tabes. 

Treatment of neurosyphilis is with aqueous crystalline penicillin G for 10–14 days or aqueous procaine penicillin G plus oral probenecid, both for 10–14 days. Patients who have penicillin allergy are desensitized and then treated with penicillin.

Related Pearl: Sympathetic and parasympathetic nerve supply to iris muscles

  • Dilator pupillae/radial muscle of iris: Sympathetic postganglionic nerves from cervical ganglion.
  • Constrictor pupillae/circular muscle of iris: Parasympathetic postganglionic nerves from ciliary ganglion (Edinger Westphal nucleus).

questions.text: A 22-year-old pregnant woman of 13 weeks gestation age informs about accidental exposure to radiation during chest X-ray at 7 weeks of gestation. What should be the next step advised to her?
questions.solution:
In this clinical case, a 22-year-old pregnant woman at 13 weeks of gestation reports accidental radiation exposure during a chest X-ray at 7 weeks of gestation and should be advised to continue the pregnancy.

The dose to the fetus during the declared term of pregnancy should be less than 1 mSv. This is equivalent to about 2 mSv to the surface of the abdomen of the mother. 

In chest X-ray PA view, the absorbed dose of radiation by the fetus is less than .001sv. Hence, pregnancy can be continued. For fetal doses less than 100mGy, there is no medical justification for terminating a pregnancy because of radiation exposure. According to the CDC, radiation dose between 50 mGy to 100 mGy is regarded as inconclusive in terms of impact on the fetus.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a history of previous cesarean section has been scheduled to undergo elective repeat LSCS 2 days later. What is the ideal time to administer antibiotics to this patient?
questions.solution:
The ideal time to administer antibiotics is within 60 min prior to the start of planned cesarean delivery according to The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists.

1-g dose of cefazolin administration before surgical incision has been shown to lower postoperative infection rates without adverse neonatal effects, as compared with drug administration after umbilical cord clamping.

For emergency delivery, prophylaxis should be given as soon as possible.

questions.text: Which is the drug of choice for controlling BP in severe preeclampsia?
questions.solution:
Labetalol (intra-venous) is the drug of choice for controlling BP in severe pre-eclampsia.

Labetalol is a nonselective β blocker and vascular α blocker that should be avoided in patients with asthma and congestive heart failure due to the bronchoconstriction effect. It is the first-line agent for urgent control of BP in pregnancy. It is effective, has a rapid onset of action, and a good safety profile.

Choice of anti-hypertensives in pregnancy:

  • PIH / pre-eclampsia / severe pre-eclampsia: Labetalol.
  • Acute Hypertension/Hypertension crisis : IV labetalol, Nifedipine, Hydralazine.
  • Chronic Hypertension in Pregnancy: Labetalol > Methyldopa.

Other options: 

Option B: Hydralazine can cause maternal hypotension and fetal distress.

Option C: Nifedipine can cause reflex tachycardia and headache in the mother.

Option D: Methyldopa can cause changes in BP is an indirect action therefore it is less effective in controlling BP.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with fibroid uterus develops acute pain in abdomen with low grade fever and leukocytosis at 28 weeks. The most likely diagnosis is ______
questions.solution:
In the given scenario history of acute pain abdomen with fever and mild leukocytosis in a 28-week pregnant woman is suggestive of red degeneration of fibroid.

Red degeneration is the most common complication of fibroids in pregnancy. It is due to the breakdown of fibroid resulting in ischemia and pain. Key clinical features of this condition are, low-grade fever, tender uterus on palpation, elevated leukocytes and elevated esr.

The diagnosis is confirmed with an ultrasound. It is usually self-limiting and can be managed with non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.

Other options:

Option B: Torsion of subserous pedunculated fibroid presents with severe pain abdomen but fever and leucocytosis are absent.

Option C: Infection is common in submucous and myomatous polyps if they project into the cervical canal or the vagina. An infected polyp can cause blood-stained purulent discharge. Infection is more likely in the postpartum and postabortal states.

Option D: Preterm labour is defined as regular uterine contractions with or without pain (at least one every 10 minutes), dilatation (> 2 cm) and effacement (80%) of the cervix, length of the cervix (measured by TVS) < 2.5 cm and funnelling of the internal os and pelvic pressure, backache and/or vaginal discharge or bleeding.

questions.text: Identify the following instrument.
questions.solution:
The above image shows Tilley’s forceps. It is used for nasal packing, ear dressing, removal of foreign bodies from the nose. It has a box joint.

Other options:

Options A and B: Walsham and Asch’s forceps are used to reduce nasal bone fractures.

Walsham forceps is mainly used to reduce bone fracture.

Asch’s forceps is mainly used to reduce nasal septum.

Option D: Citelli's forceps is used for punching bones and other tissues.

questions.text: The full red arrow head in the below image represents _______
questions.solution:
The full red arrowhead represents the yolk sac. The empty red arrowhead shows the double ring, the outer ring is called decidua parietalis(Option B) and the inner ring is called decidua capsularis(Option C).

The sign is called the double decidua sign and is seen in the first trimester transvaginal sonogram. It is useful to confirm an early intrauterine location for the pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of these steps is followed first for the management of shoulder dystocia after McRoberts maneuver?

choices.text: Flex the legs over the abdomen

questions.solution:
The first step in the management of shoulder dystocia after the MC Roberts manoeuvre is applying gentle suprapubic pressure.

Shoulder dystocia, defined as a head-to-body delivery time >60 seconds, occurs when either the anterior or the posterior (rare) fetal shoulder impacts on the maternal symphysis or the sacral promontory respectively. Risk factors for the development of shoulder dystocia include maternal diabetes mellitus, obesity, post-dated pregnancy, excessive weight gain during pregnancy, etc. 

The correct sequence of shoulder dystocia drill is as follows:

  • Call for help and mobilize labour assistants, anaesthesia, and pediatric doctors.
  • An attempt at traction is tried followed by episiotomy to afford room posteriorly.
  • 1st line of management - Mc Roberts manoeuvre involves flexion and abduction of the thigh(Option C) in conjunction with suprapubic pressure application.
  • 2nd line of management - Woods corkscrew manoeuvre involves rotating the posterior shoulder to 180 degrees in a corkscrew fashion(Option B). Other manoeuvres like Rubin's, Gaskin's (all four's position), Hubbard's, and Barnum's manoeuvres can be attempted too.
  • 3rd line of management - Zavanelli manoeuvre (replacement of the fetal head into the pelvis) followed by cesarean delivery(Option A).
  • The last line of management (Not preferred nowadays) is cleidotomy(fracture of the clavicle of the baby) or symphysiotomy(dividing the pubic symphysis of the mother).

questions.text: A patient underwent the following procedure for the management of portal hypertension. Which of the following is an early complication of this procedure?
questions.solution:
The image shows the transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) procedure with the viatorr device. An early complication of the TIPS procedure is metabolic encephalopathy.

The main indication of TIPS is variceal bleeds not responding to medical or endoscopic treatment and intractable ascites.

The shunts are inserted under local anesthesia, analgesia, and sedation, using fluoroscopic guidance and ultrasonography. A guidewire is inserted via the internal jugular vein and superior vena cava into a hepatic vein and through the hepatic parenchyma into a branch of the portal vein.

The major complication of this technique is the perforation of the liver capsule and the main contraindication to TIPSS is portal vein occlusion.

Portal hypertension is defined by a portal pressure >5 mmHg.

Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) is a treatment option whereby a percutaneous connection is created within the liver, between the portal and systemic circulations, to reduce portal pressure in patients with complications related to portal hypertension.

Complications of TIPS procedure:

  • Intraoperative complications- capsular hemorrhage
  • Early complication- hepatic encephalopathy
  • Late complication- recurrent variceal bleed
  • Delayed complication- total shunt occlusion

Shunts for portal hypertension:

  • Non-selective shunt- bowel and splenic blood is shunted
    • Linton shunt (proximal lienorenal shunt with splenectomy)
    • ECK fistula (portocaval shunt)
    • Mitra shunt (splenorenal shunt)
  • Selective shunt- only splenic blood is shunted
    • Warren shunt (distal lienorenal shunt)
    • Inokuchi shunt 

Related Pearl: Classification of Portal Hypertension

  • Prehepatic
    • Portal vein thrombosis
    • Splenic vein thrombosis
    • Massive splenomegaly (Banti's syndrome)
  • Hepatic
    • Presinusoidal
      • Schistosomiasis
      • Congenital hepatic fibrosis
    • Sinusoidal
      • Cirrhosis of Liver (Most Common)
      • Alcoholic hepatitis
    • Postsinusoidal
      • Hepatic sinusoidal obstruction (venoocclusive syndrome)
  • Posthepatic
    • Budd-Chiari syndrome
    • Inferior vena caval webs
    • Cardiac causes
      • Restrictive cardiomyopathy
      • Constrictive pericarditis
      • Severe congestive heart failure

questions.text:
The most common cause of Cushing's disease in a 60-year-old male is ______

ACTH - Adrenocorticotropic hormone
questions.solution:
The most common cause of Cushing's disease in a 60-year-old male is pituitary microadenoma.

Cortisol production is increased by adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) released from the pituitary gland in the brain. Hypercortisolemia (cortisol overproduction) causes Cushing syndrome, most often when a pituitary adenoma (a benign tumor) produces an excess of ACTH, resulting in Cushing's disease. The increased ACTH causes increased cortisol production, about three times more than the normal level.

The illustration given below shows the clinical features of Cushing syndrome.

Administration of large doses of dexamethasone can be used to differentiate between ACTH-dependent and ACTH-independent Cushing’s syndrome.

The illustration given below shows the diagnostic algorithm to determine the cause of Cushing syndrome.

In normal physiologic states, the ACTH levels are higher in the early morning as compared to the rest of the day. However, they are not as high as those in Cushing's disease.

Related Pearl: Causes of Cushing's Syndrome

Iatrogenic (Most common cause)

  • Exogenous administration of glucocorticoids

Endogenous Causes

  • ACTH Dependent – (90 % of endogenous causes)
  • Cushing’s disease – ACTH-producing pituitary adenoma
  • Ectopic ACTH syndrome – Due to ACTH secretion by
  • Bronchial or pancreatic carcinoid tumors
  • Small-cell lung cancer
  • Medullary thyroid carcinoma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • ACTH Independent – (10% )
  • Adrenocortical adenoma
  • Adrenocortical carcinoma

Rare causes

  • Macronodular adrenal hyperplasia
  • Primary pigmented nodular adrenal disease
  • McCune – Albright syndrome

Related Pearl: Screening/Confirmatory Test for Diagnosing Cushing's Syndrome

  • 24-h urinary free cortisol excretion increased above normal (3x)
  • Dexamethasone overnight test
    • Plasma cortisol >50 nmol/L at 8–9 a.m. after 1 mg dexamethasone at 11 p.m.
  • Midnight plasma cortisol >130 nmol/L
  • Midnight salivary cortisol >5 nmol/L
  • Low dose Dexamethasone test – Best initial test
    • Plasma cortisol >50 nmol/L after 0.5 mg dexamethasone q6h for 2 days

If a number of these tests are positive then a diagnosis of Cushing’s syndrome is confirmed.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a history of falling off his bicycle. He complains of severe pain around his ankle. Which of the following findings is seen in this CT scan?
questions.solution:
The given CT scan of the ankle shows a Salter-Harris type II epiphyseal fracture, in which there is involvement of the growth plate (physis) and a triangular metaphyseal bone fragment, with sparing of the epiphysis. This triangular metaphyseal fragment is known as the Thurston Holland sign. 

Salter-Harris classified epiphyseal injuries into 5 types. Type 2 epiphyseal fractures are the most common type of epiphyseal injury in patients over 10 years of age.

Other options:

Option A: Trethowan's sign is seen in slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE). It is when Klein's line does not intersect the lateral part of the superior femoral epiphysis on an AP radiograph of the pelvis but passes superior to it.

Option B: Terry Thomas sign is seen in patients with scapholunate instability which denotes the increased gap between the scaphoid and the lunate.

Option D: The teardrop sign is seen in orbital floor fractures and is also known as a blow-out fracture due to the herniation of orbital contents into the maxillary antrum.

Related Pearl: Types of Salter–Harris fractures- Mnemonic

There are nine types of Salter-Harris fractures. Among these, types I to V are more common.

The mnemonic "SALTER" can be used to help remember the first five types.

TYPE  MNEMONIC DESCRIPTION
Type I S = Slip/straight across Transverse fracture through the growth plate
Type II A = Away The fracture lies away from the joint. A fracture through the growth plate and the metaphysis, sparing the epiphysis
Type III L = Lower The fracture is below the physis in the epiphysis.
Type IV TE = Through Everything  A fracture through all three elements of the bone, the growth plate, metaphysis, and epiphysis
Type V R = Rammed (crushed)  A compression fracture of the growth plate

Rarer types VI to IX have been added subsequently.

  • Type VI - Injury to the perichondral structures
  • Type VII - Isolated injury to the epiphyseal plate
  • Type VIII - Isolated injury to the metaphysis, with a potential injury related to endochondral ossification
  • Type IX - Injury to the periosteum that may interfere with membranous growth

questions.text: A male patient is brought into the emergency after a road traffic accident in which he has sustained injuries on the face. You note excessive mobility of the maxilla but no mobility of the nose. A CT scan reveals a fracture line passing through the lower part of the nasal septum, maxillary antrum, and pterygoid plates. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Le-Fort I fracture of the maxilla. 

Le Fort Type 1 fractures generally occur on the horizontal plane at the level of the nose base. It is caused due to downward directed force onto the lower part of the maxillary rim.

It involves the three walls of the maxillary sinus as well as the pterygoid processes, extending around the maxillary antrum, nasal septum, and pterygoid plate. This leads to the separation of the palate and face. There is no involvement of the glabella or zygoma in this case. 

Clinically, patients present with swollen upper lip, anterior open bite malocclusion, maxillary buccal vestibule, palate ecchymosis, and mobility of the maxilla.

Diagnosis is made with X-rays (Water's view, posteroanterior view, and lateral view) and CT scan. They help to understand the full extent of injuries. 

Treatment requires fixation of the maxillary fractures which can be achieved by interdental wiring, and intermaxillary wiring using arch bars. Open reduction and interosseous wiring may be required in zygomatic fractures.

Related Pearl: Le-Fort's classification of Maxillary Fracture

Le-Fort I is a transverse fracture of the maxilla
  • Fracture line passes through the lower part of nasal septum, maxillary antra and the pterygoid plates
  • It separates palate from the rest of the face leading to floating teeth or palate
  • Also called Guerin’s fracture. 
Le-Fort II is a pyramidal fracture
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, lacrimal bone, floor of the orbit, upper part of the maxillary sinus and pterygoid plates
  • X-ray or CT appears like hanging maxilla
  • It is associated with CSF rhinorrhea.
Le-Fort III is craniofacial dysjunction i.e., facial skeleton completely disconnected from its cranial attachment
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, ethmo-frontal junction, superior orbital fissure, lateral wall of the orbit, fronto-zygomatic and temporo-zygomatic sutures and the upper part of pterygoid plates
  • It is also associated with CSF rhinorrhea.

questions.text: A 48-year-old lady was started on an ocular medication that she was instructed to take daily. She develops redness of the eye. Examination reveals a color change of the iris, and orbital fat atrophy. Which of the following medications was she likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history suggests the lady was started on latanoprost.

Latanoprost is a PGF 2 alpha analogue that acts by increasing the uveoscleral outflow and thereby lowers the intraocular pressure. It's side effects include increased and irreversible iris pigmentation, eyelash thickening, and conjunctival hyperemia. 

Prostaglandin analogues such as latanoprost, travoprost, bimatoprost, tafluprost, and unoprostone are used as first-line medications in glaucoma. They reduce the intraocular pressure by increasing the uveoscleral outflow of aqueous humor.

Drug Side Effects
Latanoprost

Allergic conjunctival hyperemia, permanent increase in iris pigmentation, orbital fat atrophy.

Also, once-daily dosing can cause lash growth. 
Timolol  Exacerbation of asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, bradycardia, depression, impotence 
Scopolamine Photosensitivity, blurred vision 
Pilocarpine Corneal edema, miosis, induced myopia, decreased vision, brow ache, retinal detachment 

Other options :

Option A: Timolol is a topical non-selective beta-blocker used in glaucoma. It decreases the IOP by reducing the aqueous humor production through blockade of the β-receptors on the ciliary epithelium. Ocular adverse effects such as allergy and punctate keratitis can be seen. Systemic side effects like bradycardia and bronchospasm may be seen due to absorption through the nasolacrimal duct.

Option B: Pilocarpine is a miotic agent used in glaucoma. Local adverse effects such as miosis and induced myopia can be seen. Systemic symptoms such as bronchospasm and bradycardia may be rarely seen.

Option D: Scopolamine indirectly exerts spasmolytic activity through its antimuscarinic action. It is not preferred due to its adverse effects, such as drowsiness, dryness, and blurred vision.

questions.text: Identify the test shown below.
questions.solution:
The test in the given image is called tonometry.

The above image is of the dynamic contour tonometer such as the Pascal tonometer. The dynamic contour tonometer(Pascal) offers a non-invasive and direct method of intraocular pressure (IOP) measurement with an additional measurement of the ocular pulse amplitude. This type of tonometer is unaffected by the corneal thickness and it is the tonometer of choice in post-Lasik patients.

Other options :

Option A: Pachymetry is used to measure the corneal thickness. 
The below image is of pachymetry.

Option C: Auto Refractotemetry is a computerized refractometer that is used to find out the error of refraction. This gives rapid information about the kind of refractive error in terms of sphere, cylinder with axis and inter pupillary distance.

Option D: A-scan ultrasonography is used to determine the axial length of the eyeball for IOL power calculation, anterior chamber depth, and thickness of intraocular mass.

questions.text: Waldeyer’s group of lymph nodes do not include
questions.solution:
The submandibular group of lymph nodes is not included as a part of Waldeyer’s ring.

Scattered throughout the pharynx in its subepithelial layer is the lymphoid tissue which is aggregated at places to form masses, collectively called Waldeyer’s ring.

The masses are:

  • Nasopharyngeal tonsil or the adenoids
  • Palatine tonsils or simply the tonsils
  • Lingual tonsil
  • Tubal tonsils (in fossa of Rosenmüller)
  • Lateral pharyngeal bands
  • Nodules (in the posterior pharyngeal wall)

questions.text:
A middle-aged woman presented with dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, and infertility. On examination, you note tender nodularity of the uterosacral ligaments. The diagnosis is___

PID-Pelvic inflammatory disease
questions.solution:
The given clinical case of a middle-aged woman presenting with dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, and infertility, showing tender nodularity of the uterosacral ligaments (cobblestone appearance) on examination is suggestive of endometriosis.

Endometriosis is defined by the presence of ectopic endometrial tissue at a site outside of the uterus. It is a benign condition but it is locally invasive. Some common sites of endometriosis are ovaries, pelvic peritoneum, pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligaments, rectovaginal septum, and sigmoid colon. Endometriosis in the ovaries is called endometrioma. Chocolate cysts of the ovaries represent the most important manifestation of endometriosis.

Patients with endometriosis mainly present with progressively increasing secondary dysmenorrhea, menorrhagia, infertility, dyspareunia, and chronic pelvic pain. MRI is the diagnostic tool, it shows the characteristic hyperintensity on T1 weighted images and hypointensity on T2 weighted images. Laparoscopy confirms the diagnosis.

Medical management is with gestrinone, combined OCPs, Mirena IUCDs, and Aromatase inhibitors like letrozole. Therapeutic procedures include aspiration of peritoneal fluid from the cul-de-sac, destruction of endometriotic lesions <3cm with diathermy, Nd-YAG laser, or CO2 vaporization, laparoscopic breaking of adhesions and Laser uterosacral nerve ablation (LUNA) is done for pelvic pain.

Other options :

Option A: PID (Pelvic inflammatory disease) is the infection of the female upper genital tract involving the fallopian tubes (salpingitis), ovaries (oophoritis), and uterus (endometritis). The most common causes of PID in sexually active young females are gonococci and chlamydia. If untreated, complications include infertility, chronic pelvic pain, ectopic pregnancy, and hydrosalpinx. 

Option C:  Pelvic tuberculosis is almost always secondary to a primary focus elsewhere. The leading presenting complaints include infertility, abdominal pain, vaginal discharge, and suspicion of neoplasm.

Option D: Most women with leiomyomas are asymptomatic, but those affected may experience bleeding, pain, pressure, or infertility. Symptom risk increases with the size and number of myomas. 

Related Pearl: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

  • Pelvic endometriosis: Pelvic peritoneum, the pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligament.
  • Rectovaginal endometriosis.
  • Ovarian endometriosis.
  • Chocolate cyst of the ovary.
  • Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.
  • Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

  • Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.
  • Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.
  • Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).
    • Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.
    • Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy comes with complaints of hoarseness of voice. Endoscopy shows multiple growths on his vocal cords which are all less than 1cm in diameter. How should he be managed?
questions.solution:
This child with multiple growths on his vocal cords most likely has juvenile laryngeal papillomatosis. These lesions in a pre-pubescent boy with no complications should be managed expectantly and closely followed up till the child reaches puberty.

Laryngeal papillomatosis or juvenile papillomatosis is the most common benign neoplasm of the larynx in children. It is caused by HPV 6 and 11. It involves supraglottic and glottic regions of the larynx. Adult-onset laryngeal papillomatosis involves the anterior part of the vocal cords.

It usually occurs between the ages 3–5 years, but less commonly can also occur in men aged between 30-50 years. Clinical features include hoarseness or aphonia and respiratory difficulty. The recurrence rate is high but they rarely transform to SCC.

Diagnosis is confirmed by direct laryngoscopy and biopsy. 

Usually, these lesions resolve by puberty. If they occur on the free edge of the vocal cord they can be susceptible to trauma and bleeds. But otherwise, patients are managed conservatively unless there is significant lifestyle impairment. Treatment consists of micro laryngoscopy, CO2 laser excision, and topical cidofovir.

questions.text: You are an intern posted in the labor room assisting the delivery of a primigravida at 38 weeks in labor.  The obstetrician planned for a ventuse delivery because of maternal exhaustion.  She asked you to place the ventuse cup over the flexion point at the fetal scalp.  You locate the flexion point on______

choices.text: Sagittal suture 3 cm in front of posterior fontanelle
Sagittal suture 3 cm behind of anterior  fontanelle
Coronal suture 6 cm away from posterior fontanelle
Coronal suture 6 cm away from anterior fontanelle

questions.solution:
An important step in vacuum extraction is proper cup placement over the flexion point, which is a point on the sagittal suture that lies 3 cm in front of the posterior fontanelle.

Advantages of correct positioning of the cup in vacuum extraction:

  • Maximum traction.
  • Minimum cup detachment.
  • Twisting of the fetal head is avoided.
  • The smallest head diameter is delivered through the pelvic outlet.
  • The success rate is improved.
  • Fetal scalp injury rates are lowered.
  • Perineal trauma is reduced because the smallest fetal head diameter distends the vulva

questions.text: A G2P1L1 woman at 33 weeks of gestation presents with complaints of excessive fatigue and palpitations. On examination, severe pallor and pedal edema are present with an oxygen saturation of 89%. Her hemoglobin is 5.9 g/dL. Which among the following is the best treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
The best treatment option for this patient is packed cell transfusion.

The treatment of choice for anemia with hemoglobin between 5-7 g/dL at < 34 weeks period of gestation with hypoxia and an impending sign of heart failure like pedal edema is packed cell transfusion. Only packed cell transfusions are carried out and about 80 mL-100 mL of blood is infused at a time and repeated only after 24 hours. 

The following precautions are taken prior to blood transfusions:

  • Administration of antihistaminics intramuscularly
  • Administration of diuretics intramuscularly at least 2 hours prior to transfusion to produce negative fluid balance
  • Adjustment of the drip rate to 10 drops/minute
  • Observation of the pulse, respiration, and basal lung crepitations. 

The complications of blood transfusions include premature labor, increased chances of worsening cardiac failure, and transfusion reactions.

Following are the RCOG guidelines for initiating blood transfusion during pregnancy:

  • Antepartum period
    1. Pregnancy < 34 weeks:
      1. Hb <5 g/dL with or without signs of cardiac failure or hypoxia
      2. Hb 5-7 g/dL – in presence of impending heart failure
    2. Pregnancy > 34 weeks:
      1. Hb <7 g/dL even without signs of cardiac failure or hypoxia
      2. Severe anemia with decompensation
    3. Anemia not due to hematinic deficiency:
      1. Hemoglobinopathy or bone marrow failure syndromes
      2. Consult hematologist
    4. Acute hemorrhage:
      1. Always indicated if Hb <6 g/dL
      2. If the patient becomes hemodynamically unstable due to ongoing hemorrhage
  • Intrapartum period
    1. Hb <7 g/dL 
    2. The decision of blood transfusion depends on medical history or symptoms
  • Postpartum period
    1. Hb <7g%
    2. Anemia with signs of shock/acute hemorrhage with signs of hemodynamic instability.

Other options given are parenteral formulations of iron therapy that are not indicated according to the criteria given above. Parenteral iron therapy is indicated in the following conditions:

  •  Contraindications of oral therapy such as severe gastrointestinal side effects of taking oral iron (nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, teeth staining, epigastric distress)
  •  Non-cooperative patient 
  •  Cases that are seen for the first time during the last 8–10 weeks with severe anemia.
